New Year's Day,  Martin Luther King Jr. Holiday (3rd Monday in January),  Good Friday,  Easter,  Mother's Day,  Father's Day,  Memorial Day,  July 4,  Labor Day,  Thanksgiving Day,  Christmas Day, 
or any holiday observed by the City of Rome. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3042; Ord. No. 06-11-7, § III, 11-20-06) 
Sec. 6-40. - Delay of interment, liability and right of city. 
The city shall be in no way liable for any delay in the interment of a body where a protest to the interment has been made, or where this chapter has not been complied with. The city reserves the right, under such circumstances, to place the body in a funeral home or a receiving vault until the full rights have been determined. The city may require any protest to be in writing and to be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3043) 
Sec. 6-41. - Reservation of right to require specified notice before interment. 
The right is reserved by the city to insist upon at least 24 hours' notice before any interment. Interment requests with less than 24 hours' notice may be refused. All requests with less than 12 hours' notice shall be refused. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3044) 
Sec. 6-42. - Liability for interment permit and identify of person sought to be interred or cremated. 
The city shall not be liable in damages for an error in the interment permit nor for a mistake or error in the identity of a person sought to be interred or cremated. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3045) 
Sec. 6-43. - Responsibility for telephone orders or mistakes caused by vague instructions. 
The city shall not be held responsible for any order given by telephone, or for any mistake occurring from the want of precise and proper instructions as to the particular space, size and location in a plot where interment is desired. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3046) 
Sec. 6-44. - Procedure when instructions from plot owner not available. 
When instructions from the plot owner regarding the location of an interment space in a plot cannot be obtained, or are indefinite, or when for any reason the interment space cannot be opened when specified, the city may, in its discretion, open it in such location in the plot as it deems best and proper so as not to delay the funeral; and the city shall not be liable in damages for any error so made. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3047) 
Sec. 6-45. - Error in interment. 
If an error is committed in the interment of the remains of any person, the city reserves the right to remove and reinter the remains in such other property of equal value and similar location as may be substituted and conveyed in lieu of the mistaken property. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3048) 
Sec. 6-46. - Disinterment—Permission prerequisite. 
No disinterment from any lot shall be made except with the express permission of the city clerk first obtained. The city clerk may insist that an order from a proper court of law first be secured by those seeking the disinterment. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3049) 
Sec. 6-47. - Same—Liability of city. 
The city shall exercise due care in making a disinterment and removal, but it shall assume no liability for damage to any casket, burial case, vault or urn, incurred in making the disinterment or removal. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3050) 
Sec. 6-48. - Removal of body for specified reasons repugnant to sense of decency prohibited. 
Removal of a body or cremated remains by the heirs of the deceased so that the plot, lot or space may be sold for profit to themselves, or removal contrary to the expressed or implied wish of the original plot owner, or if repugnant to the ordinary sense of decency, is absolutely forbidden. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3051) 
Sec. 6-49. - Limitation on number of bodies interred in same grave, vault, crypt or niche. 
Not more than one body, nor the remains of more than one body, shall be interred in any one grave, vault, crypt or niche. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3052) 
Sec. 6-50. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2007-10-8, § II, adopted Sept. 15, 2007, repealed § 6-50, which pertained to firearms within cemeteries; permit required. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 6-51. - Visitation hours; loitering in cemeteries. 
(a)  City cemeteries shall be open for visitation during the following hours, unless otherwise posted: Between one-half hour after sunup and one-half hour before sundown. 
(b)  Loitering in city cemeteries is prohibited. The presence of any person in any of such cemeteries during prohibited hours shall be prima facie evidence of loitering. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3054) 
Sec. 6-52. - Refreshments prohibited within cemeteries; exception. 
No person shall have refreshments within any cemetery except as authorized by the sexton. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3055) 
Sec. 6-53. - Persons within grounds to use only avenues, walks, alleys and roads. 
Persons within the cemetery grounds shall use only the avenues, walks, alleys and roads and shall not walk, drive or ride upon the lots, plots and spaces. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3056) 
Sec. 6-54. - Motor vehicles regulated. 
Motor vehicles shall not be driven through the cemetery grounds at a greater speed than ten miles per hour, and must always be kept on the righthand side of the cemetery roadway. Motor vehicles are not allowed to park or to come to a full stop in front of an open grave unless such motor vehicles are in attendance at the funeral. No offroad recreational vehicles shall be allowed in city cemeteries. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3057) 
Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 12. 
Sec. 6-55. - Maintenance account. 
(a)  The city shall establish a maintenance account for the longterm care and preservation of all city cemeteries. Monies for this account will be derived from the sale of cemetery lots and interment fees, and from the sale of each lot or each interment fee a minimum number of dollars, as set forth in the fee schedule book of the city, as provided in section 8-36, shall be used for this purpose. However, the entire fee from the sale of lots in the Memorial Addition to Myrtle Hill Cemetery shall be placed in this account. 
(b)  The maintenance account established in this section shall be a part of the city's general trust fund and will include, in addition to the fees referred to in subsection (a), all donations and other appropriations relating to cemeteries which the city may deem proper. The city can use only the interest from such maintenance account for the care and preservation of the city cemeteries. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3058) 
Sec. 6-56. - Interpretation, application and enforcement of provisions. 
This chapter shall be interpreted, applied and enforced by the public works committee. In cases of hardship, necessity or unreasonableness in the application or enforcement of any of the rules and regulations in this chapter, the majority of the public works committee shall have the right to alter the application and enforcement of these rules and regulations so as to relieve the hardship or unreasonableness, and the same shall not constitute forfeiture nor shall it have the effect of changing or abridging any rule, covenant or regulation under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3059) 
Sec. 6-57. - Violation of chapter. 
Any person performing any act forbidden by this chapter or failing to perform any act required by this chapter shall have breached this chapter and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided by section 1-9. 
(Ord. No. 82-4-1, § 1, 4-7-82; Code 1981, § 5-3060) 
Chapter 7 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; city divisions and departments, § 2-2; certain boards designated, § 2-78; fire prevention and protection, ch. 9; flood damage prevention, ch. 10; police, ch. 17. 
State Law reference— State militia, O.C.G.A. § 38-2-1 et seq.; emergency management, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-1 et seq.; local organizations for emergency management, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-27; emergency funds for local government, O.C.G.A. § 50-8-8. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Emergency management means the preparation for the carrying out of all emergency functions, other than functions for which the state and federal governments are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies, energy emergencies, or disasters, or the imminent threat thereof, of manmade or natural origin, caused by enemy attack, sabotage, civil disturbance, fire, flood, earthquake, wind, storm, wave action, oil spill, or other water contamination requiring emergency action to avert danger or damage, epidemic, air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, explosion, riot, or other hostile action, or other causes. These functions include, without limitation, firefighting services, police services, medical and health services, rescue, engineering, warning services, communications, defense from radiological, chemical and other special weapons, evacuation of persons from stricken areas, emergency welfare services, emergency transportation, plant protection, temporary restoration of public utility services, and other functions related to civilian protection, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to the preparation for and carrying out of the foregoing functions in the city. 
Energy emergency means a condition of danger to the health, safety, welfare, or economic well-being of the citizens of this city arising out of a present or threatened shortage of usable energy resources; also any condition of substantial danger to the health, safety, or welfare of the citizens of this city resulting from the operation of any electrical power-generating facility, the transport of any energy resource by any means whatsoever, or the production, use or disposal of any source material, special nuclear material, or byproduct, as defined by the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 (68 Stat. 919, 42 USC 2011 et seq.); also any nuclear incident, as defined by the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 (68 Stat. 919, 42 USC 2011 et seq.), occurring within or outside this city substantially affecting the health, safety, or welfare of the citizens of this city. 
(Ord. No. 82-5-1, § 1, 5-3-82; Code 1981, § 4-3001) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3. 
Sec. 7-2. - Liberality of construction. 
This chapter shall be construed liberally in order to effectuate its purposes. 
(Ord. No. 82-5-1, § 1, 5-3-82; Code 1981, § 4-3007) 
Sec. 7-3. - Emergency management agency—Established; office of director; nominations, appointments, general duties of director. 
There is hereby established in the city an emergency management agency. The city commission shall nominate, for appointment by the governor, a director of the emergency management agency for the city. When appointed, the emergency management agency director shall: 
(1)  Represent the governing officials of the city on matters pertaining to emergency management. 
(2)  Assist city officials in organizing city departments for emergency operations. 
(3)  Develop in conjunction with other city departments, the plan for emergency functions set forth in section 7-1. Such plan will be consonant with the state emergency plan and shall be submitted to the city commission for approval and thence to the state director for approval. 
(4)  Maintain the emergency management agency in carrying out the day-to-day administration of the emergency management agency and disaster program including the rendering of required reports. 
(5)  Render reports such as financial and daily activity reports as required by governing officials in keeping with good business practices. 
(6)  Procure, with authority of governing officials, a facility to be used as the city emergency operating center. 
(7)  Serve as manager of the E-911 emergency telephone system. 
(8)  During periods of a declared emergency, and under the supervision of governing officials, coordinate the activities of the city emergency operating center staff. 
(Ord. No. 82-5-1, § 1, 5-3-82; Code 1981, § 4-3002) 
Sec. 7-4. - Same—Duties of city departments. 
The emergency management agency shall be established around existing city departments and agencies, and the emergency functions listed in section 7-1 are assigned to departments of the city as provided in this section. Emergency functions are also assigned to appropriate departments of the county. 

 
Heads of departments listed above are responsible for developing the plan for their assigned emergency function. Such plans shall be submitted through the emergency management agency director to the city manager and then to the city commission for approval. 
(Ord. No. 82-5-1, § 1, 5-3-82; Code 1981, § 4-3003) 
Sec. 7-5. - Emergency powers. 
In the event of an actual attack upon the United States or any other disaster which may affect the lives and property of the citizens of the city, the chairman of the city commission or, in his absence, his legally appointed successor, may declare that a state of emergency exists and thereafter shall have and may exercise for such period as such state of emergency exists or continues, the following emergency powers: 
(1)  To enforce all rules, laws and regulations relating to emergency management and to assume direct operational control over all emergency management forces. 
(2)  To seize, take for temporary use, or condemn any property or supplies for the protection of the public. 
(3)  To sell, lend, give or distribute all or any such property or supplies among the inhabitants of the city and to maintain a strict accounting of property or supplies distributed and for funds received for such property or supplies. 
(4)  To perform and exercise such other functions and duties and to take such emergency actions as may be necessary to promote and secure the safety, protection and well-being of the inhabitants of the city. 
(Ord. No. 82-5-1, § 1, 5-3-82; Code 1981, § 4-3004) 
State Law reference— Powers of local organizations for emergency management, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-27. 
Sec. 7-6. - Volunteers. 
All persons other than officers and employees of the city, performing emergency functions pursuant to this chapter, shall serve with or without compensation. While engaged in such emergency functions, volunteers shall have the same immunities as city officers and employees. 
(Ord. No. 82-5-1, § 1, 5-3-82; Code 1981, § 4-3005) 
Sec. 7-7. - Penalties. 
Any person violating any provision of this chapter or any rule, order or regulation made pursuant to this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable as is set out in section 1-9. 
(Ord. No. 82-5-1, § 1, 5-3-82; Code 1981, § 4-3006) 
Sec. 7-8. - Curfews during times of emergency or disaster. 
(a)  Authorized. Consistent with the Georgia Emergency Management Act, the city may, in times of a state of emergency, declare a curfew within the limits of the city. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  Curfew. A "curfew" is a regulation requiring the withdrawal of any person not otherwise exempt from this section from appearing in certain public areas during specified hours. 
(2)  Exempt individuals. Unless otherwise specified in the declaration implementing the curfew, "exempt individuals" include those individuals engaged in the provision of designated, essential services, such as fire, law enforcement, emergency medical services and hospital services, military services, and utility emergency repairs. The declaration may, in the discretion of the Rome City Commission, the mayor, or the city manager, also exempt regular employees of local industries traveling to and from their jobs with appropriate identification, news media employees, building and repair contractors, properly registered according to chapter 7, article I, section 7-10 of this Code, performing activities related to construction, repair, renovation or improvement of buildings and other structures damaged during the disaster or emergency. 
(3)  State of emergency. "State of emergency" shall have the same meaning as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3, to-wit: "the condition declared by the Governor when, in his judgment, the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster, emergency, or energy emergency in any part of the state is of sufficient severity and magnitude to warrant extraordinary assistance by the state to supplement the efforts and available resources of the several localities and relief organizations in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship, or suffering threatened or caused thereby," or shall be deemed to exist during the proclamation of a civil emergency as set forth in section 7-37 of this Code. 
(c)  Declaration of a curfew. Upon a state of emergency, the Rome City Commission, the mayor, or the city manager may declare a curfew within the city or within designated parts of the city. To the extent possible given the nature of the state of emergency, the city will make reasonable efforts to provide public notification of the curfew. 
(d)  Curfew during a state of emergency. It shall be prohibited for any person, other than exempt individuals, to appear in public in the territory subject to the curfew, including but not limited to, streets, highways, alleys, sidewalks, vacant lots, parks, public buildings or any other public places in all or a designated part of the city during the stated hours of the curfew. 
(e)  Warnings; citation or arrest. Any person, other than an exempt individual, found in public in the territory subject to a curfew shall be notified of the curfew, given a warning, and shall promptly exit the curfew area. If such person fails or refuses to promptly exit the curfew area, such person shall be subject to citation or arrest. 
(f)  Penalties. For violations of the curfew, the city may punish a violator as provided in section 1-9 of this Code for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 2011-4-1, § I, 4-4-11) 
Sec. 7-9. - Price gouging during times of emergency or disaster. 
(a)  Authorized. Consistent with its authority under the Georgia Emergency Management Act, the city may, in times of a state of emergency or a subsequent recovery period, prohibit price gouging. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  Price gouging. The term "price gouging" is defined as selling or offering for sale at retail any goods or services, including, but not limited to, gasoline, lumber, or food, necessary to preserve, protect, or sustain the life, health, or safety of persons or their property at a price higher than the price at which such goods or services were sold or offered for sale immediately prior to the state of emergency; provided, however, that such price may be increased only in an amount which accurately reflects an increase in costs of goods or services to the person selling the goods or services or an increase in the cost of transporting the goods or services into the city due to the state of emergency. 
(2)  State of emergency. "State of emergency" shall have the same meaning as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3, to-wit: "the condition declared by the Governor when, in his judgment, the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster, emergency, or energy emergency in any part of the state is of sufficient severity and magnitude to warrant extraordinary assistance by the state to supplement the efforts and available resources of the several localities and relief organizations in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship, or suffering threatened or caused thereby," or shall be deemed to exist during the proclamation of a civil emergency as set forth in Section 7-37 of this Code. 
(3)  Subsequent recovery period. The term "subsequent recovery period" is defined as that period during which the underlying reason for the state of emergency continues to cause disruptions to the territory subject to the state of emergency, but shall not exceed six months after the state of emergency has been terminated unless extended by official action of the Rome City Commission. 
(c)  Prohibition against price gouging. During a state of emergency or a subsequent recovery period, no firm, partnership, corporation, individual, or other entity located or doing business within the city shall engage or participate in price gouging. 
(d)  Citation or arrest. The city, in order to enforce this Code section, may issue citations or arrest individuals found in violation thereof. Each retail sale in which a firm, partnership, corporation, individual, or other entity has engaged or participated in price gouging shall constitute a separate violation of this Code section. 
(e)  Penalties. For violations of this Code section, the city may punish a violator as provided in section 1-9 of this Code for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 2011-4-3, § I, 4-4-11) 
Sec. 7-10. - Registration of building contractors during times of emergency or disaster. 
(a)  Authorized. Consistent with the Georgia Emergency Management Act, the city may, in times of a state of emergency, require the registration of building contractors conducting business in the city. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  Building contractor. As used in this Code section, the term "building contractor" shall mean any firm, partnership, corporation, individual, or other entity engaging in, undertaking, or carrying on any business relating to the construction, repair, renovation, or making of improvements to real property within the city, including, but not limited to any buildings, structures, or fixtures on real property. 
(2)  Conducting business. For the purposes of this Code section, a Building Contractor is "conducting business" in the city if: (a) he or she has or operates an office, agency, project site or place of business located in the limits of the city, whether permanently, temporarily, periodically, or otherwise, and provides construction, repair, renovation, or the making of improvements to real property within the city, including, but not limited to any buildings, structures, or fixtures on real property; or (b) he or she provides construction, repair, renovation, or the making of improvements to real property within the city, including, but not limited to any buildings, structures, or fixtures on real property within the city regardless of the location of the principal office. 
(3)  State of emergency. "State of emergency" shall have the same meaning as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3, to-wit: "the condition declared by the Governor when, in his judgment, the threat or actual occurrence of a disaster, emergency, or energy emergency in any part of the state is of sufficient severity and magnitude to warrant extraordinary assistance by the state to supplement the efforts and available resources of the several localities and relief organizations in preventing or alleviating the damage, loss, hardship, or suffering threatened or caused thereby," or shall be deemed to exist during the proclamation of a civil emergency as set forth in section 7-37 of this Code. 
(4)  Subsequent recovery period. The term "subsequent recovery period" is defined as that period during which the underlying reason for the state of emergency continues to cause disruptions to the territory subject to the state of emergency, but shall not exceed three months after the state of emergency has been terminated unless extended by official action of the Rome City Commission. 
(c)  Registration and certification of building contractors. All building contractors conducting business or proposing to conduct business within the limits of the city during a state of emergency or subsequent recovery period shall register and file applications with the building inspection department. The building contractor, or an officer, agent, or employee of the building contractor, shall provide the building inspection department with a statement describing the general nature of the business to be conducted and shall give true and correct information as may be required on the registration form, application or certificate provided by the building inspection department. Upon satisfaction that the building contractor has complied with the terms of this Code section, the building inspection department shall cause to be issued to the building contractor a certificate authorizing the building contractor and officers, agents, and employees of the building contractor, to do business within the city during a state of emergency or subsequent recovery period. Such certificate shall be valid during the applicable state of emergency and subsequent recovery period, unless revoked or suspended. 
(d)  Registration fee. Before issuance of the certificate by the building inspection department, the building contractor shall pay the city a registration fee of $50.00. 
(e)  Transferability. Each certificate issued by the building inspection department pursuant to this Code section is granted to the building contractor named thereon. Such certificate shall not be transferred to another firm, partnership, corporation, individual, or other entity. 
(f)  Display of certificate. Each certificate issued pursuant to this Code section shall be posted conspicuously by the building contractor in the place of the building contractor's business or shall be carried by the building contractor in a vehicle used by the building contractor to conduct business. Such certificate shall be exhibited to any authorized officer of the city upon request. 
(g)  Revocation or suspension of the certificate. Each certificate issued pursuant to this Code section is a mere permit for conducting business within the city during a state of emergency and subsequent recovery period. The city may revoke or suspend such certificate if the building contractor, or any officer, agent, or employee of the building contractor, violates this Code section or any other law, rule, or regulation of the City of Rome, the State of Georgia, or the United States. If, after the city issues a certificate, the city desires to revoke such certificate, it shall provide written notice of the revocation to the building contractor. Such revocation notice shall indicate the reason or reasons for the revocation. The building contractor may contest the revocation in the Municipal Court of the City of Rome. 
(f)  Warnings; citations. The city, in order to enforce this Code section, may issue warnings and citations. 
(g)  Penalties. For violations of this Code section, the city may punish a violator as provided in section 1-9 of this Code for each violation. Each day in which a building contractor conducts business in the city without a certificate shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 2011-4-4, § I, 4-4-11) 
Sec. 7-11. - Authority to waive procedures during states of emergency. 
(a)  Authorized. Consistent with the Georgia Emergency Management Act, in times of a state of emergency, the city may meet in a temporary location or locations and ignore certain time-consuming procedures and formalities as prescribed by law. 
(b)  Definitions. 
(1)  Fees. For the purposes of this Code section, "fee" or "fees" shall mean any fee or rate charged by the city for building permits, land disturbance permits, zoning applications, special land use permits, temporary land use permits, or any other fees relating to the reconstruction, repair, and clean-up of areas impacted by the underlying cause of a state of emergency. This term shall not include those fees collected by the city on behalf of the federal or state government or those fees charged by the city pursuant to a federal or state regulation, rule, or statute. 
(2)  State of emergency. For the purposes of this Code section, "state of emergency" shall mean an emergency or disaster resulting from man-made or natural causes or enemy attack, that makes it imprudent, inexpedient, or impossible to conduct the affairs of the city at the regular or usual times of places thereof or shall be deemed to exist during the declaration of a state of emergency or disaster by the Governor of the State of Georgia, as described in O.C.G.A. § 38-3-51, or a proclamation of a civil emergency as set forth in section 7-37 of this Code. 
(3)  Temporary dwelling. For the purposes of this Code section, "temporary dwelling" shall mean any mobile or easily-movable shelter, including, but not limited to mobile homes, trailers, or recreational vehicles, intended for occupation by persons not otherwise permitted by the zoning regulations in a particular part of the city. 
(c)  Location and powers during a state of emergency. During a state of emergency, the Rome City Commission may meet at any place within the limits or outside the limits of the city upon the call of the mayor, or in his or her absence or inability to act, the mayor pro tempore, or any other two commissioners, and shall proceed to establish and designate by ordinance, resolution, or other manner alternate or substitute sites or places as the emergency temporary location or locations of where all or any part of the city's business may be transacted or conducted during the state of emergency. Such temporary location or locations may be within or outside the limits of the city, and may be within or outside the State of Georgia. During the period in which city business is being conducted at the temporary location or locations, the Rome City Commission and other officers of the city shall have and possess all of the executive, legislative, and judicial powers conferred upon the Rome City Commission and other officers by or under the City Charter, this Code, and the laws of the State of Georgia. All acts of the Rome City Commission and other officers of the city during a state of emergency and performed outside of the limits of the city shall have the same effect as if performed within the limits of the city. 
(d)  Waiver of time-consuming procedures and formalities. During a state of emergency, the powers of the Rome City Commission and other officers of the city may be exercised in the light of the exigencies of the state of emergency without regard to or compliance with time-consuming procedures and formalities prescribed by law and pertaining to the city. 
(e)  Fees. During a state of emergency, the Rome City Commission or its designee may temporarily reduce or waive fees to encourage the rebuilding or clean-up of an area within the city impacted by the underlying reason for a state of emergency. 
(f)  Purchasing and public works contracts. During a state of emergency, the Rome City Commission, the city manager, or the director of the city finance department may waive the requirements of city procurement code for public works contracts. However, any such waiver shall be recorded in the minutes of the city as soon as practical and the underlying reason for the state of emergency shall be described therein. 
(g)  Enforcement of the Code. Upon a declaration of a state of emergency or disaster by the Governor of the State of Georgia, as described in O.C.G.A. § 38-3-51, or the proclamation of a civil emergency by the city, as described in section 7-37 of this Code, the Rome City Commission, mayor, or city manager may temporarily suspend the enforcement of this Code, or any portion thereof, where: (1) the emergency or disaster is of such nature that immediate action outside of the Code is required; (2) such suspension is consistent with the protection of the public health, safety, and welfare; and (3) such suspension is not inconsistent with the federal or state constitutions or any federal or state regulations, rules, or statutes. 
(h)  Temporary dwellings. Upon a declaration of a state of emergency or disaster by the Governor of the State of Georgia, as described in O.C.G.A. § 38-3-51, or the proclamation of a civil emergency by the city, as described in section 7-37 of this Code, the city may provide temporary dwelling structures in any zoning district of the city while the primary dwellings of residents of the city are being repaired, replaced, or cleaned up due to damage caused by the underlying reason for a state of emergency; provided, however, that the building inspection department shall review the plans for such temporary dwelling structures and issue a permit therefor. The duration of the permit shall not exceed six months. In the case of continuing hardship and in the discretion of the building inspection department, the permit may be extended up to an additional six months. Upon expiration of the permit or an extension thereof, such temporary dwellings shall be removed. 
(Ord. No. 2011-4-2, § I, 4-4-11) 
Secs. 7-12—7-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CIVIL EMERGENCIES 

Sec. 7-36. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Civil emergency means: 
(1)  A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by mob action or civil disobedience, or by the use of actual force or violence, or by any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power to execute by three or more persons acting together without authority of law. 
(2)  Any natural disaster or manmade calamity including flood, conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion within the corporate limits of, or affecting, the city, resulting in the death or injury of persons or the destruction of property to such extent that extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
Curfew means a prohibition against any person walking, running, loitering, standing, motoring or otherwise being present upon any alley, street, highway, public property or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the city, except persons officially designated for duty with reference to such civil emergency. 
Incendiary missile means any type of bottle or container containing gasoline or other flammable or explosive material. 
Weapon means any club, bottle, board, rock, gun, knife, instrument or object of any kind used, or intended to be used against the person or property of another. 
(Code 1959, § 11A-1; Code 1981, § 4-3021) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 7-37. - Proclamation of civil emergency; powers of one proclaiming. 
Whenever, in the judgment of the chairman of the city commission, or in the event of his absence or inability to act, of the city manager, it is determined that a civil emergency exists, he shall have power to impose by proclamation any or all of the following regulations necessary to preserve the peace and order of the city: 
(1)  To impose a curfew pursuant to the provisions of section 7-8 of this Code. 
(2)  To order the closing of any business establishments or clubs anywhere within the city for the period of the emergency, such businesses to include, but not be limited to, those selling intoxicating liquors, malt beverages, firearms, ammunition and explosives and gasoline or other flammable materials. 
(3)  To designate any public street, thoroughfare or vehicle parking area closed to motor vehicles and pedestrian traffic. 
(4)  To call upon regular and reserve law enforcement agencies and organizations within or without the city to assist in preserving and keeping the peace within the city. 
(5)  To issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the preservation of peace and the protection of life and property. 
(Code 1959, § 11A-2; Code 1981, § 4-3022; Ord. No. 2011-4-1, § II, 4-4-11) 
Sec. 7-38. - When proclamation effective. 
The proclamation of emergency provided for in this article shall become effective upon its issuance in writing and dissemination to the public by appropriate news media. 
(Code 1959, § 11A-3; Code 1981, § 4-3023) 
Sec. 7-39. - Termination and renewal of proclamation. 
Any emergency proclaimed in accordance with the provisions of this article shall terminate after 24 hours from the issuance thereof, or upon issuance of a proclamation determining that such an emergency no longer exists, whichever occurs sooner; provided, however, that such emergency may be extended for such additional periods of time as may be determined necessary by resolution of the city commission. 
(Code 1959, § 11A-4; Code 1981, § 4-3024) 
Sec. 7-40. - Offenses. 
During the time of a proclaimed emergency under this article, the following shall be considered violations punishable as provided in section 1-9. It shall be unlawful: 
(1)  For any unauthorized person to remain at the place or scene of any riot or unlawful assembly after he has been ordered to disperse by the police or any other lawful authority. 
(2)  For any person not designated for duty to possess, carry or use, either on his person or within a vehicle, any weapon. 
(3)  For any person to make, possess, store, carry, use, disseminate or receive any type of fire bomb, explosive Molotov cocktail, or any other incendiary missile or the materials for the making and production of same. 
(4)  For any person not designated for duty to possess, carry or use any knife or any firearm or the ammunition for use in the same. 
(5)  For any person to possess, carry or consume alcoholic beverages in a public street or place within any restricted area designated as provided in section 7-37. 
(6)  For any person to disobey any order contained in the proclamation of emergency. 
(Code 1959, § 11A-5; Code 1981, § 4-3025) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 3. 
Chapter 8 - FINANCE AND TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Finance, art. X; bonded indebtedness, art. XI; taxation, art. XII. 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; city divisions and departments, § 2-2; standing committees of city commission, § 2-51; alcoholic beverages, ch. 3; alcoholic beverage excise taxes, § 3-351 et seq.; buildings, ch. 5. 
State Constitution reference— Taxation power of municipal governments, art. IX, § IV. 
State Law reference— Revenue and taxation, O.C.G.A. tit. 48; ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq.; municipal taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Ad valorem tax. 
An annual ad valorem tax upon all real and personal property within the city is hereby levied. The millage rate therefor shall be established each year by resolution of the city commission. The rate shall not exceed the total of the rates authorized by law for general, recreation, education and debt retirement needs of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 3-3001) 
Cross reference— Parks, recreation and cultural affairs, ch. 15. 
Sec. 8-2. - Procurement code incorporated by reference. 
A certain document, one copy of which is on file in the office of the secretary, where it is available for public inspection, being known as the Rome Procurement Code, 1980 edition, adopted by the city commission on February 1, 1980, and all amendments thereto, are hereby incorporated in this section and made a part of this Code by reference. 
(Code 1981, § 3-2001) 
Secs. 8-3—8-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FINANCIAL ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 8-36. - Fee schedule book. 
The secretary shall keep and maintain a record of all license fees, business and occupation taxes, fees and service charges established and required by the city for the use or purchase of city services and for permits and licenses and any other regulatory or administrative fee or charge imposed by the city. The record and any amendments or changes thereto shall be adopted by the city commission by resolution and shall be known as the fee schedule book of the city. An official copy thereof shall be maintained in the office of the secretary and shall be available for public inspection. The fee schedule book and any amendments that may be made to it are hereby incorporated into this Code and made a part hereof as if fully set forth in this section. 
(Code 1981, § 3-1001) 
Sec. 8-37. - Fiscal year. 
The fiscal year of the city shall begin on January 1 and end on December 31. 
(Code 1981, § 3-1002) 
State Law reference— Fiscal year, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-81-2, 36-81-3. 
Sec. 8-38. - Authority to charge penalties and interest for delinquent taxes and other unpaid bills. 
(a)  Acceptance of checks, drafts, etc. The city, by and through its authorized personnel, is hereby authorized to accept a check, draft, money order, etc., payable to the order of the city, upon which a proper receipt will be written. 
(b)  Credit. The head of a department may extend credit only as authorized by the city manager. 
(c)  Unpaid checks, drafts, etc. If any instrument of payment given to the city is returned unpaid by the bank for any reason whatsoever, there shall be added to the tax or fee being paid a penalty or collection fee as established by resolution and shown in the fee schedule of the city. 
(d)  Penalty and interest on unpaid bills. There shall be added to any tax bill, water bill or other bill not paid by the due date or within a specified grace period, penalty and interest in an amount as established by resolution and shown in the fee schedule of the city. 
(e)  Collection of delinquent taxes, bills, etc. The departments of the city shall diligently collect, or attempt collection of, all taxes, water bills or other bills, and upon their inability to do so, the city manager may enter into a contract or contracts for the collection of such delinquent taxes, bills, etc. 
(Ord. No. 84-5-3, § 1, 5-7-84; Code 1981, § 3-1004) 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 22. 
Secs. 8-39—8-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - INSURANCE COMPANIES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal licensing of insurance companies, brokers and agents, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-71. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 92-12-6, § 1, adopted Dec. 21, 1992, repealed former § 8-71 in its entirety, which pertained to definitions. 
Sec. 8-72. - Gross premiums tax imposed—On life insurers. 
(a)  There is hereby levied an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident, and sickness insurance within the city in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 8-97. 
(b)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Gross direct premiums means gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. 
(Ord. No. 83-12-2, § 5, 12-19-83; Code 1981, § 3-4035) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-73. - Same—On all other insurers. 
(a)  There is hereby levied an annual tax upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in class (1) as set out in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5, doing business within the city in an amount equal to 2½ percent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. 
(b)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Gross direct premiums shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2(a). 
(Ord. No. 83-12-2, § 6, 12-19-83; Code 1981, § 3-4036) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 8-74—8-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE FEES 

Sec. 8-96. - Fee schedule. 
The amount of the license fee for each class of license levied under this division shall be as set forth in the fee schedule book of the city as provided in section 8-36. 
Sec. 8-97. - Levied on insurers generally. 
There is hereby levied, for the year 1984 and for each year thereafter, an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business within the city in the amount of $100.00. For each separate business location in excess of one not covered by section 8-98, which is operating on behalf of such insurers within the city, there is hereby levied a license fee in the amount of $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 83-12-2, § 2, 12-19-83; Code 1981, § 3-4032; Ord. No. 92-12-6, § 2, 12-21-92) 
Sec. 8-98. - Levied on life insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. 
For each separate business location, not otherwise subject to a license fee under this division, operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and in connection with such loans or sales, offers, solicits or takes application for insurance through a licensed agent of a life insurer for life insurance, such insurer shall pay an additional license fee for each location for each year. 
(Ord. No. 83-12-2, § 3, 12-19-83; Code 1981, § 3-4033) 
Sec. 8-99. - Levied on life insurance agencies; independent life insurance agencies, brokers, etc., not otherwise licensed. 
There is hereby levied an annual license fee upon independent agencies and brokers for each separate business location from which a life insurance business is conducted and which is not subject to the company license fee imposed by section 8-97, for each such location within the city. 
(Ord. No. 83-12-2, § 4, 12-19-83; Code 1981, § 3-4034) 
Sec. 8-100. - Due date. 
License fees imposed in this division shall be due and payable by January 31 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 83-12-2, § 7, 12-19-83; Code 1981, § 3-4037) 
Secs. 8-101—8-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TELEPHONE COMPANIES 

Sec. 8-131. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Recurring local service revenues means: 
(1)  Monthly charges for local exchange service, including: 
a.  Charges for additional listings and joint users. 
b.  The guarantee portion of the charge for semipublic pay station services. 
c.  Charges for local message rate service, including mobile service local messages. 
d.  Subscriber station revenues from teletype-writer exchange service. 
(2)  Charges for Morse transmission, signaling, data transmission, remote metering and supervisory control, where both terminal points are within the city limits. 
(3)  All charges for local private lines service (except audio and video program transmission services) where both terminals of the private lines are within the city limits. 
(Code 1959, § 17-44; Code 1981, § 3-4051) 
Sec. 8-132. - Occupational license tax. 
Telephone companies operating within the corporate limits of the city shall pay an occupational license tax in the amount set forth in the fee schedule book of the city as provided in section 8-36. 
(Code 1959, § 17-45; Code 1981, § 3-4052) 
Sec. 8-133. - Payment of license tax. 
The occupational license tax levied under this article shall be paid in quarterly installments, each of which shall be due on or before the last day of the second month following the end of each calendar quarter and shall be based on taxable revenues billed during such calendar quarter. Any amount of license tax previously paid, and absorbed by the company, which is applicable to any period under this article shall be credited against the amounts imposed in this section or by subsequent ordinance. 
(Code 1959, § 17-46; Code 1981, § 3-4053) 
Secs. 8-134—8-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ATTORNEYS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Annotation— Ordinance, when construed along with statutes of state, was not subject to constitutional attacks leveled against it. Robbins v. City of Rome, 230 Ga. 901, 199 S.E. 2d 802 (1973). 
State Law reference— Levy of license or occupation tax upon practitioners of professions, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5. 

Sec. 8-166. - Application of article. 
The passage and application of this article within the corporate limits of the city recognizes that a city may levy an occupational or license tax upon the practice of the legal profession within its municipal limits, but may not regulate the legal profession, since the power to license and regulate attorneys at law is vested in the Supreme Court of the state and administered through that court and through the State Bar of Georgia. 
(Code 1959, § 17-47; Code 1981, § 3-4061) 
Sec. 8-167. - Tax levied for specified purposes. 
(a)  For the purpose of raising revenue for the support and maintenance of the government of the city, including the payment of bonds, interest on the bonded debts, paving streets and to defray any other necessary legal expense of the city, the license tax specified in this article is hereby levied and is to be collected for each fiscal year beginning January 1 and ending December 31 of each year. 
(b)  Such license tax is levied against and is to be paid by all persons who may engage in, prosecute, follow or carry on within the corporate limits of the city, the practice of law. 
(Code 1959, § 17-48; Code 1981, § 3-4062) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 20. 
Sec. 8-168. - License tax—Amount. 
The license tax for attorneys at law for each person practicing law within the city shall be in the amount set forth in the fee schedule book of the city as provided in section 8-36. 
(Code 1959, § 17-49; Code 1981, § 3-4063) 
Sec. 8-169. - Same—Default; interest and penalty; collection. 
(a)  Attorneys at law shall have until and including May 1 of each year to pay the tax levied under this article, after which date any such attorney failing to pay shall be in default. 
(b)  Upon the expiration of 30 days after such default, or sooner as the secretary deems necessary to protect the interests of the city, he shall issue a fi. fa. for the amount of the license tax with interest, as other tax fi. fas. in favor of the city are issued. Thereupon the secretary shall turn the same over to the chief of police, and it shall be the chief's duty to force collection of the same by levy and sell the same as other tax fi. fas. in favor of the city are sold. 
(c)  The tax, if not paid when due, shall bear interest at the rate of 33 1/3 percent per month from May 1 of each year, or from the date of beginning practice of such profession in the city if such practice is begun after May 1 of each year. 
(Code 1959, § 17-50; Code 1981, § 3-4064) 
Secs. 8-170—8-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DEPOSITORY FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS 

Sec. 8-191. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Depository financial institution means state and national banking associations, federal savings and loan associations and state building and loan associations. 
Gross receipts has the same meaning as, and is determined in accordance with, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 
(Ord. No. 83-12-2, § 1, 12-19-83; Code 1981, § 3-4071) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-192. - Business license tax—Imposed. 
There is hereby levied upon depository financial institutions within the city an annual business license tax at the rate set forth in the fee schedule book of the city as provided in section 8-36. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, the minimum amount of annual business license tax due from any depository financial institution pursuant to this article shall be the amount provided in such fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 83-12-2, § 2, 12-19-83; Code 1981, § 3-4072) 
Sec. 8-193. - Same—Due date; filing of return. 
Each depository financial institution within the city shall file a return of its gross receipts with the city by March 1 of the year following the year in which such gross receipts are measured. Such returns shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by state law and regulation. The tax levied pursuant to this article shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in the return. The due date of taxes levied by this article shall be April 1, 1984, and April 1 of each subsequent year. 
(Ord. No. 83-12-2, § 3, 12-19-83; Code 1981, § 3-4073) 
Sec. 8-194. - Same—Payment when no current ad valorem tax digest available. 
If as of March 1 of any year, no current ad valorem tax digest is available or no current ad valorem tax rate has been set by the city commission, savings and loan institutions doing business within the city shall file their returns and pay the taxes called for in this article within ten days of the date a current ad valorem tax computation is possible. 
(Ord. No. 83-12-2, § 4, 12-19-83; Code 1981, § 3-4074) 
Secs. 8-195—8-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - MOTEL-HOTEL EXCISE TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Excise tax on rooms, lodgings and accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 

Sec. 8-226. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Due date means not later than the 20th day after the close of the monthly period for which the tax is to be computed. 
Guestroom means a room occupied, or intended, arranged or designed for occupancy, by one or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. It shall not include meeting rooms or exhibition halls. 
Hotel means any structure or any portion of a structure including any lodginghouse, roominghouse, dormitory, Turkish bath, bachelor hotel, studio hotel, motel, motor hotel, auto court, inn, public club or private club, containing guestrooms and which is occupied or is intended or designed for occupancy by guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor or otherwise. It does not include any jail, hospital, asylum, sanitarium, nursing or convalescent home, orphanage, prison, detention or other building in which human beings are housed and detained under legal restraint. 
Innkeeper means any person who is subject to taxation under this article for the furnishing for value to the public any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations; and any person or organization who voluntarily collects the tax under this article. 
Monthly period means a calendar month of any year. 
Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of any room or apartment in a hotel or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room or apartment. 
Occupant means any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses or has the right of use or possession of any guestroom in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use or other agreement, or otherwise. 
Operator means any person operating a hotel in the city including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, or a lessee, sublessee, lender in possession, licensee or any other person otherwise operating such hotel. 
Permanent resident means any occupant of a hotel, once that occupant has stayed in the hotel for more than 30 consecutive days. 
Person means an individual, firm, partnership, joint venture association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, nonprofit corporation or cooperative nonprofit membership, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate or any other group or combination acting as a unit, except the United States of America, the state and any political subdivision of either thereof upon which the city is without power to impose the tax provided in this article. 
Rent means the consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. 
Return means any return filed or required to be filed as provided in this article. 
Tax means the tax imposed by this article. 
Tourism development purposes means the expenditure of funds, which may include capital costs and operating expenses, for the creation or expansion of physical attractions which are available and open to the public and which improve destination appeal to visitors, support visitors' experience, and are used by visitors. 
(Code 1959, § 17-62; Code 1981, § 3-6002; Ord. No. 98-8-1, § I, 8-17-98; Ord. No. 2009-9-6, § I, 9-21-09; Ord. No. 2014-5-1, § I, 5-27-14; Ord. No. 2014-11-1, § I, 11-10-14) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-227. - Intent. 
(a)  The intent of this article is to impose a tax, pursuant to authority granted by the General Assembly of this state, the funds from which taxation shall be used for public purposes and may be used for the purpose of promoting, attracting, stimulating, and developing conventions and tourism in the city. 
(b)  The city shall expend, for the purposes of promoting tourism, conventions, and trade shows in each fiscal year during which the tax is collected an amount which is not less than the amount which would have been spent if the tax rate had not been increased from five percent to eight percent, plus 12½ percent of the total tax collected at the rate of eight percent, and plus 25 percent of the total tax collected at the rate of eight percent. Provided further that 12½ percent of the tax collected at the rate of eight percent shall be used for the marketing and promotion of the county convention center known as the Forum. Provided further that 25 percent of the tax collected at the rate of eight percent shall be used for tourism development purposes, and, more specifically, shall be allocated for maintenance, operation, and promotion expenses related to The Tennis Center of Georgia at Berry College. 
(Code 1959, § 17-61; Code 1981, § 3-6001; Ord. No. 95-6-3, § I, 6-19-95; Ord. No. 2014-5-1, § II, 5-27-14) 
Sec. 8-228. - Imposition; rate. 
There is hereby imposed and there shall be paid a tax of eight percent of the rent for every occupancy of a guestroom in a hotel in the city. The tax shall be paid upon any occupancy on and after July 1, 2014, although such occupancy is had pursuant to a contract, lease, or other arrangement made prior to such date. 
(Code 1959, § 17-63; Ord. No. 88-1-1, § 1, 1-19-88; Ord. No. 95-6-3, § II, 6-19-95; Ord. No. 2014-5-1, § III, 5-27-14) 
Sec. 8-229. - Collection of tax by operator; receipt to occupant; rules for reporting and remittance of taxes collected. 
(a)  Every operator maintaining a place of business in the city and renting guestrooms in the city shall collect a tax of eight percent on the amount of rent from the occupant unless an exemption is provided under section 8-230. 
(b)  Such operator shall provide a receipt to each occupant to whom the tax is charged, showing the amount of rent and the amount of all taxes by category. 
(c)  All taxes shall be due and collected at the same time that the rent is collected. 
(d)  The proceeds of such taxes shall be used in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(b). 
(Code 1959, § 17-64; Code 1981, § 3-6004; Ord. No. 88-7-2, § 1, 7-18-88; Ord. No. 95-6-3, § III, 6-19-95; Ord. No. 05-5-10, § I, 5-16-05; Ord. No. 2014-5-1, § IV, 5-27-14) 
Sec. 8-230. - Exemptions. 
No tax shall be imposed under this article upon a permanent resident or upon Georgia state or local government officials or employees when traveling on official business. 
(Code 1959, § 17-65; Code 1981, § 3-6005; Ord. No. 88-1-1, § 1, 1-19-88) 
Sec. 8-231. - Registration of operator; form and contents; execution; certificate of authority. 
Every person engaging or about to engage in business as an operator of a hotel in the city shall immediately register with the city clerk on a form provided therefor. Such registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his place(s) of business and such other information which would facilitate the collection of the tax as the city clerk may require. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person; in case of ownership by an association or partnership, by a member or partner; in the case of ownership by a corporation, by an officer. The city clerk shall, after such registration, issue without charge a certificate of authority to each operator to collect the tax from the occupant. A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of an operator. Each certificate shall state the name and location of the business to which it is applicable. 
(Code 1959, § 17-66; Code 1981, § 3-6006; Ord. No. 2014-5-1, § V, 5-27-14) 
Sec. 8-232. - Determination, returns and payments. 
(a)  All amounts of the tax shall be due and payable monthly on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each respective monthly period. 
(b)  On or before the 20th day of the month following each monthly period, each operator of each hotel shall file a return with the city clerk, showing the gross rent, rent from permanent residents, rent from government officials or employees while traveling on official business, taxable rent, amount of taxes due for the related period, and such other information as may be required by the city clerk. 
(c)  Operators collecting the tax shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if such amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of deduction shall be the rate authorized for deductions from the state sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-1 et seq. 
(Code 1981, § 3-6007; Ord. No. 2014-5-1, § VI, 5-27-14) 
Sec. 8-233. - Deficiency determinations. 
(a)  Recomputation of tax; authority; basis of recomputation. If the city clerk is not satisfied with the accuracy of the return of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any person, the city clerk may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within the city clerk's possession or that may come into his possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly periods. 
(b)  Interest on deficiency. The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of 12 percent per annum from the due date of the tax, until the date of payment. 
(c)  Notice of determination; service. The city clerk or his designated representatives shall give to the operator written notice of the city clerk's determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the operator at his address as it appears in the records of the city clerk. Service by mail is complete when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by the addressee. 
(d)  Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period should last expire. 
(e)  When any innkeeper or operator fails to make any return or to pay the full amount of the tax required by this article, there shall be imposed, in addition to other penalties provided by law, a penalty to be added to the tax in the amount of five percent or $5.00, whichever is greater, if the failure is for not more than 30 days and an additional five percent or $5.00, for each additional 30 days or fraction of 30 days during which the failure continues. The penalty for any single violation shall not exceed 25 percent or $25.00 in the aggregate, whichever is greater. If the failure is due to providential cause shown to the satisfaction of the city clerk in affidavit form attached to the return and remittance is made within ten days of due date, the return may be accepted exclusive of penalties and interest. In the case of a false or fraudulent return or a failure to file a return where willful intent exists to defraud the City of Rome of any tax due under this article, a penalty of 50 percent of the tax due shall be assessed. 
(f)  All civil penalties and interest added to any tax imposed under this article and collected by the City of Rome shall be included as revenue derived from such tax for purposes of the expenditure requirements imposed on the city as provided by Georgia law. 
(Code 1959, § 17-68; Code 1981, § 3-6008; Ord. No. 2014-5-1, § VII, 5-27-14; Ord. No. 2014-11-1, § II, 11-10-14) 
Sec. 8-234. - Determination if no return made. 
(a)  If any person fails to make a return, the city clerk shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the person, or as the case may be, of the amount of the total rentals in the city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the periods in respect to which the person failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is in, or may come into, the possession of the city clerk. Written notice shall be given in the manner prescribed in section 8-233(c). 
(b)  The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of 12 percent per annum from the due date of the tax, until the date of payment. 
(Code 1959, § 17-69; Code 1981, § 3-6009; Ord. No. 2014-5-1, § VIII, 5-27-14) 
Sec. 8-235. - Administration of article. 
(a)  Authority of city clerk. The city clerk shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the collection of the tax imposed by this article. 
(b)  Records required from operators; form. Every operator renting guestrooms in the city to a person shall keep such records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers and in such form as the city clerk may require. 
(c)  Examination of records; audits. The city clerk or any person authorized in writing by the city clerk may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator renting guestrooms to a person and any operator liable for the tax, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid. 
(d)  Authority to require reports; contents. In the administration of the provisions of this article, the city clerk may require the filing of reports by any persons or class of persons having in their possession or custody information relating to rentals of guestrooms which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the city clerk when required by the city clerk and shall set forth the rental charged for each occupancy, the dates of occupancy, and such other information as the city clerk may require. 
(Code 1959, § 17-70; Code 1981, § 3-6010; Ord. No. 2014-5-1, § IX, 5-27-14) 
Sec. 8-236. - Violations. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. Each such person shall be guilty of a separate offense for each day during any portion of which any violation of any provision of this article is committed, continued or permitted by such person and shall be punished accordingly. Any operator or any other person who fails to register as required herein, or to furnish any return required to be made, or who fails or refuses to furnish a supplemental return or other data required by the city clerk or who renders a false or fraudulent return shall be deemed guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 1959, § 17-71; Code 1981, § 3-6011; Ord. No. 2014-5-1, § X, 5-27-14) 
Sec. 8-237. - Collection of tax. 
(a)  Action for tax. At any time within three years after any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected under this article becomes due and payable and at any time within three years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected, the city clerk may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the city to collect the amount delinquent together with interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(b)  Duty of successors or assignees of operator to withhold tax from purchase money. If any operator liable for any amount under this section sells or otherwise transfers his business, then the purchaser, or the seller's successors or assigns shall withhold a sufficient amount from the purchase price of the business to cover any deficient amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the city clerk showing that all taxes due under this article have been paid or a certificate from the city clerk stating that no amount is due. 
(c)  Liability for failure of purchaser to withhold. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold purchase price as required, he shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price. 
(d)  Overpayments. Whenever the amount of any tax or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the city under this section, it may be offset by the city clerk. If the operator or person determines that he has overpaid or paid more than once, which fact has not been determined by the city clerk, he shall have three years from date of payment to file claim in writing stating the specific ground upon which claim is founded. The claim shall be audited. If the claim is approved by the city clerk, the excess amount paid the city may be credited on any amounts then due and payable from the person by whom it was paid, or his administrators, executors, successors or assigns. 
(Ord. No. 06-11-6, § I, 11-20-06) 
Chapter 9 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1]
