ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 9-1—9-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 9-36. - Chief of fire department; police power. 
The chief of the fire department (also known as the fire chief) shall have authority to exercise police powers in the enforcement of any provision of this chapter or any other ordinance provision pertaining to the fire department, right-of-way, inspection of buildings and fire escapes, or other provisions or ordinances pertaining to fire protection. 
(Code 1959, § 14-1; Code 1981, § 4-2001) 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; buildings, ch. 5. 
Sec. 9-37. - Facilities and equipment, use in extinguishing fire authorized. 
In case of fire all firefighters on duty are authorized to use all available public or private facilities and equipment in extinguishing such fire. 
(Code 1959, § 14-2; Code 1981, § 4-2002) 
Sec. 9-38. - Interference with firefighters prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with a firefighter on duty in the firefighter's use of any public or private equipment being used by the firefighter in fighting and extinguishing a fire. 
(Code 1959, § 14-3; Code 1981, § 4-2003) 
Sec. 9-39. - Riding on fire vehicles restricted to firefighters. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, not a member of a fire company of the city, to ride upon any vehicle or apparatus going to or returning from a fire. 
(Code 1959, § 14-4; Code 1981, § 4-2004) 
Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 12. 
Sec. 9-40. - Maliciously injuring or obstructing firefighting apparatus. 
It shall be unlawful for any person willfully or knowingly to interfere or tamper with or to injure or damage in any way or by any means whatever any equipment or material or apparatus of any kind connected with or used by any fire company as a part of their machinery or material for extinguishing fires, or knowingly or willfully to put any obstruction in front of any fire station. 
(Code 1959, § 14-5; Code 1981, § 4-2005) 
Sec. 9-41. - Water being used in extinguishing fire; cutting off or order to cut off prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cut off or order the water cut off at any public or private water hydrant when the water is being used by the fire department in fighting and extinguishing a fire. 
(Code 1959, § 14-6; Code 1981, § 4-2006) 
Cross reference— Water supply and distribution, § 22-36 et seq. 
Sec. 9-42. - Obstructing fire hydrants. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the use of fire hydrants, or to obstruct approaches to same, by the fire department. 
(Code 1959, § 14-7; Ord. No. 90-4-3, § I(4-2007), 4-16-90; Code 1981, § 4-2007) 
Sec. 9-43. - Persons permitted within vicinity of fire. 
No person except firefighters, city commissioners and other city officers, the police force, the property owner and their agents and insurance agents, shall be allowed within the immediate vicinity of the fire, except by request of the fire chief or the officers in command of the fire department. 
(Code 1959, § 14-8; Code 1981, § 4-2008) 
State Law reference— Driving or parking vehicle near fire apparatus, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-247. 
Sec. 9-44. - Electricians; duty at fire or other emergency. 
It shall be the duty of the Georgia Power Company to have a competent electrician to turn off the electric current, or to take such other means as are necessary to protect the safety of firefighters and other citizens, at fires. Such electrician, immediately upon arrival at a fire, shall report to the command officer, and at the request of the command officer, disconnect wires, cut off electrical current or take such other action as may be necessary to safeguard firefighters and other citizens from electrical hazards. Upon failure of such company to have an electrician at each fire as required by this section the company shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 1959, § 14-9; Ord. No. 90-4-3, § I(4-2009), 4-16-90; Code 1981, § 4-2009) 
Cross reference— Electricity, § 5-111 et seq. 
Sec. 9-45. - Looters at fires. 
The fire chief, or the officer in command at the fire, shall cause to be arrested any person who shall be caught stealing goods or any article of value from any store, house or the vicinity thereof during a fire. 
(Code 1959, § 14-10; Code 1981, § 4-2010) 
Sec. 9-46. - Insurance reports of fire losses paid. 
All fire insurance companies or their authorized representatives operating within the county shall file with the chief of the fire department a report of all fire losses paid within 15 days after each claim is paid. 
(Code 1981, § 4-2011) 
Secs. 9-47—9-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LIFE SAFETY CODE 

Sec. 9-71. - Adoption. 
There is hereby adopted the current and latest edition of the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) Standard 101, Life Safety Code, published by the National Fire Protection Association, as promulgated into law with modifications by Chapter 120-3-3 of the Rules and Regulations of the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner (O.C.G.A. § 25-2-4). The Life Safety Code is adopted for the purpose of providing rules and regulations for the construction, erection, use, occupancy, and maintenance of buildings and structures within the city with minimum standards for safety to life from fire and other emergencies in the local public interest, welfare, and safety. 
(Code 1959, § 14-14.1; Ord. No. 82-6-2, § 1, 6-7-82; Ord. No. 85-11-2, § 2, 11-4-84; Ord. No. 89-6-5, § I(a), 6-19-89; Code 1981, § 4-2021(a); Ord. No. 99-2-1, § I, 2-1-99; Ord. No. 2011-2-2, § I, 2-7-11; Ord. No. 2018-10-1, § I, 10-22-18) 
Sec. 9-72. - Copy on file. 
At least one copy of the adopted Life Safety Code and any adopted amendments or additions thereto shall be on file in the offices of the building inspector, the fire chief, the fire marshal, and the city clerk at all times. 
(Code 1959, § 14-14.1; Ord. No. 82-6-2, § 1, 6-7-82; Ord. No. 85-11-2, § 2, 11-4-84; Ord. No. 89-6-5, § I(b), 6-19-89; Code 1981, § 4-2021(b); Ord. No. 2011-2-2, § II, 2-7-11) 
Sec. 9-73. - Amendments. 
None. 
(Code 1959, § 14-14.1; Ord. No. 82-6-2, § 1, 6-7-82; Ord. No. 85-11-2, § 2, 11-4-84; Ord. No. 89-6-5, § I(c), 6-19-89; Code 1981, § 4-2021(c); Ord. No. 99-2-1, § II, 2-1-99; Ord. No. 2011-2-2, § III, 2-7-11; Ord. No. 2018-10-1, § I, 10-22-18) 
Secs. 9-74—9-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 

Sec. 9-101. - General. 
This article shall be known as the Fire Prevention Code of the City of Rome, Georgia, and it may be cited as "The Fire Prevention Code." 
(Ord. No. 83-4-4, § 1, 4-4-83; Ord. No. 87-4-1, § 1(1), 4-6-87; Ord. No. 89-6-6, § (1)(1), (2), 6-19-89; Ord. No. 90-6-1, § 1(1)—(3), 6-19-90; Ord. No. 92-1-1A, § I(4-2031), 1-6-92; Code 1981, § 4-2031) 
Cross reference— Application of building and fire safety codes to existing buildings, § 16-86 et seq. 
Sec. 9-102. - Organization and administration. 
9.102.1 Purposes and intents; organization; division of fire prevention; administration. 
(a)  Purposes and intents. It is the primary purpose of this article to provide for the reasonable and realistic protection of life and property from the hazards created by fire out of control, smoke, explosion, or panic created from a fear of fire out of control, smoke, or explosion. It is the basic intent of this article to accomplish its primary purpose: 
(1)  Through education efforts and programs designed to change high-risk attitudes and behaviors that are the root causes of most fires out of control; 
(2)  Through consultations and informational programs, develop in the citizens of and visitors to the City of Rome and Floyd County, an awareness of the provisions of this article, and other applicable laws, codes, and standards, and aid them to determine the options available to correct hazards, problems, or violations identified; 
(3)  By providing through this article reasonable, realistic and practical safeguards against fire out of control and its related hazards; and 
(4)  As may be deemed necessary, initiate enforcement and legal proceedings as set forth in this article to gain compliance with the provisions of this article and the codes and standards adopted by this article. 
This article is hereby declared to be remedial and shall be construed to secure the beneficial interests and purposes thereof, which are public safety, health, and general welfare, through safety to life and property from fire out of control, explosion and other hazards incident to the use and occupancy of buildings, structures, facilities or premises located in the City of Rome. 
(b)  Organization and programs. There is hereby created the division of fire prevention within the Rome Fire Department for the purpose of implementing the provisions of this article. The division shall be under the direction and general supervision of the fire marshal. The fire marshal is the fire code official for the purposes of this article for the City of Rome. The fire marshal is responsible to the fire chief for the administration, implementation and enforcement of the provisions of this article and for the direction and supervision of the division. The division shall strive to improve the safety and lives and property from fire out of control and its associated hazards within the City of Rome through programs of safety education, through consultations, and through the inspection of buildings, structures, facilities and premises as often as deemed appropriate by the fire marshal and fire chief. As the fire chief and fire marshal deem appropriate, the division may develop and implement, in coordination and cooperation with other departments, agencies or organizations, public or private, a comprehensive program of community emergency education. 
(c)  Appointment of the fire marshal. The fire marshal shall be appointed by the fire chief on the basis of an evaluation of the applicant's qualifications. The appointment shall continue until the fire marshal vacates the position or is removed for cause in accordance with the applicable policies and regulations of the City of Rome and Rome Fire Department. 
(d)  Assistance to the fire marshal. The fire chief may detail or assign members of the Rome Fire Department to the division of fire prevention to assist the fire marshal. Such members shall be under the direction and supervision of the fire marshal during their detail or assignment to the division. The fire chief, upon request of the fire marshal, may fill positions deemed necessary for carrying out the purposes and programs of the division, in accordance with the personnel policies and regulations of the City of Rome. The selections shall be open to members and nonmembers of the Rome Fire Department. Employees assigned to fill positions with the division shall be under the direction and supervision of the fire marshal. 
(e)  Enforcement assistance. The chief of police, the city marshal, the building official or law enforcement officers of the City of Rome shall render assistance to the fire chief or the fire marshal upon request in the implementation and enforcement of this article. 
9.102.2 Applicability of this article and adopted codes and standards. 
(a)  Applicability. The provisions of this article, and the codes and standards adopted by this article, shall apply to all new and existing buildings, structures, premises, facilities and conditions within the City of Rome; provided, however, existing situations or conditions not in strict compliance with this article or the codes and standards adopted by this article, and not in contravention with state law, rules or regulations, may be continued unless they are deemed by the fire marshal to constitute a distinct hazard to life or to property from fire out of control, smoke or explosion. The provisions of this article shall not apply to the interior of one-family or two-family dwellings or to premises upon which such dwellings are located or to the interior of any apartment dwelling unit, provided such dwellings or apartments are used strictly for residential purposes. This article and the codes and standards adopted by this article shall apply to such dwelling units whenever an activity coming under this article is conducted therein and/or which creates a hazard from fire out of control, smoke or explosion to life or to property. 
(b)  Existing and special historic buildings. The provisions of this article shall apply to existing buildings or structures in the City of Rome as provided in this article; provided, however, the provisions of this article shall be coordinated by the fire marshal with the provisions of chapter 16, article IV, of the Code of the City of Rome, Georgia, "Application of Building and Fire Safety Codes to Existing Buildings." The provisions of this article shall apply to special buildings or structures identified by the state or the federal government or by the City of Rome as historic buildings; provided, however, the provisions of this article shall be coordinated by the fire marshal with the applicable provisions of state laws or regulations and with the provisions of chapter 23, article V, of the Code of the City of Rome, Georgia, "Historic Districts." 
(c)  Federal or state authority. The provisions of this article shall not be held to deprive any federal or state agency, or any applicable governing body having jurisdiction, of any power or authority which it had on the effective date of the adoption of this article or any remedy then existing for the enforcement of its orders, nor shall it deprive an individual or corporation of its legal rights as provided by law. 
9-102.3 Administrative and municipal liability. 
(a)  Administrative liability. Any officer or employee of the City of Rome empowered or authorized to administer or act under the provisions of this article or other applicable codes or standards in force in the City of Rome or required by the State of Georgia, and acting for the city or state in the discharge of his or her duties, shall not be held liable personally, and he or she is hereby relieved from all personal liability from any damages that may accrue to any person or property as a result of any act required, implied or permitted in the discharge of his or her duties, or as required, implied or permitted by this article or other applicable codes in force in the city or adopted or required by the State of Georgia, or as a result of the omission of any action required or authorized by this article or other applicable codes in force by the city or adopted or required by the State of Georgia. Any suit instituted against any officer or employee of the City of Rome in connection with the implementation of the provisions of this code or other applicable codes in force in the City of Rome or adopted or required by the State of Georgia shall be defended by the legal representative of the City of Rome until such matter is settled. 
(b)  Municipal liability. The City of Rome shall not be liable for any damage to persons or property from any act or any failure to act in connection with any provision of this article or other applicable law, regulation or codes in force in the city or adopted or required by the State of Georgia. 
(c)  Permitting and inspection. The inspection, approval or permitting of any building or plan by any employee of the division of fire prevention of the fire department of the City of Rome, under the requirements of this article, shall not be construed in any court as a warranty of the physical condition of such building or the adequacy of such plan. Neither the City of Rome nor any employee thereof shall be liable in tort for damages for any defect or hazardous or illegal condition or inadequacy in such building or plan, nor for any component of such building which may occur subsequent to such inspection, approval or permitting. 
9-102.4 Conducting inspections; right of entry; related provisions. 
(a)  Inspections. The fire marshal is authorized to inspect, or cause to be inspected, as he or she deems appropriate or necessary based on fire experience in the City, on complaint, or on other applicable grounds, and as resources permit, buildings, structures, premises and facilities coming within the scope of this article. The purpose of such inspections is to ascertain if any conditions exist which could be reasonably construed to cause a fire out of control or explosion, or that could contribute to the spread of a fire out of control or its byproducts, or to ascertain any significant nonconformance with the purposes, intents and other provisions of this article or any other applicable law, rule or regulation affecting safety to life and/or property from fire out of control, explosion or the hazards related to same. The fire marshal is authorized to apply other applicable laws and to cause to be corrected any conditions which could be reasonably construed to cause a fire out of control or explosion or that could contribute to the spread of a fire out of control, or any significant nonconformance with the purposes, intents or provisions of this article affecting safety to life and/or property from fire out of control, explosion or the hazards related to same. 
(b)  Right of entry to conduct inspections. The fire marshal or his or her authorized representatives may, to the extent permitted by law, have free access to and the right to enter at all reasonable times any building, structure, facility or premises, except single-family or two-family dwellings, located within the City of Rome, whether completed or under construction, for the purpose of conducting inspections and otherwise implementing the provisions of this article. Before entering any building, structure, facility or premises not normally open to the public, except when a fire out of control or other emergency condition exists or has occurred, the fire marshal or his representatives shall obtain the consent of the occupant, owner or person in charge at the time. Where consent to enter is refused, the fire marshal may seek an order or an administrative search warrant from the Municipal Court of the City of Rome, or if deemed appropriate, from the Superior Court of Floyd County, authorizing his or her entry or that of his or her representatives for the purpose of conducting the inspection or investigation. The term "emergency condition," for the purposes of this section, shall mean any condition or circumstance which the fire marshal or the fire chief determines to constitute an immediate threat or danger to the occupants of the building, structure, facilities or premises or to persons or property exposed to a fire out of control, the hazards associated with fire out of control, explosion, the threat of fire or explosion, or exposed to risks from some other hazardous condition or circumstances. 
(c)  Implied consent. Any application for, or the acceptance of, any approval, permit, license or certificate requested or required pursuant to this article, any applicable code or other applicable law or ordinance of the City of Rome or the state, constitutes agreement and consent by the person making the application, or accepting the approval, permit, license or certificate to allow the fire marshal or his or her representatives to enter the building, structure, facility or premises at any reasonable time to conduct inspections as may be deemed appropriate by the fire marshal or as otherwise provided by this article or other applicable state law or ordinance, or rules or regulations. 
9-102.5 Notice of, or order to, eliminate dangerous or unlawful conditions. 
(a)  Notice of violations. Whenever the fire marshal or his or her designated representatives find any violations of this article, applicable adopted codes, or standards, or any fire hazards, as defined herein, they are authorized to issue or serve a written notice of the findings of an inspection as set forth in section 9-102.4 and to notify the building official. For the purposes of this article, a fire hazard means any thing or act which increases or may cause an increase of the hazard or menace of fire out of control to a greater degree than that customarily recognized as normal by persons in the public service regularly engaged in preventing fires out of control; or which may obstruct, delay, hinder or interfere with the operations of the Rome Fire Department or the egress of occupants in the event of fire out of control or other emergency condition, actual or perceived. 
(b)  Abatement order—Written. Whenever the fire marshal or his or her designated representatives find any violations of this article or any fire hazards, which are deemed to create a serious or significant potential for fire out of control or explosion or which are deemed to create a serious or significant potential threat to life in event of fire out of control or explosion, they are authorized to issue a written order to correct or abate the violations or hazards. Such order when issued shall set forth a reasonable and realistic time frame or date limit for correction, abatement or compliance. The time frame for correction, abatement or compliance established by or as directed by the fire marshal or his or her designated representative may be reasonably correlated by him or her or them to the seriousness or relative degree of hazard, and/or to the complexity of the means of correction or abatement. 
(c)  Abatement order—Verbal. Where deemed necessary, due to the potential risk to life or property, the fire marshal or his or her representative may issue a verbal order for the immediate correction or abatement of a violation or fire hazard. This may be followed by a written order of notice or action. 
(d)  Summary abatement. The fire marshal or the fire chief shall have the authority to summarily abate any violation of this article or any fire hazard, which constitutes an immediate or imminent danger or threat to life in their judgment, and where the following of the provisions for obtaining corrective action or abatement as set forth elsewhere in this article is not practical in their judgment. 
(e)  Unsafe buildings or structures. Any building or structure which is deemed to be structurally unsafe or which is not provided with adequate means of egress, or which is deemed to constitute a serious fire hazard, or which is otherwise deemed dangerous to human life, or which in relation to existing use constitutes a hazard to the safety, health or welfare to the public by reason of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, obsolescence, fire damage, disaster damage, vandalism, flood damage or abandonment, as specified in this article or by any other applicable codes or ordinances in force in the City of Rome, is deemed to be an unsafe building or structure. 
9-102.6 Serving notices or orders. 
(a)  Generally. The service of notices or orders issued in connection with [subsections] 9-102.5(a) and 9-102.5(b) of this article may be made by the fire marshal or his or her representatives upon the owner, occupant or person in charge of the building, structure, facility, premises or portion thereof where the hazards or violations were found, or by delivering a copy of the notice or order to any or all of the persons noted. If such person(s) cannot be served by delivery as noted, service may be accomplished by affixing a copy of the notice or order in a conspicuous place at or near the entrance of the building, structure, facility or premises, or by delivering or sending a copy of the notice or order to the known agent of the owner or occupant, or in the event of an absentee owner with no known agent, by sending a copy by certified or registered mail to the owner's last known residence, business or post office address. 
(b)  To occupants of certain premises. If the building, structure, facility or premises is owned by one or more persons and is occupied by one or more other persons under lease or otherwise, the notice or order issued in connection with this section shall apply to the occupants thereof, except where the notice or order requires the addition to or changes in the building, structure or premises such as would immediately become real estate and become the property of the owners and not the occupants unless it is otherwise agreed between or among the owners and the occupants. 
9-102.7 Penalty provisions. 
(a)  General penalty; separate violations. Any person who shall fail to comply with an order of correction or abatement as set forth in this section, or who shall build or act in violation of this article or of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved under authority of this article in connection with any approval, certificate, or permit issued thereunder, or who shall perform any act deemed to create a serious potential for fire out of control, or explosion and for which the issuance of an order to correct or abate is not adequate, and who is found guilty shall be guilty of a violation of this article. A person found guilty under this section shall, for each violation and noncompliance, respectively, be subject to punishment by a fine of not less than $100.00, nor more than $5,000.00, or by imprisonment for a period of not more than 120 days or by both such fine and imprisonment. The imposition of a penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue, and the responsible persons shall correct or abate such violation within a time limit as ordered by the court. When not otherwise specified, each five days a prohibited condition or violation continues following an order of the court to correct or abate the same shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Procedures upon determination of violation—Generally. When the fire marshal, the fire chief or their authorized representatives determine that violations of this Code warrant the filing of charges or action of the court as provided for in [subsection] 9-102.7(a), the issuing of a citation of charges and/or summons to appear before the Municipal Court of the City of Rome shall be served by the city marshal or his authorized representative or by any certified law enforcement officer of the City of Rome upon request of the fire marshal, the fire chief or their authorized representative. 
(c)  Same—Injunctive relief. In addition to the filing of charges as specified in [subsections] 9-102.7(a) and 9-102.7(b), or as a separate remedy at law, the fire marshal or the fire chief may seek injunctive relief for any fire hazard, violation, or condition that threatens the safety of life or property based on the provisions of this code or any applicable code or ordinance of the City of Rome or of the State of Georgia. 
(d)  Removal of prohibited conditions. The application of penalties by the court as provided for in [section] 9-102.7 shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions or violations. 
9-102.8 Removal of notices or order; illegal use of buildings. 
(a)  Removal, generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any notice or order issued in connection with this article and affixed to a building, structure, facility or premises, without the approval of the fire marshal or his or her authorized representative. 
(b)  Unlawful use of building or facility. It shall be unlawful for any person to use a building, structure, facility or premises in violation of the provisions of this article where an order has been affixed to same prohibiting the use of same under authority of any provisions of this article without the approval of the fire marshal or his or her authorized representative or the court. 
(c)  Change of occupancy or use of building. When it is determined that the occupancy or use of a building has changed from that shown on the certificate of occupancy issued by the building official, the fire marshal, or the state fire marshal, the fire marshal may issue such notice or orders as necessary and in conformance with this article to remove or remedy any noted violations or hazards, and he or she shall refer the building to the building official, or as appropriate, the state fire marshal, for any repairs, alterations, remodeling, removing or demolition required. 
9-102.9 Coordination with and application of related codes and standards. 
(a)  Changes in existing buildings or facilities. Any alterations, additions or changes required in existing buildings, structures, facilities or premises because of a change in use, occupancy, exit design or other reason shall be made in compliance with the codes and standards adopted under this article and as set for in section 9-103 of this article. 
(b)  Review of plans coordinated. The fire marshal and the building official shall coordinate their review of plans on new construction and/or renovations or alterations of existing buildings or structures so as to ascertain compliance with this article and the codes and standards adopted by this article under their respective jurisdictions. The building official, pursuant to state, shall not issue any building permit on buildings under the jurisdiction of the state fire marshal (O.C.G.A. §§ 25-2-13 and 25-2-14), until the required state construction permit is issued by the state fire marshal. 
(c)  New construction. The fire marshal and the building official shall have the authority to jointly consider and approve a modification of any of the applicable codes for new construction with regard to matters relating to fire protection and safety to life in the event of fire out of control or related emergencies where the proposed designed, fire protection system, building use, or construction method involved is unusual or where it involves an unusual hazard, condition, or hardship, and the provisions of the codes and standards in force do not clearly or adequately deal with the proposed design, protection system application or design, building use, or construction method, in their judgment. Such approvals shall not result in a condition(s) that is/are less protective than any code or standard adopted by the state. 
(d)  Alternate materials. It is the intent of this provision to allow the use of designs, systems, methods, or devices of equivalent or superior quality, strength, fire resistance, effectiveness, durability, and safety to those prescribed by the applicable codes and standards, provided that technical documentation, data, or other information or material acceptable to the fire marshal and building official is submitted for review and such demonstrates to their satisfaction the equivalency of the design, system, method, or device for the intended use. Any modification or alternate safeguard jointly approved by the fire marshal and the building official shall not afford a condition less safe to life, and where appropriate, property, than in their judgment would be provided with compliance with the provisions of applicable codes or standards. 
9-102.10 Modifications and appeals. 
(a)  Existing conditions. The fire marshal shall have the authority to modify any of the provisions of the adopted codes or standards adopted by reference by this article, except regarding buildings under the jurisdiction of O.C.G.A. § 25-2-13, upon application in writing by the owners and/or occupants of an existing building, structure, facility or premises, or by their authorized agents, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of this code or the codes or standards adopted by reference by this article or the City of Rome. Such modification may be granted by the fire marshal, provided that in his judgment, the spirit, intents and purposes of this article are observed, the public safety shall be reasonably and practically secured, the modification is in the interest of the community and substantial justice will be done. The particulars of any modification granted or allowed, and the decision of the fire marshal thereon, shall be entered upon the records of the division. 
(b)  Right to appeal. Whenever the fire marshal or the fire chief shall issue an order pursuant to this article, disapprove an application, refuse to grant a permit, refuse to grant a waiver or modification, or when it is claimed that the provisions of this article or the codes and standards adopted by reference by this article or the City of Rome do not apply or that the true intent and meaning of same have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted, the applicant or aggrieved person may appeal from the order or decision of the fire marshal or the fire chief to the board of adjustments as established by the adopted building code of the City of Rome within 30 days after the decision is rendered by the fire marshal or the fire chief. The provisions of the applicable building code relative to time limits, variations and modifications, and decisions as connected with the appeals to the board of adjustments shall be applicable to appeals from the fire marshal or the fire chief relating to this article. If the applicant or aggrieved person is not satisfied with the decision of the board of adjustments, appeal may be made to the court of appropriate jurisdiction. Every decision of the board of adjustments relative to this article shall be filed in the office of the fire marshal. 
9-102.11 General provisions. 
(a)  Interference with fire officials. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, abuse, or obstruct in any way the fire chief, the fire marshal or their representatives in carrying out any actions in accordance with their official duties as set forth by this article, or by any other applicable local ordinance, or by any law or regulation of the State of Georgia. 
(b)  Unlawful use of credentials; unlawful impersonation of fire official. It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to use an official or unofficial badge or credential so as to impersonate an authorized fire official or to otherwise impersonate a fire official. 
(c)  Authority to investigate fires, explosions, false alarms or related incidents. The fire chief, the fire marshal or his authorized representatives are authorized to investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of any fire or explosion, or to investigate any incident resulting from the sending or sounding of a false alarm of fire or a bomb threat. When, in the judgment of the fire marshal, reasonable cause exists that a fire or explosion may have been of criminal origin, the fire marshal or his or her authorized representative is authorized to locate and take custody of any and all physical evidence relating to the cause of the fire or explosion and to continue the investigation to the extent deemed appropriate within the limits of division resources and within the limits of applicable state laws. The fire marshal shall inform the Rome Police Department of each fire of criminal or suspected criminal origin, false alarms or bomb threats. The fire marshal shall also assist the Rome Police Department in its investigations of reported incidents, if so requested by that department. The Rome Police Department shall be responsible for the investigation of fires and/or explosions of criminal or suspected criminal origin, false alarms or bomb threats so as to identify, apprehend and assist in the prosecution of the persons responsible for such criminal acts. 
(d)  Evacuation of buildings, structures, facilities or premises. When, in the judgment of the fire chief, the fire marshal, or their authorized representatives in their absence, there is an actual or serious potential danger to the occupants of or persons in close proximity to any building, structure, facility or premises because of unsafe structural conditions, or the presence of explosives, explosive fumes or vapor, toxic fumes, gases or materials, the fire chief, the fire marshal, or their authorized representatives in their absence, may order the complete or partial immediate evacuation of any building, structure, facility or premises and, as necessary, areas in such proximity to these as to be endangered. All persons under order to evacuate shall promptly leave the evacuation area and shall not reenter until authorized to do so by the official who issued the evacuation order. This section shall not pertain to bomb threats where no bomb or explosive device is known to exist. In such bomb threat situations, the decision to evacuate or not to evacuate is the responsibility of the person in charge of the building, structure, facility or premises at that time. 
(e)  Permits and approvals. A person shall not maintain, store or handle materials, or conduct processes which produce conditions hazardous to life or property, or install equipment used in connection with such activities without first obtaining approval, or as appropriate based on the provisions of section 9-102.11 of this article, a permit from the fire marshal. Where conditions or activities are also regulated by a state or federal agency and a permit, license or certificate is required by the regulating agency, then no local permit is required; provided, however, the approval of the fire marshal is required and he shall have the authority to apply the provisions of this article where a hazardous condition is discovered. 
(f)  Tests. All equipment required by this article or other applicable codes adopted by the City of Rome or by the State of Georgia shall be maintained in a safe, sound, and operational condition. The fire marshal may require tests or test reports as proof of compliance. Required tests and reports are to be made at the expense of the owner or his agent by an approved testing laboratory or other approval agency or firm acceptable to the fire marshal. 
(g)  Authority to expose or stop work. Whenever any construction or installation coming under this article is subject to inspection prior to use and is covered or concealed without having first been inspected, the fire marshal may require by verbal and/or written order that such work be exposed for inspection. The fire marshal shall be notified when the installation is ready for inspection within a reasonable period of time. When any construction or installation work is being performed in violation of the plans, specifications or understandings as approved by the fire marshal, a written order may be issued to the responsible person to stop work on that portion of the work which is in violation. The order shall state the nature of the violation. No work shall be continued on that portion until the violation has been corrected and the order is lifted by the fire marshal or his or her designated representative. 
(h)  Effect of court decision. If, for any reason, any provision, section, subsection, clause or phrase of this article, or any code or standard adopted by reference by this article, is held to be invalid or unconstitutional by a decision of a court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining provisions of this article, or of any code or standard adopted by reference by this article. 
9-102.12 Approvals and fire regulatory permits; related provisions. 
(a)  Generally. A person shall not maintain, store or handle materials, or conduct processes, which produce conditions hazardous to life or property, or install equipment used in connection with such activities, without first obtaining approval, or as appropriate a fire regulatory permit, from the fire marshal as provided by various provisions of this article. Where conditions or activities are also regulated by a state or federal agency and a permit, license or certificate is required by the regulating agency, then no local fire regulatory permit is required; provided, however, the approval of the fire marshal is required and he shall have the authority to apply the provisions of this code where a hazardous condition is discovered. 
(b)  New activities. Any person desiring to conduct or engage in any new process or activity requiring a fire regulatory permit under this article shall apply for a permit as set forth in this section and shall be issued such permit prior to engaging in the conducting of the process or activity, or before occupying a building or structure requiring a permit. 
(c)  Existing activities. Persons known to be conducting processes or activities required to be permitted under this article on or before January 1, 2009, shall be advised that a permit is required. Such persons may also be advised of any violations noted under this article that must be corrected before a permit can be issued. The fire marshal shall exercise reasonableness and shall apply the applicable provisions of subsections 9-102.2(a), 9-102.2(b), 9-102.9(a) and 9-102.10(a) when applying the provisions of this article or any of the technical codes or standards adopted by reference under this article or otherwise adopted by the Rome City Commission, when such are being applied to existing conditions or activities. No existing process or activity requiring a permit under this article and found to be in significant noncompliance with the applicable provisions of this article shall be authorized to continue for a period of one year from the date the person is notified of the permit requirement. Where there is noncompliance, the fire marshal may issue a temporary permit with an established expiration date. A temporary permit issued in connection with this subsection may be extended, provided a plan of corrective action has been submitted prior to the expiration of the permit, evidence clearly indicates that compliance is being obtained, and there are practical difficulties in completing the corrective action by the expiration date. 
(d)  Permit—Effect. A fire regulatory permit shall constitute permission to maintain, store or handle materials, or to conduct processes which may produce conditions hazardous to life or property, or to install equipment used in connection with such activities. A permit shall not be a substitute for any license or certificate required by law. A permit issued shall be construed to be a license to proceed with work and shall not be construed as authority to violate, cancel, alter or set aside any of the provisions of this article or any code or standard adopted by reference under this article. The issuance of a permit shall not be construed as preventing the fire marshal from thereafter requiring correction of errors in plans or in construction, or of violations of this Code. 
(e)  Permit—Transfer duration. A fire regulatory permit shall not be transferable, and any change in use or occupancy of a building or premises shall require a new permit. A fire regulatory permit shall continue until revoked or for such a period of time as is designated at the time of issuance. 
(f)  Application for permit. An application for a permit shall be made to the fire marshal on a form available at the division of fire prevention. The form shall be fully completed. The application shall be accompanied by such data as may be required by the fire marshal and by the required fee, as set forth in [subsection] 9-102.12(h) of this article. 
(g)  Agreement to comply; responsibility. The filing of an application for a permit or a request for an approval from the fire marshal under this article constitutes an agreement on the part of the persons the applicant represents to comply with the provisions of this article and of the technical codes and standards adopted by reference under this article otherwise adopted by the Rome City Commission. Such filing shall also constitute an understanding on the part of the permittee that the permittee, not the City of Rome, the fire marshal or the fire chief, shall bear the full responsibility for any damages to persons and/or property in connection with any fire, explosion or other accident or event involving any process, material, installation or activity covered by a permit or approval issued in connection with any of the provisions of this article. 
(h)  Processing fee. There shall be a processing fee of $50.00 for the issuance of a fire regulatory permit. The fee shall accompany the permit application when it is filed. If an inspection conducted to determine compliance with this article reveals that a condition exists which would preclude the issuance of a permit, the processing fee shall not be refunded. Further, where a permit is denied due to violations and hazards noted, the activity for which the permit is required shall not be deemed in compliance. The fire marshal may require the filing of a new application and fee if he deems the original application and fee to have been filed prematurely or filed with false or incomplete information. Such fee shall not be 
required of government, charitable or religious organizations. The fire marshal shall be responsible for maintaining records of and permits issued and fees collected. The disposition funds collected shall be in compliance with the applicable policies and procedures of the City of Rome. 
(i)  Review of applications; issuance. The fire marshal or his authorized representatives shall review applications submitted and issue approvals or permits as required, provided, however, that the data on the application and plans and specifications submitted therewith, indicate to a reasonable degree, compliance with the provisions of this article and the technical codes and standards adopted by reference under this article or otherwise adopted by the Rome City Commission. Permits for activities requiring evidence of financial responsibility on the part of the permittee as required by this article, and/or state law, shall not be issued unless proof of required financial responsibility is furnished. 
(j)  Rejected. If an application for a permit or approval is rejected by the fire marshal or his authorized representative, the applicant shall be advised of the reasons for such rejection. The permittee shall have the right of appeal as set forth in subsection 9-102.10(b). 
(k)  Display of permits. A copy of the fire regulatory permits issued and any exceptions granted shall be maintained in the division of fire prevention. Such record shall be available for public inspection during normal business hours upon request to the fire marshal or his or her designated representative. 
(l)  Records. A record of fire regulatory permits issued and any exceptions granted shall be maintained in the division of fire prevention. Such record shall be available for public inspection during normal business hours upon request to the fire marshal or his or her designated representative. 
(m)  Duration of permits; limitations on issuance. A fire regulatory permit issued under this article shall continue until revoked or for the period of time designated therein at the time of issuance of the permit. The permit shall be issued to one person only and for the location or purpose described in the permit. Any change which affects any of the conditions of the permit shall require a new permit. The fire marshal may grant an extension of the permit period where an expiration date has been established upon presentation by the permittee of a satisfactory reason for failure to start or complete the work or activity authorized by the permit by the designated expiration date. A permit issued shall become invalid unless the use authorized by such is commenced within six months after issuance, or if the use authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned for a period of six months after the time the use of the permit is commenced. One or more extensions of time, for periods not to exceed 90 days each, may be allowed for the permit provided the extension is requested in writing and justifiable cause is demonstrated. Extensions granted by the fire marshal shall be in writing. 
(n)  Temporary permit. When a potentially hazardous situation or activity of a temporary nature is encountered, and such is not specifically regulated by this article, a permit may be required by and issued by the fire marshal to cover the duration of the situation or activity. He shall require the filing of an application and fee as set forth for a regular fire regulatory permit. 
(o)  Consolidated permit. Only one permit shall be required for each location of a firm which may be required to obtain more than one permit under the permit requirements of this chapter. Such consolidated permit shall list all of the materials or activities covered by the permit. Revocation of any of the permitted materials or activities covered by the consolidated permit shall require the revocation of the permit and issuance of a new permit. In such situation, a new and revised permit may be issued by the fire marshal for the materials or activities not covered by the revocation. No new application is required; however, a new fee is required for the revised consolidated permit. 
(p)  Revocation of permits. The fire marshal may revoke his approval or a permit, issued under the provisions of this article when it is determined there has been any false statement or misrepresentation as to the material facts in the application or in the plans on which the approval or permit was based. The fire marshal may revoke his approval or a permit upon determination by him that the occupancy, operation, material, or activity for which the approval or permit was issued is in violation of, or is not in conformity with, the provisions of this article or with other applicable codes or technical standards adopted by the City of Rome or with applicable laws, rules or regulations of the State of Georgia. Where a state or federal agency also has jurisdiction, the fire marshal may notify the responsible agency of any noted violation, nonconformance or condition deemed to be hazardous. 
(q)  Fire regulatory permit and fire department services fee. The fire chief, fire marshal or their authorized representatives shall enforce the provisions of the fire regulatory permit and fire department services fees. These fees are located in the Fee Schedule Book of the City of Rome as authorized by City of Rome Code Section 8-36. 
For purposes of this Code, the word "permit" as used in the International Fire Code (IFC), shall be construed as being a "Fire Regulatory Permit" as required under section 9-102.12 of the Rome Fire Prevention Code. The fire regulatory permit fees shall be separate from the application process fee required by [subsection] 9-102.12(h). The permit application and issuance process established by [section] 9-102.12 shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2-3, § I, 2-7-11; Ord. No. 2011-4-5, § I, 4-4-11)

Sec. 9-103. - International Fire Code and referenced codes and standards adopted as amended by the state; incorporated by reference; purposes and intents; local amendments. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted, for the local purposes of the public safety and welfare, that certain fire prevent code known as the International Fire Code, particularly the edition adopted with amendments or modifications by Chapter 120-3-3 of the Rules and Regulations of the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner (O.C.G.A. § 25-2-4), except such portions as are deleted, modified, amended or added in this article. Such code, including the additions, modifications or amendments, as well as technical codes and standards referenced by the International Fire Code or the Rules and Regulations of the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner, is hereby incorporated by reference and made part of this article as if fully set forth in this section. Copies of the specifications, rules and regulations shall be kept on file for public inspection in the offices of the fire chief, the fire marshal, and the building official. 
(b)  Section 9-102 of Article IV, Fire Prevention Code, shall regulate the administration, application implementation, interpretation, and enforcement of the International Fire Code and the technical codes and standards adopted by reference under section 9-103(a). 
(c)  Purposes and intents. It is the primary purpose of this article to adopt and enforce the state minimum fire safety standards by transferring the authority from the State of Georgia and the responsibilities of the office of the insurance and safety fire commissioner to the City of Rome pursuant to O.C.G.A § 25-2-12(b), including all subsequent revisions thereof. 
(1)  Enforcement. The City of Rome will enforce the state minimum fire safety standards as set forth in O.C.G.A § 25-2-12 (a) with respect to those buildings and structures listed in O.C.G.A § 25-2-13, except for hospitals, nursing homes, jails, ambulatory health care centers, and penal institutions and except for buildings and structures which are owned and operated or occupied by the state. 
(2)  Duties of safety fire division. The safety fire division of the office of the insurance and safety fire commissioner shall continue to perform those duties specified in O.C.G.A § 25-1-12 (a)(2) with respect to hospitals, nursing homes, jails, ambulatory health care centers, and penal institutions and except for buildings and structures which are owned and operated or occupied by the state. 
(3)  Responsibilities and duties of the City of Rome. The City of Rome will be responsible for enforcing such fire safety standards within its jurisdiction and will: 
a.  Conduct fire safety inspections on existing buildings and structures. 
b.  Review plans and specifications for proposed buildings and structures, issue building permits when plans are approved, and conduct fire safety inspections of such buildings and structures. 
c.  Issue permanent and temporary certificates of occupancy. 
d.  Conduct arson investigations. 
(4)  Fees. The City of Rome will charge and retain appropriate fees for performing the duties required in O.C.G.A § 25-2-12(2)(A), (B). 
(d)  The following deletions, modifications, amendments, and additions are hereby made to the adopted International Fire Code. 
(1)  Chapter 1 of the adopted International Fire Code for local purposes regarding the local administration, application, implementation, interpretation, and enforcement is hereby deleted and is replaced by Section 9-102 of Article IV, Fire Prevention Code, of the Code of the City of Rome, Georgia. Nothing herein shall be construed as deleting modifications to said Chapter 1 of the Rules and Regulations of the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner or the Georgia Department of Community Affairs that are applicable to administrative, implementation and enforcement provisions as they apply to the state fire marshal's office or buildings, structures, facilities, premises, or hazardous materials coming under the jurisdiction of the state fire marshal as set forth by O.C.G.A. Chapter 25, Title 2. 
(2)  Chapter 2 of the adopted International Fire Code is hereby modified by including the following local definitions of the City of Rome with those in Section 202, General Definitions: 
Alter : any change or modification in the construction, occupancy or use of any building, structure, facility or premises. 
Approved : acceptable to the fire marshal, or, as appropriate, the fire chief, of the City of Rome. In determining acceptability of installations, equipment, materials or procedures, the fire marshal, or as appropriate, the fire chief, may base acceptance on compliance with nationally recognized standards. The fire marshal, or, as appropriate, the fire chief, may require evidence of proper installation, proper use, or use of proper procedures. The fire marshal, or, as appropriate, the fire chief, may also refer to listings or labeling practices of recognized testing laboratories, inspection agencies or other recognized organizations concerned with product evaluations and which are in a position to determine compliance with appropriate standards for the current production of listed items and the satisfactory performance of such equipment or materials in actual usage. 
Building code : the building code adopted in Chapter 5, Article III, of the Code of the City of Rome, Georgia. 
Building official : the building inspector of the City of Rome, Georgia. 
Chief of police : the Chief of the Police Department of Rome, Georgia. 
Chief of the division of fire prevention : the fire marshal of the division of fire prevention of the Fire Department of Rome, Georgia. 
Chief of the fire department/fire chief : the Fire Chief of the Fire Department of Rome, Georgia. 
Combustible : capable of undergoing combustion. 
Electrical code : the electrical code adopted in Chapter 5, Article IV, of the Code of the City of Rome, Georgia. 
Gas code : the gas code adopted in Chapter 5, Article V, of the Code of the City of Rome, Georgia. 
Mechanical code : the mechanical code adopted by Chapter 5, Article VII, of the Code of the City of Rome, Georgia. 
The division : the division of fire prevention and community emergency education within the Rome Fire Department. 
Zoning code : the zoning code in Chapter 23 of the Code of the City of Rome, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2-3, § II, 2-7-11; Ord. No. 2018-10-2, § I, 10-22-18) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2018-10-2, § I, adopted Oct. 22, 2018, amended § 9-103 and in so doing changed the title, as set out herein. 
Chapter 10 - FLOOD DAMAGE PREVENTION 

Sec. 10-1. - Statutory authorization, findings of fact, purpose and objectives 
(a)  Authorization. Article IX, Section II of the Constitution of the State of Georgia and O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20(a) have delegated the responsibility to local government units to adopt regulations designed to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare of its citizenry. 
(b)  Findings of fact. 
(1)  The flood hazard areas of the City of Rome, Georgia are subject to periodic inundation which results in loss of life and property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures for flood relief and protection, and impairment of the tax base, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(2)  These flood losses are caused by the occupancy in flood hazard areas of uses vulnerable to floods, which are inadequately elevated, flood-proofed, or otherwise unprotected from flood damages, and by the cumulative effect of obstructions in floodplains causing increases in flood heights and velocities. 
(c)  Statement of purpose. It is the purpose of this chapter to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare and to minimize public and private losses due to flood conditions in specific areas by provisions designed to: 
(1)  Require that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities which serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial construction; 
(2)  Restrict or prohibit uses which are dangerous to health, safety and property due to water or erosion hazards, or which increase flood heights, velocities, or erosion; 
(3)  Control filling, grading, dredging and other development which may increase flood damage or erosion; 
(4)  Prevent or regulate the construction of flood barriers which will unnaturally divert floodwaters or which may increase flood hazards to other lands; 
(5)  Control the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels, and natural protective barriers, which are involved in the accommodation of floodwaters. 
(d)  Objectives. The objectives of this chapter are: 
(1)  To protect human life and health; 
(2)  To minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and gas mains, electric, telephone and sewer lines, streets and bridges located in floodplains; 
(3)  To help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and development of flood prone areas in such a manner as to minimize flood blight areas; 
(4)  To minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control projects; 
(5)  To minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding and generally undertaken at the expense of the general public; 
(6)  To minimize prolonged business interruptions, and; 
(7)  To insure that potential homebuyers are notified that property is in a flood area. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10-2, § I, 10-5-09) 
Sec. 10-2. - General provisions. 
(a)  Lands to which this chapter applies. This chapter shall apply to all areas of special flood hazard within the jurisdiction of the City of Rome, Georgia. 
(b)  Basis for area of special flood hazard. The areas of special flood hazard identified by the Federal Emergency Management Agency in its flood insurance study (FIS), dated September 25, 2009, with accompanying maps and other supporting data and any revision thereto, are adopted by reference and declared a part of this chapter. 
For those land areas acquired by a municipality through annexation, the current effective FIS dated September 25, 2009, with accompanying maps and other supporting data and any revision thereto, for Floyd County Georgia are hereby adopted by reference. 
Areas of special flood hazard may also include those areas known to have flooded historically or defined through standard engineering analysis by governmental agencies or private parties but not yet incorporated in a FIS. 
The repository for public inspection of the FIS, accompanying maps and other supporting data is located: 
Rome/Floyd County Inspection Department  Environmental Compliance Section  607 Broad Street, Room 211  Rome, Georgia 30162 
(c)  Establishment of flood area permit. If development or construction is proposed within or affecting a special flood hazard area (SFHA), approval of a flood area permit application shall be required. An application for a flood area permit may be included with and reviewed as part of a land development permit application. 
(d)  Compliance. No structure or land shall hereafter be located, extended, converted or altered without full compliance with the terms of this chapter and other applicable regulations. 
(e)  Abrogation and greater restrictions. This chapter is not intended to repeal, abrogate, or impair any existing ordinance, easements, covenants, or deed restrictions. However, where this chapter and another conflict or overlap, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. Upon adoption this ordinance shall replace Article 6.14 Flood Damage Prevention of the "Unified Land Development Code of Floyd County and the City of Rome, Georgia". 
(f)  Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of this chapter all provisions shall be: 
(1)  Considered as minimum requirements; 
(2)  Liberally construed in favor of the governing body; and 
(3)  Deemed neither to limit nor repeal any other powers granted under state statutes. 
(g)  Warning and disclaimer of liability. The degree of flood protection required by this chapter is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on scientific and engineering considerations. Larger floods can and will occur; flood heights may be increased by manmade or natural causes. This chapter does not imply that land outside the areas of special flood hazard or uses permitted within such areas will be free from flooding or flood damages. This chapter shall not create liability on the part of Floyd County and/or by any officer or employee thereof for any flood damages that result from reliance on this chapter or any administrative decision lawfully made hereunder. 
(h)  Penalties for violation. Failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter or with any of its requirements, including conditions and safeguards established in connection with grants of variance or special exceptions shall constitute a violation. Any person who violates this chapter or fails to comply with any of its requirements shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than $1,000.00 or imprisoned for not more than six months, or both, or be sentenced to community service and in addition, shall pay all costs and expenses involved in the case. Each day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. Nothing herein contained shall prevent the City of Rome from taking such other lawful actions as is necessary to prevent or remedy any violation. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10-2, § I, 10-5-09) 
Sec. 10-3. - Administration. 
(a)  Designation of ordinance administrator. The chief building official is hereby appointed to administer and implement the provisions of this chapter. In accordance with the prescribed procedures of the jurisdiction, the chief building official may designate a technical official to administer the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Permit procedures. Application for a floodplain development permit shall be made to the chief building official or designee on forms furnished by the community prior to any development activities, and may include, but not be limited to the following: plans in duplicate drawn to scale showing the elevations of the area in question and the nature, location, and dimensions of existing or proposed structures, earthen fill placement, storage of materials or equipment, and drainage facilities. 
Specifically, the following information is required: 
(1)  Application stage. 
a.  Elevation in relation to mean sea level (or highest adjacent grade) of the lowest floor, including basement, of all proposed structures; 
b.  Elevation in relation to mean sea level to which any nonresidential structure will be flood-proofed; 
c.  Design certification from a registered professional engineer or architect that any proposed nonresidential flood-proofed structure will meet the flood-proofing criteria of subsection 10-4(b)(2); and 
d.  Description of the extent to which any watercourse will be altered or relocated as a result of a proposed development. 
(2)  Construction stage. For all new construction and substantial improvements, the permit holder shall provide to the administrator an as-built certification of the regulatory floor elevation or flood-proofing level immediately after the lowest floor or flood proofing is completed. Any lowest floor certification made relative to mean sea level shall be prepared by or under the direct supervision of a registered land surveyor or professional engineer and certified by same. When flood proofing is utilized for nonresidential structures, said certification shall be prepared by or under the direct supervision of a professional engineer or architect and certified by same. 
Any work undertaken prior to submission of these certifications shall be at the permit holder's risk. 
The chief building official or designee shall review the above-referenced certification data submitted. Deficiencies detected by such review shall be corrected by the permit holder immediately and prior to further progressive work being allowed to proceed. Failure to submit certification or failure to make said corrections required hereby shall be cause to issue a stop-work order for the project. 
(c)  Duties and responsibilities of the administrator. Duties of the chief building official or designee shall include, but shall not be limited to: 
(1)  Review proposed development to assure that the permit requirements of this chapter have been satisfied; 
(2)  Review proposed development to assure that all necessary permits have been received from governmental agencies from which approval is required by federal or state law including section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972, 33 U.S.C. 1334, and require that copies of such permits be provided and maintained on file; 
(3)  Review all permit applications to determine whether proposed building sites will be reasonably safe from flooding; 
(4)  When base flood elevation data or floodway data have not been provided in accordance with subsection 10-2(b), then the chief building official or designee shall obtain, review and reasonably utilize any base flood elevation and floodway data available from a Federal, State, or other source in order to administer the provisions of Section 10-4; 
(5)  Review and record the actual elevation in relation to mean sea level (or highest adjacent grade) of the lowest floor, including basement, of all new or substantially improved structures in accordance with subsection 10-3(b)(2); 
(6)  Review and record the actual elevation, in relation to mean sea level, to which any new or substantially improved structures have been flood-proofed, in accordance with subsection 10-3(b)(2); 
(7)  When flood-proofing is utilized for a structure, the chief building official or designee shall obtain certification of design criteria from a registered professional engineer or architect in accordance with subsections 10-3(b)(1)c. and 10-4(b)(2) or subsection 10-4(d)(2); 
(8)  Make substantial damage determinations following a flood event or any other event that causes damage to structures in flood hazard areas; 
(9)  Notify adjacent communities and the Georgia Department of Natural Resources prior to any alteration or relocation of a watercourse and submit evidence of such notification to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA); 
(10)  For any altered or relocated watercourse, submit engineering data/analysis within six months to the FEMA to ensure accuracy of community flood maps through the letter of map revision process, and assure that flood-carrying capacity of any altered or relocated watercourse is maintained; 
(11)  Where interpretation is needed as to the exact location of boundaries of the areas of special flood hazard (for example, where there appears to be a conflict between a mapped boundary and actual field conditions) the chief building official or designee shall make the necessary interpretation. Any person contesting the location of the boundary shall be given a reasonable opportunity to appeal the interpretation as provided in this chapter; 
(12)  All records pertaining to the provisions of this chapter shall be maintained in the office of the Rome/Floyd County Building Inspection Department and shall be open for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2009-10-2, § I, 10-5-09) 
Sec. 10-4. - Provisions for flood hazard reduction. 
(a)  General standards. In all special flood hazard areas the following provisions are required: 
(1)  New construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall be anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure; 
(2)  New construction and substantial improvements of existing structures shall be constructed with materials and utility equipment resistant to flood damage; 
(3)  New construction or substantial improvements of existing structures shall be constructed by methods and practices that minimize flood damage; 
(4)  Elevated buildings. All new construction or substantial improvements of existing structures that include any fully enclosed area located below the lowest floor formed by foundation and other exterior walls shall be designed so as to be an unfinished or flood resistant enclosure. The enclosure shall be designed to equalize hydrostatic flood forces on exterior walls by allowing for the automatic entry and exit of floodwater. 
a.  Designs for complying with this requirement must either be certified by a professional engineer or architect or meet the following minimum criteria: 
(i)  Provide a minimum of two openings having a total net area of not less than one square inch for every square foot of enclosed area subject to flooding; 
(ii)  The bottom of all openings shall be no higher than one foot above grade; and 
(iii)  Openings may be equipped with screens, louvers, valves or other coverings or devices provided they permit the automatic flow of floodwater in both directions. 
b.  So as not to violate the "lowest floor" criteria of this chapter, the unfinished or flood-resistant enclosure shall only be used for parking of vehicles, limited storage of maintenance equipment used in connection with the premises, or entry to the elevated area; and 
c.  The interior portion of such enclosed area shall not be partitioned or finished into separate rooms. 
(5)  All heating and air conditioning equipment and components (including ductwork), all electrical, ventilation, plumbing, and other service facilities shall be designed and/or located so as to prevent water from entering or accumulating within the components during conditions of flooding. 
(6)  Manufactured homes shall be anchored to prevent flotation, collapse, or lateral movement. Methods of anchoring may include, but are not limited to, use of over-the-top or frame ties to ground anchors. This standard shall be in addition to and consistent with applicable state requirements for resisting wind forces. 
(7)  New and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the system. 
(8)  New and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the systems into floodwaters. 
(9)  On-site waste disposal systems shall be located and constructed to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them during flooding. 
(10)  Any alteration, repair, reconstruction or improvement to a structure which is not compliant with the provisions of this chapter shall be undertaken only if the nonconformity is not furthered, extended or replaced. 
(b)  Specific standards. In all special flood hazard areas the following provisions are required: 
(1)  New construction and/or substantial improvements. Where base flood elevation data are available, new construction and/or substantial improvement of any structure or manufactured home shall have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated no lower than two feet above the base flood elevation. Should solid foundation perimeter walls be used to elevate a structure, openings sufficient to facilitate equalization of flood hydrostatic forces on both sides of exterior walls shall be provided in accordance with standards of subsection 10-4(a)(4), "elevated buildings." 
a.  All heating and air conditioning equipment and components (including ductwork), all electrical, ventilation, plumbing, and other service facilities shall be elevated at or above one foot above the base flood elevation. 
b.  Sufficient fill shall be placed, if necessary, to provide at least 15 feet of clearance at the ground surface between all faces of any building containing a dwelling unit and the base flood limits. 
(2)  Nonresidential construction. New construction and/or the substantial improvement of any structure located in A1-30, AE, or AH zones, may be flood proofed in lieu of elevation. The structure, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, must be designed to be water tight to two feet above the base flood elevation, with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water, and structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and the effect of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the design and methods of construction are in accordance with accepted standards of practice for meeting the provisions above, and shall provide such certification to the official as set forth above and in subsection 10-3(c)(7). 
a.  Sufficient fill shall be placed, if necessary, to provide at least 30 feet of clearance at the ground surface from the face of the building, at its principal entrance, and the base flood limits. 
(3)  Flood storage capacity and impediments. Any cut or fill within the floodplain must be graded to provide positive drainage to the main watercourse. Fill placed within the floodplain shall be limited such that at no point is the cross-sectional area of the floodplain outside the floodway and below the base flood elevation as measured perpendicular to the direction of the watercourse reduced by more than 60 percent. 
(4)  Standards for manufactured homes and recreational vehicles. Where base flood elevation data are available: 
a.  All manufactured homes placed and/or substantially improved on: 
(i)  Individual lots or parcels, 
(ii)  In new and/or substantially improved manufactured home parks or subdivisions, 
(iii)  In expansions to existing manufactured home parks or subdivisions, 
(iv)  On a site in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision where a manufactured home has incurred "substantial damage" as the result of a flood, must have the lowest floor, including basement, elevated no lower than two feet above the base flood elevation. 
b.  Manufactured homes placed and/or substantially improved in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision may be elevated so that either: 
(i)  The lowest floor of the manufactured home is elevated no lower than two feet above the level of the base flood elevation; or 
(ii)  The manufactured home chassis is elevated and supported by reinforced piers (or other foundation elements of at least an equivalent strength) of no less than 36 inches in height above grade. 
c.  All manufactured homes must be securely anchored to an adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse and lateral movement as provided in subsection 10-4(a)(6). 
d.  All recreational vehicles placed on sites must: 
(i)  Be on the site for fewer than 180 consecutive days. 
(ii)  Be fully licensed and ready for highway use (a recreational vehicle is ready for highway use if it is licensed, on its wheels or jacking system, attached to the site only by quick disconnect-type utilities and security devices, and has no permanently attached structures or additions); or 
(iii)  The recreational vehicle must meet all the requirements for "New Construction", including the anchoring and elevation requirements of subsections 10-4(b)a. and (b)c. 
(5)  Floodway. Located within special flood hazard areas established in subsection 10-2(b) are areas designated as floodways. A floodway may be an extremely hazardous area due to velocity floodwaters, debris or erosion potential. In addition, the area must remain free of encroachment in order to allow for the discharge of the base flood without increased flood heights. Therefore, the following provisions shall apply: 
a.  Encroachments are prohibited, including earthen fill, new construction, substantial improvements or other development within the regulatory floodway. Development may be permitted, however, provided it is demonstrated through hydrologic and hydraulic analyses performed in accordance with standard engineering practice that the encroachment shall not result in any increase in flood levels or floodway widths during a base flood discharge. A registered professional engineer must provide supporting technical data and certification thereof. 
b.  Any new construction or substantial improvement shall comply with all other applicable flood hazard reduction provisions of section 10-4. 
(c)  Building standards for streams without established base flood elevations and/or floodway (A-Zones). Located within the special flood hazard areas established in subsection 10-2(b), where streams exist but no base flood data have been provided (A-Zones), or where base flood data have been provided but a floodway has not been delineated, the following provisions apply: 
(1)  When base flood elevation data or floodway data have not been provided in accordance with subsection 10-2(b), then the chief building official or designee shall obtain, review, and reasonably utilize any scientific or historic base flood elevation and floodway data available from a federal, state, or other source, in order to administer the provisions of section 10-4. If data is not available from these sources, only then shall subsections (2) and (3) apply.
