(8)  Whether or not the applicant, his spouse, or any member of the applicant's household is a member or employee of the police department, whether or not any member or employee of the police department is interested in any way, directly or indirectly, in the license applied for, the devices or the operation of the same; and whether or not the applicant has received or borrowed money or anything else of value or accepted credit from any member or employee of the department or the spouse or any member of the household of any member or employee. 
(9)  A statement that the applicant permits a record of his fingerprints to be made by the police department for the purpose of additional investigation to determine whether or not the application should be granted. 
(10)  Written approval of the chief of police, who shall issue such approval when he finds that the applicant is not guilty of any of the violations or facts listed in subsection (d)(6), (7) or (8). 
(e)  Issuance of license. Upon receipt of the proper application and the tax, the secretary shall then issue a license for the center. 
(f)  Location. No license shall be valid except for the location shown in the application. 
(g)  Regulations. 
(1)  No amusement center nor any coin-operated amusement device therein shall be operated so as to constitute a public nuisance. 
(2)  It shall be the responsibility of the licensee to maintain order on the licensed premises at all times. 
(3)  It shall be the responsibility of the licensee to see that the licensed premises do not become overcrowded so as to constitute a hazard to the health or safety of persons therein. 
(4)  The licensee shall provide a full-time adult attendant upon the licensed premises during business hours. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the business of operating an amusement center to sell, offer for sale or knowingly permit to be sold or offered for sale or to be dispensed or consumed or brought on the licensed premises any alcoholic or malt beverages. 
(6)  Every amusement center licensed under this section shall have affixed on its premises in plain view evidence of the issuance of its license. 
(7)  The license required and described in this section shall be purely a personal privilege and shall not constitute property. It is not transferable in any manner. 
(8)  Any violation of the Criminal Code of Georgia (O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq.), or of any ordinance, pertaining to obscene materials as defined and regulated in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-80 et seq., shall result in immediate revocation of a license issued under this section. 
(Code 1959, § 17-38; Ord. No. 78-12, 3-20-78; Ord. No. 79-3, 4-16-79; Code 1981, § 9-9006) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 11-57. - Rummage sales. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, the term rummage sale means any sale of used or new goods by persons not regularly engaged in the business of such sales and shall include garage sales, yard sales, attic sales, flea markets and other such sales however named. 
(b)  No person shall conduct at his or her place of residence rummage sales for more than two, two-day periods in any one calendar year. 
(c)  Any person who conducts a rummage sale away from his or her place of residence and in a C-3 zone may do so only after having purchased a rummage sale license from the city. 
(d)  Any person who conducts a rummage sale away from his or her place of residence and outside a C-3 zone may do so only after having purchased an itinerant vendor license from the city. 
(e)  The rummage sale license and the itinerant vendor license provided for in subsections (c) and (d), respectively, above may be issued without a fee to bona fide charity and nonprofit organizations, such as churches, schools and civic groups. 
(Code 1981, § 9-9007; Ord. No. 93-1-2, § I, 1-4-93) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 11-58. - Dealers in precious metals. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Dealer in precious metals means any person engaged in the business of buying, selling or pawning precious metals, whether for cash or trade, and whether or not a fixed place of business is maintained for such purposes. 
Precious metals means any form of gold, silver or platinum. 
(b)  Notice required. Prior to any buying, selling, trading or otherwise dealing in precious metals, and prior to advertising to carry on such activities, a person shall, at least 72 hours prior to such activity and/or advertisement, file with the chief of police a written notice of intent to conduct such business in the city. Such notice shall include the following: 
(1)  The full name and address of the person. 
(2)  The full name and address of the person's employer, if any. 
(3)  The length of stay within the city, including dates of opening and closing business. 
(4)  The address and time at which the business will be conducted. 
(c)  Records. Every precious metal dealer shall keep a well-bound record book or register into which shall be entered an accurate description of all property pledged, traded, purchased or sold by him. Such description shall include all the information required for the reports to the police department, as provided for in this section, and shall contain a copy of each receipt, bill of sale, or document transferred between the dealer and his customer. All entries shall be made as soon after the transaction as is possible and in no event more than two hours after such transaction. 
(d)  Report to police department; contents; submission. Every dealer in precious metals shall make to the police department a written report of all transactions in which he has been involved. The report shall be delivered to the police department not less than 24 hours after a day's transactions, and in addition to any other information required by the chief of police, the report shall contain the following information under column titles as follows: 
(1)  Articles. The entry in this column shall be a description of the class of goods within which the purchased items belong (coins, rings, silverware, etc.). 
(2)  Description of articles. The entry in this column shall be a full description of the articles, including style, material, color, design, number of stones in jewelry, and any and all identifying names, weights and numbers. 
(3)  Amount paid. In this column, there shall be entered the amount paid for the articles by the precious metals dealer. 
(4)  Name and address of seller. The entry in this column shall contain the name and address of the person presenting the goods for sale, and such name shall be substantiated and verified by the dealer in precious metals by examination of the driver's license, social security card or other reliable identification, which shall also be entered, including driver's license or social security number or other identification. 
(5)  Description of person. The entry in this column shall include the physical description of the seller, indicating sex, race, age, hair color, height and weight. 
(e)  Duty to retain goods. No precious metals received by a dealer in precious metals shall be sold or permitted to be removed from his place of business for a period of five working days from the time of receiving same, and all such items shall be retained in the original condition in which they were received during the five working days' period. 
(f)  Notice of altered goods. With respect to any items which normally have a serial number or other means of identification, if any dealer in precious metals becomes aware that such items have had the serial number or other means of identification removed, mutilated, defaced, destroyed, or melted down, such fact shall be immediately reported by the dealer to the chief of police or his duly authorized agent. 
(g)  Surrender of stolen property. If it is determined that any item bought, sold, traded or received by the precious metals dealer is the subject of any theft, the precious metals dealer shall, upon demand of the chief of police or his designated agent, surrender the same to the police department. 
(h)  Dealing with minors. No precious metals dealer shall receive in pawn, trade, purchase or sale, any precious metals from a person under 18 years of age. 
(i)  Violations. Any violation of this section shall be grounds for refusing or revoking a license, and the person responsible may be punished as provided for in section 1-9. 
(Ord. of 12-8-80, § 1; Code 1981, § 9-9008) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Dealers in precious metals and gems, O.C.G.A. § 43-37-1 et seq. 
Sec. 11-59. - Public dances. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Public dance means any dance held or conducted on city property. 
(b)  Public dances may be held within the corporate limits of the city, subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  The city commission is hereby authorized to issue permits to responsible organizations that desire to sponsor public dances within the corporate limits of the city. A record of such permits shall be maintained by the secretary and such permits shall remain effective until and unless revoked by the commission. It shall be unlawful for any person to sponsor a public dance within the corporate limits of the city without first having obtained, and having in force at the time, such a permit. 
(2)  No public dance shall be held within the corporate limits of the city unless the police department shall have been given at least three days' notice in writing of the date, time and place of the proposed dance. The person sponsoring such dance shall be responsible for providing such police attendance and protection as, in the opinion of the chief of police, is adequate to meet the need therefor. 
(Code 1959, §§ 20-8, 20-9, 20-11; Code 1981, § 9-9009) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Roadhouses and public dance halls, O.C.G.A. § 43-21-50 et seq. 
Sec. 11-60. - Sidewalk cafes. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Sidewalk cafe means an area of food service located outside, but connected with, a part of, and adjacent to, an indoor restaurant or cafe located in the city. 
(b)  Application for permit. Notwithstanding the provisions of sections 20-1 through 20-4, a licensed restaurant may apply to the city's office of downtown development for a permit to operate a sidewalk cafe. Such application shall contain at least the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the licensee; 
(2)  The proposed location; 
(3)  A description of the proposed use or occupancy of the public right-of-way; and 
(4)  Such other information as may be reasonably required by the office of downtown development. 
(c)  Condition for permit issuance. Upon review and approval of the office of downtown development, the city clerk's office shall issue a permit containing restrictions, terms, and conditions to ensure the proper use for public property and to protect the health, safety and welfare of the city, including the following: 
(1)  The area permitted for sidewalk cafes shall be so located and maintained that only the following portion of the sidewalk shall be used: 
a.  Within the CBC district, no more than an eight-foot portion of the sidewalk measured from the face of the restaurant perpendicularly toward the curb. 
b.  Within the eight feet outside wall of the restaurant and perpendicular to the curb, a minimum of four feet shall be provided at all times from continuous unobstructed pedestrian traffic on the sidewalk between the sidewalk cafe and the curb or nearest obstacle. 
c.  Permanent plantings, city-owned waste receptacles, streetlight poles and other permanent fixtures along the sidewalk must be considered when determining the boundaries set forth in a permit. 
d.  The office of downtown development shall serve as the review agency for site plans, specifications, fixtures, materials and annual renewals. 
(2)  Any special construction proposed to encroach upon or occupy any of the public right-of-way shall be permitted only by prior approval of such plans by the chief building official. 
(3)  The permit holder of any sidewalk cafe shall at all times ensure that: 
a.  No encroachment on public rights-of-right, other than as stated in this section, shall be allowed to exist. 
b.  All restrictions, terms and conditions of any permit granted for sidewalk cafes shall be met. 
c.  All general provisions and clean community regulations of the refuse collection and disposal provisions of chapter 19 are complied with. 
(4)  The issuance of a sidewalk cafe permit shall not be construed or interpreted to convey any property rights or any other rights not expressly set forth in such permit. 
(5)  Permits are renewed within the first quarter of each calendar year. 
(d)  Regulations. Except as otherwise provided, a sidewalk cafe operating in the city shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Limitations on area. The area in which a sidewalk cafe is operated shall abut the outside front wall of the restaurant of which it is an extension and shall not extend in either direction beyond the outside front wall of the restaurant. 
(2)  Divider required. At restaurants where alcohol is served, the area permitted for a sidewalk cafe shall be separated from the remaining sidewalk area by a system of connected posts and railing that serves to contain crowds and maintain the boundaries of the cafe. The system shall be designed and constructed such that it resists movement and can be disassembled and removed, if necessary. The design must be included in the application and must be approved prior to issuance of a permit. Such divider shall not be less than three feet (36 inches) nor more than three feet six inches (42 inches) in height. All tables and chairs shall be located totally within the limits of the divider. It shall be the responsibility of the permit holder to maintain the divider in its exact approved location at all times. 
(3)  Sanitation. It shall be the responsibility and duty of the restaurant to which the sidewalk cafe permit is issued to maintain the area covered by the permit in a clean, neat, and orderly manner at all times. The area shall be cleared of all debris at all times. All tables and chairs are to be kept clean, sanitary, safe, and in structurally sound condition at all times. 
(4)  Removal of furnishings and suspension of operation. All tables, chairs, and dividers of a sidewalk cafe shall be removed from the public sidewalk area from time to time and outside operations suspended as required by the city for sidewalk cleaning or for such other purposes as the city may determine, in its sole discretion, for such purposes as, but not limited to: 
a.  Any permitted special event; 
b.  Any street, sidewalk, or utility construction; 
c.  Any emergency situations; or 
d.  The protection of the health, safety, and welfare of the public. 
(5)  Alcoholic beverages/open containers. Sidewalk cafe permit holder shall be exempt from the restrictions on open containers if such establishment is otherwise licensed to sell alcoholic beverages under the applicable laws and ordinances. All applicable provisions of chapter 3 (Alcoholic Beverages) of the code of the City of Rome and Title 3 (Alcoholic Beverages) of the official Code of Georgia shall be enforced regarding the sale, service, possession, and consumption of alcoholic beverages. The permit holder shall post approved signs designating the limits of the open container area. 
(6)  Furnishings. Furnishings shall not be secured to lamp posts, streetlights, trees or any other public street fixtures. Furnishings may not be stacked or stored outside on the public right-of-way at any time. 
a.  Fences. A system of connected posts and railing, firmly secured, but temporarily moveable, shall serve to maintain the boundaries of the sidewalk cafe and allow visibility to the street patrons. Fences in any approved locations will in no instance be a visual barrier to vehicular traffic or impede driver visibility. Fence materials typically are to be discreet in color, design, materials and finishes and relatively transparent. Flower boxes or planters may be used to define the corner boundaries of the area. 
b.  Menu boards and signs. Menu boards, both portable and on walls, shall be subject to sign permit approval and shall comply with the City Code. 
c.  Trash receptacles. The number, type and location of trash receptacles shall be subject to approval. 
d.  Umbrellas. Each table may be equipped with an umbrella that, when open, shall extend to at least the same diameter as the table it serves and shall be anchored with a weighted base. Any umbrella protruding into public space shall be positioned at a minimum height of seven feet. An umbrella may not display the name or logo of the restaurant operating the sidewalk cafe and/or advertise a product. Each umbrella shall be maintained in good, clean, and operable condition. 
e.  Tables and Chairs. Materials. Tables and chairs shall match and be made of safe, sturdy, and durable material, such as wood, steel, or wrought iron. All furniture shall be commercial grade and manufactured for outdoor commercial use. Small round or square tables shall seat no more than four people. Use of larger tables may be granted provided that all clearance requirements are met. Round tables shall be no larger than three feet diameter. Square tables shall be no larger than three feet wide and rectangular tables no more than three x four feet. Tables shall be no more than 30 inches in height. 
(7)  Landscaping. Flower boxes or planters may be used to define the corner boundaries of the seating area. The combined height of the planters and live plants shall not exceed four feet from sidewalk grade and no wider than two feet at the base. The planting areas shall be planted with seasonal blooming or ornamental evergreen live plants year round. The permit holder shall maintain flower boxes and planting areas. The flower boxes, planters and trash receptacles shall be portable and made of safe, durable and attractive materials such as wood, steel or colored concrete. 
(8)  Hours of operation. A business with a sidewalk cafe permit may be open for breakfast, lunch and/or dinner and any combination thereof, consistent with the businesses normal hours of operation. 
(9)  Smoking. Those businesses which are prohibited by state or local law from allowing smoking within the interior of their establishments may not allow smoking within the area permitted for a sidewalk cafe. 
(10)  Guidelines. The city shall adopt standards and guidelines for consideration of applications, without amendments to this article. 
(e)  Liability and insurance. The city shall require permit holders to indemnify and hold harmless the city and its officers and employees for claims and liability arising out of the permit holder's use of a sidewalk cafe. The city shall require the permit holder to obtain insurance covering the use of a sidewalk cafe and to name the city as an additional insured with respect to such insurance. The city shall prepare guidelines with respect to any indemnification and insurance requirements of permit holders. 
(f)  Revocation or suspension of permit. The approval of a sidewalk cafe permit is conditional at all times. A sidewalk cafe permit may be revoked or suspended by the city's code enforcement officer, upon approval of the city clerk's office, if it is found that: 
(1)  Any necessary business or health permit has been suspended, revoked, or cancelled. 
(2)  The permit is not incompliance with any of the city's regulations with respect to sidewalk cafes. 
(3)  The permit holder has failed to correct violations of this chapter or any other ordinance within 48 hours of receipt of the notice of same delivered in writing to the permit holder. 
(4)  The permit holder has a history of violations of this chapter of three or more within a two-year period, or immediately upon any violation depending upon severity of the violation. 
(5)  Permits may be suspended for a period up to 12 months depending upon history and severity of violations. 
(g)  Fines for violations. In addition to the possible revocation or suspension of a permit, the following minimum fines shall be imposed for violations of this chapter: 
(1)  First citation: $100.00 fine. 
(2)  Second citation (within one-year period): $250.00 fine. 
(3)  Third and subsequent citations (within one-year period): $500.00 fine. 
(h)  Americans with Disabilities Act. Any person or entity receiving a permit hereunder agrees to fully comply with all requirements of the Americans with Disabilities Act as currently existing or as may be hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 2007-6-2, § I, 6-18-07; Ord. No. 2011-6-2, §§ I—V, 6-6-11; Ord. No. 2015-05-02, §§ I—III, 5-26-15) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2007-6-2, § I, adopted June 18, 2007, deleted in its entirety the former Art. II, § 11-60, and replaced it with a new Art. II, § 11-60 as set out herein. The former Art. II, § 11-60 pertained to similar subject matter. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 11-61. - Fair housing. 
The provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 8-3-202, 8-3-203 and 8-3-204 are hereby adopted verbatim. 
(Ord. No. 79-4, 5-21-79; Code 1981, §§ 8-8001—8-8007) 
State Law reference— Fair housing, O.C.G.A. § 8-3-200 et seq. 
Secs. 11-62—11-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ADVERTISING[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Distributing advertising matter, § 19-54. 
State Law reference— False advertising, O.C.G.A. § 10-1-420 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 11-86. - Deceptive advertisements illegal. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to publish, or place before the public in a newspaper or in any other way, an advertisement of any sort regarding goods or services offered to the public for sale or distribution and containing any representation or statement of fact which is untrue or misleading, with intent to sell or in any way dispose of such goods or services, or to induce the public in any manner to enter into any obligation relating thereto or to acquire title or interest therein. 
(Ord. No. 79-17, 10-1-79; Code 1981, § 9-3001) 
Sec. 11-87. - Price reductions must be bona fide. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise or otherwise represent to the public in any manner whatsoever a reduction in the price of any goods or services, of whatsoever kind offered to the public, where the reduction is not based upon a previous bona fide sale price or cost price previously advertised or represented to the public for the articles or services so offered to the public. 
(Ord. No. 79-17, 10-1-79; Code 1981, § 9-3002) 
Sec. 11-88. - Deceptive representations. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, by means of exaggerated variations in the comparative size, location or position of letters, figures or other markings or characters in any price tag, or other public representation of any nature whatsoever, to mislead or deceive the public as to the true nature, price, quantity, quality, brand or character of any goods or services, or as to the nature of, or the reason, for the sale so being made to the public. 
(Ord. No. 79-17, 10-1-79; Code 1981, § 9-3003) 
Sec. 11-89. - Sound trucks and sound amplifying devices. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Sound-amplifying equipment means any machine or device for the amplification of any sound. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or permit to be operated in the city any sound-amplifying devices or equipment for any purpose whatever, whether the same is stationary or operated from a vehicle, unless a permit has been obtained from the chief of police to do so; provided, however, that it shall be unlawful for any person to make any loud and raucous noise to the disturbance of the peace. Any person to whom a permit has been issued under this section who abuses his discretion and causes or permits loud and raucous noises shall subject the permit to immediate revocation. 
(Ord. No. 79-17, 10-1-79; Code 1981, § 9-3004) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 12. 
Sec. 11-90. - Advertising on sidewalks prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to paint, print, write, or stamp with paint, pencil, ink, or other substances, any advertisement or notice upon the sidewalks of the city. 
(Ord. No. 79-17, 10-1-79; Code 1981, § 9-3005) 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 20. 
Secs. 11-91—11-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SIGNS AND OUTDOOR ADVERTISING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings, ch. 5; zoning, ch. 23. 
State Constitution reference— Outdoor advertising devices near certain highways, art. III, § VI, par. II(a)(6). 
State Law reference— Outdoor advertising near state highways, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-70 et seq. 

Sec. 11-116. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Air and gas filled device means any sign using, either wholly or in part, forced air or other gas as a means of supporting its structure. 
Area of sign (sign area) means the area within a continuous perimeter enclosing the limits of writing, representation, emblem, or any figure of similar character together with any frame, other material, open space, or color forming an integral part of the display or used to differentiate such sign from the background against which it is placed. 
Awning/canopy means a structure made of cloth, metal, or other material affixed to a building and/or supported by the ground. 
Banner means a sign intended to be hung either with or without a frame, possessing characters, letters, illustrations, or ornamentations applied to paper, plastic, or fabric of any kind excluding flags, emblems, and insignia or political, professional, religious, educational, or corporate organizations, provided that such flags, emblems and insignia are displayed for non- commercial purposes. 
Building inspector means the person designated by the city as the chief building and zoning inspection official or his designated representative. 
Changeable copy sign means a permanently mounted sign designed to accept changeable letters, symbols, or other characters. 
Construction sign means a sign erected and maintained on the premises announcing the proposed or existing construction of a building or project. 
Flag means a cloth, fabric or plastic sign with one pole or angular two-sided frame intended to be mounted to a pole or on its own support that bears a company, corporation, or business emblem, logo, letters, illustrations or characters depicting that organization. This is to be exclusive of American, states' or any other jurisdiction's flag. 
Flashing sign means a sign, the illumination of which is not kept constant in intensity at all times when in use, and which exhibits marked changes in lighting effects. 
Freestanding sign means a permanently affixed sign which is wholly independent of a building for support. 
Hanging sign means a sign which is suspended by a chain or cable from an awning, canopy or marquee. 
Height of sign means, in the case of freestanding signs, the distance in vertical feet measured from the level of an adjacent street centerline to the highest point of the sign structure, provided, however, that all freestanding sign structures shall be allowed to be built to a height of 40 feet. For other signs, the height is to be measured from the grade below the sign. 
Illuminated sign means a sign illuminated by an internal or external light source. 
Marquee means a permanent roof-like structure extending from part of the wall of a building but not supported by the ground, and constructed of a durable material. 
Moving sign means a sign which revolves, rotates, swings, undulates or otherwise attracts attention through the structural movement of parts, but not including flags, banners or pennants. 
Nonconforming sign means any sign which does not conform to the provisions of this division. 
Nonpermitted zoning district means a zoning district in the city within which signs cannot be erected. 
Nonprofit activity means an activity, project, operation, or enterprise of a temporary nature carried on by a corporation or an organization qualified as an exempt organization under applicable provisions of the Internal Revenue Code. 
Off-premises sign means a sign that advertises a product, service, place, activity, person, institution, business or solicitation which is not carried out on the premises upon which the sign is located. 
On-premises sign means a sign located on the same premises on which the advertised product, service, place, activity, person, institution, business or solicitation is located. For the purposes of this division, this shall include: 
(1)  Actions, functions, demonstrations, displays, offerings for sale, or sales that occur on the premises. 
(2)  Actions, functions, demonstrations, displays, sales, offerings for sale, products, services or merchandise that are advertised or promoted on the premises. 
(3)  Actions, functions, products, services or merchandise that are on display on the premises. 
(4)  Actions, functions, demonstrations, displays, sales, offerings for sale, service or merchandise about which additional information and data can be received at a location on the premises. 
ON-PREMISES FREESTANDING SIGN 
Political sign means a sign identifying and urging voter support for a particular election issue, political party, or candidate for public office. 
Portable sign means any sign which is manifestly designed to be transported, including by trailer or on its own wheels, even though the wheels of such sign may be removed and the remaining chassis or support constructed without wheels is converted to an A- or T-frame sign or attached temporarily or permanently to the ground. 
Projecting sign means a sign which is affixed to a building or wall and extends beyond the line of such building or wall or beyond the surface of that portion of the building or wall to which it is affixed by more than 18 inches. 
Real estate sign means a temporary sign erected by the owner or his agent, advertising the real property upon which the sign is located for rent, for lease, or for sale. 
Road frontage means the width in linear feet of each lot where it abuts the right-of-way of any public street. 
Roofline means the top of a flat roof or the ridge of a gable, hip or gambrel roof. 
ROOFLINE    ROOFLINE 
Roof sign means a sign projecting over the coping top of a flat roof, or over the ridge of a gable, hip or gambrel roof, and/or supported by or attached to such roof. 
Sidewalk, sandwich or A-frame sign means a sign which is normally in the shape of an A or some variation thereof and which is usually two-sided. 
Sign means any identification, description, illustration or device, illuminated or nonilluminated, which is visible to the general public and directs attention to a product, service, place, activity, person, institution, business or solicitation, including any permanently installed or situated merchandise; or any emblem, painting, flag, banner, pennant, balloon, or placard designed to advertise, identify, or convey information. 
Sign face means the part of a sign that is or can be used for advertising purposes. 
Street means any and all kinds of public ways, lanes or alleys and each part thereof, including the pavement, shoulders, curbing, gutters, storm drains, sidewalks and rights-of-way. 
Temporary sign means a sign of a nonpermanent nature which is permitted to be displayed by a business for not more than 30 days per calendar year. 
Wall face means a measurement of area equal to the height of the structure from the ground to the coping or eave of the roof multiplied by the width of the wall associated with the individual business. The wall face is to be measured for each wall independently. 
Wall sign means a sign applied to or mounted to the wall or surface of a building or structure, the display surface of which does not project more than 18 inches from the outside wall of such building or structure, exclusive of lighting, catwalks, etc. The total lettering on one wall face shall constitute a wall sign and be measured independently of other wall faces. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Ord. No. 89-12-2, § II, 12-18-89; Code 1981, § 9-3012) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 11-117. - Purpose. 
(a)  Regulation of the location, size, placement, and certain features of signs is necessary to enable the public to locate goods, services and facilities in the city without difficulty and confusion, to improve the general attractiveness of the community, to take advantage of the beauty of the community's natural environment, and to protect property values therein. Accordingly, it is the intention of the city to establish regulations governing the display of signs which will: 
(1)  Promote and protect the public health, safety, and general welfare. 
(2)  Enhance the economy and the business and industry of the city by promoting the reasonable, orderly and effective display of signs. 
(3)  Restrict signs and lights which increase clutter or which increase the probability of traffic accidents by obstructing vision. 
(4)  Promote signs which are compatible with their surroundings. 
(b)  As these or any regulations can only establish the mechanical limits of signs and not enforce a level of visual quality in sign design, any person planning a sign is strongly encouraged to consider: 
(1)  The character of the proposed sign and the audience for which the sign is to be designed. The applicant is urged to think not only of the sign in and of itself but also in terms of the effects such a sign will have upon the character of the surrounding area. 
(2)  The character of the sign structure, that is, the physical means of supporting the sign, and whether that structure could be made an integral part of the sign rather than a separate and frequently distracting element. 
(c)  Any person contemplating a sign is also encouraged to contact the building inspector or a private firm or individual engaged in sign/graphic design for advice or assistance in the planning of such sign. 
(d)  It is also the purpose of this division to insure proper maintenance, for safety and structural soundness, as well as the appearance and attractiveness of signs. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Ord. No. 89-12-2, § I, 12-18-89; Code 1981, § 9-3011) 
Sec. 11-118. - General regulations. 
(a)  Except as specifically excluded from the provisions of this division, it shall be unlawful for any person to post, display, substantially change, or erect a sign in the city without first obtaining a sign permit. A change in the sign face only of a sign shall not constitute a substantial change. Any sign face change that requires any change in frame, structure, lighting, casing, or any other alteration of the sign shall require a permit. 
(b)  No sign or sign structure shall be more than 40 feet in height. 
(c)  No sign shall be erected within ten feet of any street right-of-way, except wall signs that would be installed, erected or built on a wall that is closer than ten feet from the right-of-way, or as otherwise specified in this division. 
(d)  No sign shall be erected in the city that contains a sign area in excess of 400 square feet. 
(e)  For the purposes of this division, the straightline method of measurement shall be utilized measuring from the nearest point of the sign to the boundary line or structure involved. 
(f)  Every electric sign shall be listed and installed under the standards of an approved electrical testing laboratory or approved by the building inspector and installed in conformance with the standards of the National Electrical Code, and a separate electrical permit shall be purchased therefor. 
(g)  No sign shall be erected that does not meet the construction requirements of the Standard Building Code (SBCCI) when applicable, or the building inspector in those cases when the Standard Building Code (SBCCI) does not apply. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Ord. No. 89-12-2, § III, 12-18-89; Code 1981, § 9-3013) 
Cross reference— Electricity, § 5-111 et seq. 
Sec. 11-119. - Permit application. 
(a)  Applications for sign permits required in section 11-118(a) shall be filed by the sign owner or his agent in the office of the building inspector upon forms furnished by the office of the building inspection department. Such application shall describe and set forth the following: 
(1)  The type and purpose of the sign as defined in this division. 
(2)  The value of the sign. 
(3)  The street address of the property upon which the sign is to be located and the proposed location of the sign on the site. 
(4)  The square foot area per sign and the aggregate square foot area if there is more than one sign face. 
(5)  The names and addresses of the owners of the real property upon which the subject sign is to be located. 
(6)  The written consent of the owner or his agent, granting permission for the placement or maintenance of the subject sign. 
(7)  A sketch or print drawn to scale showing all pertinent information required by the building inspector such as wind pressure requirements and display materials in accordance with the Standard Building Code (SBCCI) as adopted by the city commission. The building inspector may require additional information on such print or sketch to insure compliance with this division. 
(8)  The name, address, telephone number and business license number of the sign contractor. 
(9)  The name, address, telephone number and business license number of the applicant. 
(10)  An affidavit from the applicant certifying that the sign does not violate the requirements of this article. 
(b)  A sign permit shall become null and void if construction of the sign for which the permit has been issued has not begun within six months of the date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Code 1981, § 9-3014) 
Sec. 11-120. - Sign permit fees. 
No sign permit shall be issued until the appropriate application has been filed with the building inspector and appropriate fees paid. The permit fees shall be established by resolution of the city commission and set forth in the fee schedule book of the city, as provided in section 8-36. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Code 1981, § 9-3015) 
Sec. 11-121. - Labels required on signs. 
With each permit under this division the building inspector shall issue a sticker bearing the same number as the permit with which it is issued. It shall be the duty of the building inspector to affix such sticker to the sign in the corner area nearest to the street so it can be easily seen. The absence of a proper sticker on a sign erected subsequent to December 19, 1988, shall be prima facie evidence that the same has been or is being erected or operated in violation of the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Code 1981, § 9-3016) 
Sec. 11-122. - Nonconforming signs. 
(a)  Any permanent sign lawfully existing or under construction on December 19, 1988, which does not conform to one or more of the provisions of this division may be continued in operation and maintained indefinitely as a legal nonconforming sign subject to compliance with the requirements of subsection (b). 
(b)  Maintenance and repair of legal nonconforming signs, normal maintenance of legal nonconforming signs, including changing of copy, necessary nonstructural repairs, and incidental alterations which do not further extend or intensify the nonconforming features of the sign, shall be permitted. If a legal nonconforming sign is damaged or destroyed by any means to the extent of 50 percent or more of its current replacement value, exclusive of the cost of the support structure, the sign may not be rebuilt or used thereafter unless it conforms to all of the provisions of this division. If the damage or destruction of the nonconforming sign is less than 50 percent of the replacement value at that time, the sign may be rebuilt to its original condition and may continue to be displayed. 
(c)  If a business ceases operation for a period of time in excess of 60 days, the sign owner or lessee, or the property owner, shall immediately remove any sign identifying or advertising such business or any product sold thereby; provided, however, this requirement shall not apply where under the provisions of this division an existing conforming sign may be altered to advertise a new business or product sold thereby, and there is evidence that a new business will be in operation on the premises within 60 days. Upon the failure of the sign owner or lessee, or property owner, to comply with this section, the building inspector shall give notice in writing to the sign owner and any lessee and to the property owner, which notice shall state that such sign shall be removed within 30 days. If the sign owner or lessee, or property owner, fails to comply with such written notice to remove, the building inspector is hereby authorized to cause removal of such sign, and any expense incidental to such removal shall be charged to the owner of the property upon which the sign is located and shall constitute a lien upon the property. 
(d)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Remove means: 
(1)  The sign face, along with posts, columns, or supports of freestanding signs, shall be taken down and removed from the property. 
(2)  The sign face and supporting structures of awning/canopy, marquee, projecting, roof, and wall signs shall be taken down and removed from the property. 
(3)  The sign face of painted wall signs shall be removed by painting over the wall sign in such a manner as to completely cover up and hide from sight the sign in question. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Ord. No. 89-12-2, § IV, 12-18-89; Code 1981, § 9-3017) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 11-123. - Signs and sign devices prohibited. 
The following types of signs are prohibited in all zoning districts of the city: 
(1)  Roof signs, with the exception of balloons that do not pose any danger to a roof or other structures, as determined by building inspector or his representative, but only as a temporary sign. 
(2)  Sidewalk, sandwich or curb type signs except as temporary signs for nonprofit activities. 
(3)  Portable or trailer display signs. 
(4)  Air- and gas-filled devices, except as a temporary sign. 
(5)  Hanging signs, except those having less than six square feet in sign area. 
(6)  Off-premises signs, except in accordance with this division. 
(7)  Signs on public rights-of-way, except signs exempt under section 11-124. 
(8)  Searchlights or beacons. 
SEARCHLIGHTS OR BEACONS 
(9)  Moving signs. 
(10)  Signs placed on trees, rocks, and utility poles. 
(11)  Signs erected or displayed in such a manner as to obstruct free and clear vision of a street, intersection, or ingress or egress from parking lots. 
(12)  Signs which, by reason of shape, color, or position may interfere with, obstruct the view of or be confused with any authorized traffic sign, signal or device; or which make use of the word "stop," "danger," "go," "slow," "caution," "warning," or any other word, phrase, symbol or character in such manner as to interfere with, mislead, or confuse traffic. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Ord. No. 89-12-2, § V, 12-18-89; Code 1981, § 9-3018) 
Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 12. 
Sec. 11-124. - Exempt signs. 
The following types of signs are exempt from the requirements of this division: 
(1)  Nonilluminated real estate or construction signs not in excess of 32 square feet, provided such signs are located on the lot or building for sale, lease or being constructed, are not located on any public right-of-way, and are limited to one sign per street frontage. Such signs shall be removed within ten days after the subject lot or building is leased, sold, or construction is completed. 
(2)  Signs of a noncommercial nature and in the public interest, erected by, or on the order of a public officer in the performance of his duty such as public notices, safety signs, danger signs, trespassing signs, traffic and street signs, property street numbers, memorial plaques, and signs of historical interest. 
(3)  Signs on private property directing traffic movement, provided that such signs shall not exceed eight square feet in area nor exceed four feet in length. Such signs shall not be allowed on any public right-of-way. 
(4)  On-premises credit card identification signs up to two square feet per card. Such signs shall be at least ten feet from the public right-of-way of any street. 
(5)  Any sign not visible from public thoroughfares or any sign within a business, office, mall, or other enclosed area. 
(6)  Off-premises nonilluminated church, civic, school, hospital or other quasipublic signs not exceeding four square feet in area. However, no such sign shall be allowed on any public right-of-way. 
OFF-PREMISES  QUASIPUBLIC SIGNS  4 Sq. Ft. Max. 
(7)  On-premises or model home, model apartment, sales office signs, etc., within a residential development, provided such signs do not exceed six square feet in area and are set back at least ten feet from the right-of-way of any street. Such signs shall be limited to one per sales office, model, etc. 
ON-PREMISES MODEL HOME,  APARTMENT SALES OFFICE SIGN 
(8)  On-premises "no trespassing," "no hunting," and similar type public notice signs less than six square feet in area, provided no such signs shall be allowed on any public right-of-way. 
(9)  Restaurant menu signs on private property. Such signs shall not be allowed on any public right-of-way. 
(10)  Signs on vending machines which relate to their intended use. 
(11)  Signs on gas pumps as long as the sign area of these signs does not exceed eight square feet. 
(12)  Professional nameplates not exceeding two square feet in area, such signs to be nonilluminated and attached to the building. 
(13)  Special events signs for nonprofit activities erected with the approval of the building inspector or his representative; provided, that no such sign shall be erected without a sign permit, even though such permit is issued at no charge. 
(14)  Yard sale signs, provided that these are not larger than four square feet in size and are not on any public right-of-way. Such signs shall be removed within three days of the date of the yard sale. 
(15)  On-premises, "no parking," "no cruising" and other similar type public notice signs placed at shopping centers, shopping malls, and parking lots. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Ord. No. 89-12-2, § VI, 12-18-89; Code 1981, § 9-3019) 
Sec. 11-125. - Signs permitted and regulated in designated zoning districts. 
(a)  Any sign not specifically permitted in a zoning district as provided under this section shall be prohibited in that district except as otherwise provided for under this division. 
(b)  No sign shall be erected in the following zoning districts of the city: R-1A, R-1B, R-2A, R-2B, R-2C, R-HR, R-3 and A-1 except: 
(1)  Temporary real estate signs not in excess of six square feet. 
(2)  Temporary signs pertaining to the sale or lease of lots or dwellings within a residential development. 
(3)  Permanent signs identifying only the name of a residential development. 
(4)  Church bulletins, signs identifying schools, public nonprofit recreation facilities, churches, and public buildings and facilities. 
(5)  Political signs in conformance with section 11-134. 
(6)  Customary home occupation signs. Such signs are limited to one per premises and shall not be illuminated, in excess of one square foot in area, and located less than 20 feet from any property line. In all other respects, these signs shall conform and be established in accordance with chapter 23. 
(7)  A sign advertising the presence of a bed and breakfast lodging or a bed and breakfast inn. 
(c)  Only on-premises signs shall be erected in O and O-I zoning districts of the city, provided that no such sign shall exceed 32 square feet and shall not be closer than ten feet to the right-of-way of any street. 
(d)  Unless otherwise prohibited or limited in this division, all sign classifications shall be permitted in the following zoning districts: C-1, C-2, C-3, C-4, PUD, M-1 and M-2. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Ord. No. 90-1-5, § I, 1-22-90; Code 1981, § 9-3020) 
Cross reference— Zoning, ch. 23. 
Sec. 11-126. - Off-premises freestanding signs. 
(a)  No off-premises sign shall be permitted within a linear distance of 1,000 feet from the nearest point of any other off-premises sign structure with each side of the road being measured independently. 
(b)  No off-premises sign shall be permitted within a linear distance of 200 feet from the boundary line of a nonpermitted zoning district located on the same side of an adjacent street. 
(c)  No off-premises freestanding sign shall be allowed within an historic zoning district. 
(d)  No off-premises sign shall be erected within ten feet of any street right-of-way. 
(e)  No off-premises sign shall be permitted which would be located within 100 feet of a residential structure located within a residential zone. 
(f)  The off-premises freestanding sign structure shall have a maximum height of 40 feet. 
(g)  No off-premises sign shall be permitted within 1,000 feet of the Coosa, Etowah, and/or Oostanaula Rivers with such distance to be measured from the 580-foot mean sea level elevation contour. 
(h)  No off-premises sign shall be permitted along the length of Riverside Parkway within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Code 1981, § 9-3021) 
Cross reference— Zoning, ch. 23. 
Sec. 11-127. - On-premises freestanding signs. 
(a)  No on-premises freestanding sign shall be erected within ten feet of any street right-of-way, provided, however, that the setback requirement may be reduced to three feet where the road right-of-way is 100 feet or more in width. 
(b)  The allowable sign area for each sign shall be an amount equal to the ratio of 1.5 square feet per one linear foot of road frontage to a maximum of 400 square feet per sign, provided, however, that every property shall be allowed a sign with a sign area of up to 25 square feet. 
(c)  One sign per property shall be allowed, except properties between 1.0 and 1.9 acres shall be allowed up to two signs, and properties over 2.0 acres shall be allowed up to three signs. 
(d)  The on-premises freestanding sign structure shall have a maximum height of 40 feet. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Ord. No. 91-9-3, § I, 9-16-91; Code 1981, § 9-3022) 
Sec. 11-128. - On-premises signs, excluding freestanding signs, generally. 
The maximum sign area of all on-premises signs, exclusive of freestanding signs, shall not exceed 20 percent of the square footage of the wall face upon which they are situated. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Code 1981, § 9-3023) 
Sec. 11-129. - Wall signs. 
(a)  Wall signs shall not project more than 18 inches from the wall face upon which they are situated. 
(b)  Wall signs shall not extend above the eave or roofline nor shall they project beyond the edge of the wall face of the building upon which they are situated. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Code 1981, § 9-3024) 
Sec. 11-130. - Projecting signs. 
(a)  Projecting signs shall be attached to the vertical surface of a building and shall not extend higher than 12 feet or beyond the eave or roofline of the building to which they are attached, whichever is lower. Projecting signs shall have a minimum height of nine feet. 
(b)  Projecting signs shall meet the requirements of the Standard Building Code (SBCCI) as adopted by the city commission. 
(c)  Projecting signs shall not extend farther than six feet perpendicular to the wall to which they are attached. 
(d)  The area of projecting signs shall not exceed 18 square feet. 
(e)  Off-premises projecting signs are prohibited within the city. 
(f)  A hanging sign may be attached to any awning, canopy, or marquee. The location and arrangement of all such signs shall be subject to the review and approval of the building inspector. Such signs shall have a maximum sign area of six square feet and shall have a minimum height of nine feet. 
(g)  Signs on an awning, canopy, or marquee shall not project higher than the face of the awning, canopy, or marquee to which such signs are to be affixed. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Code 1981, § 9-3025) 
Cross reference— Building code, § 5-75 et seq. 
Sec. 11-131. - Temporary signs. 
(a)  The owner or his agent must notify the building inspector prior to the placement of a temporary sign. Nonprofit activities shall be exempt from this requirement. Such permission may be granted to the same business for a maximum of 30 days within any calendar year. 
(b)  Temporary signs include the following: 
(1)  Signs advertising festivals, special events, etc., provided that such signs shall not be closer than ten feet from any street right-of-way. 
(2)  On-premises signs relating to the initial opening or final closing of a business or service, provided that such sign shall not be closer than ten feet to any public right-of-way. 
(3)  Air- and gas-filled devices. 
(4)  Balloons, streamers, banners, and pennants. 
(5)  Construction signs. Such signs shall be removed from the site within one week of the issuance of a certificate of occupancy from the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Code 1981, § 9-3026) 
Sec. 11-132. - Maintenance and appearance of signs. 
(a)  All signs shall be maintained in good condition as to present a neat and orderly appearance. The building inspector may cause to be removed after due notice any sign which shows gross neglect or becomes dilapidated. 
(b)  The building inspector will give the owner 30 days' written notice to correct the deficiencies or to remove the signs. If the owner refuses to correct the deficiencies or remove the signs the building inspector may have the signs removed at the expense of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Code 1981, § 9-3027) 
Sec. 11-133. - Illumination of signs. 
(a)  The light from any illuminated sign shall not be of an intensity or brightness which will interfere with the general welfare of residents or occupants of adjacent properties. 
(b)  No colored lights shall be used at any location or in any manner so as to be confused with or construed as traffic control devices. 
(c)  Neither direct nor reflected light from primary light sources shall create a hazard to operators of motor vehicles. 
(d)  Every electric sign shall be listed and installed under the standards of an approved electrical testing laboratory or approved by the building inspector and installed in conformance with the standards of the National Electrical Code. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Code 1981, § 9-3028) 
Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 12. 
Sec. 11-134. - Political signs. 
Political signs shall be permitted within any zoning district of the city, subject to the following restrictions and allowances: 
(1)  Political signs shall be allowed in a residential zoning district without a permit when such signs do not exceed 32 square feet in area. 
(2)  A political sign shall not be erected more than 90 days prior to the election which the sign is intended to influence; provided, that the nominee determined in a primary election shall not be required to remove a sign pending the determination of the general election. 
(3)  Any political sign shall be removed within ten days after the final election including any runoffs which the sign is intended to influence. 
(4)  Political signs located outside of commercial and manufacturing zoning districts shall not exceed 32 square feet in area. 
(5)  Political signs must be set back a minimum of ten feet from any public right-of-way. Political signs shall not be permitted to be attached to any street sign, any sign directing or controlling traffic, any pole or post supporting such signs, any utility pole or post, nor to any tree, shrub, or plant. 
(6)  Before any political sign is erected, the permission of the owner of the property upon which the sign is proposed to be erected must be obtained. 
(7)  A permit for political signs exceeding 32 square feet in area shall be required. 
(8)  Political signs shall not exceed 40 feet in height. 
(9)  The city is empowered to remove or cause to be removed all political signs not conforming with the provisions of this division without notice to the candidate whose sign creates the nonconformance. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Ord. No. 90-5-5, § I, 5-21-90; Code 1981, § 9-3029; Ord. No. 92-5-1, § I, 5-4-92) 
Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 12; zoning, ch. 23. 
Sec. 11-135. - Enforcement and administration. 
(a)  This division shall be administered and enforced by the building inspector or his designated representative. 
(b)  All administration and appeal procedures relative to this division shall be handled in accordance with procedures set forth in chapter 23; provided, however, that no variance shall be allowed for sign height or sign area. Variances for setback may be granted in cases of undue hardship concerning on-premises signs only. 
(c)  The building inspector may at his discretion issue sign permits where circumstances of unnecessary hardship or where community health, safety, and general welfare demand it. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Code 1981, § 9-3030) 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 11-136. - Remedies. 
In case any sign or other device covered by this division is or is proposed to be erected, constructed, altered, converted or used in violation of any provision of this division, the building inspector may, in addition to other remedies, and after due notice to the appropriate person, have issued a citation for violation of this Code requiring the presence of the violator in the municipal court; or institute injunction, or other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent such unlawful erection, construction, alteration, conversion, or use to correct or abate such violation. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Code 1981, § 9-3032) 
Sec. 11-137. - Penalties for violation. 
Any person violating any provisions of this division shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished in accordance with section 1-9. 
(Ord. No. 88-12-6, § 1, 12-19-88; Code 1981, § 9-3031) 
Secs. 11-138—11-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AUCTION, FIRE, BANKRUPT, ETC., SALES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 9. 
State Law reference— Uniform Deceptive Trade Practices Act, O.C.G.A. § 10-1-370 et seq.; Fair Business Practices Act of 1975, O.C.G.A. § 10-1-390 et seq.; misrepresenting ownership in advertising liquidation, auction or going-out-of-business sale, O.C.G.A. § 10-1-425. 

Sec. 11-161. - Fraudulent sales. 
(a)  Any person advertising by newspapers, radio, posters or otherwise, representing that he is operating, offering or maintaining "fire sales," "wreck sales," "bankrupt sales," "closing out or going out of business sales" and similar businesses, whereby the public are led to believe that they are being offered merchandise at reduced rates on account of fires, wrecks, bankruptcies, closing out or discontinuance of business, when in fact such sales are not bona fide, but are fakes and frauds, and the advertisement and representations are untrue and false, shall be held to be guilty of an offense and of a breach of orderly and proper conduct. 
(b)  Any business advertising that it is going out of business must actually go out of business within 120 days after the commencement of such advertising. 
(Code 1959, § 6-1; Code 1981, § 9-4001) 
Sec. 11-162. - Fire and bankrupt sales; adding unaffected or undamaged goods to stock prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person conducting any sale, whether by auction or otherwise, of any goods, wares or merchandise, which are or have been, or which are claimed to be or have been in or damaged by a fire, or which are or have been or which are claimed to be or have been sold or purchased on account of any fire, or which are or have been or are claimed to be or have been the property of any bankrupt or person who has failed in business or has made a general assignment, or which are being sold or offered for sale in any other way than through the usual channels of trade, to sell or offer for sale therein any goods, wares or merchandise not so circumstanced or affected or damaged, or to add to, or to permit to be added to, or to bring into or permit to be brought into any store, warehouse or other building in the city, any goods for the purpose of adding to those goods, wares or merchandise so circumstanced or affected and on hand in any such store, warehouse or other building for the purpose of being sold at such sale. 
(Code 1959, § 6-2; Code 1981, § 9-4002) 
Sec. 11-163. - False representation—Quality of goods. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent, by advertisement or otherwise, that the goods, wares or merchandise which such person offers for sale are of a certain brand or quality, or that the goods will be sold at a certain percentage of their cost price or value, and then sell goods, wares or merchandise of a brand or quality inferior to that or those represented or advertised, or sell such goods, wares or merchandise at a higher percentage of their cost value than that represented or advertised. 
(Code 1959, § 6-3; Code 1981, § 9-4003) 
Sec. 11-164. - Same—Quality of services or materials. 
It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in any business which includes the furnishing of services and materials in connection therewith, to represent falsely, by advertisement or otherwise, that any services, or any process involving the furnishing of services or material, or both services and material, which such person offers for sale are of a certain brand or quality recognized in such trade or business, and then, with intent to defraud, furnish services or materials of a brand or quality inferior to that so represented or advertised. 
(Code 1959, § 6-4; Code 1981, § 9-4004) 
Secs. 11-165—11-195. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PEDDLERS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 20. 
State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; transient merchants, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 11-196. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Peddler means any person, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling by foot, wagon, motor vehicle or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, carrying, conveying or transporting meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden truck, farm products or provisions, offering and exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers, or any person who, without traveling from place to place, shall sell or offer the same for sale from a wagon, motor vehicle, railroad car or other vehicle or conveyance. One who solicits orders and, as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this article, shall be deemed a peddler subject to the provisions of this article. The word "peddler" shall include the words "hawker" and "huckster." 
(Ord. No. 84-9-1, § 2, 9-4-84; Code 1981, § 9-6002) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 11-197. - Location. 
No peddler shall have any exclusive right to any location in the public streets, nor shall he be permitted a stationary location, nor shall he be permitted to operate in any congested area where his operations might impede or inconvenience the public. For the purpose of this article, the judgment of a police officer, exercised in good faith, shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public impeded or inconvenienced. 
(Ord. No. 84-9-1, § 6, 9-4-84; Code 1981, § 9-6006) 
Sec. 11-198. - Duties of police officers. 
It shall be the duty of any police officer of the city to require any person seen peddling, and who is not known by such officer to be duly licensed, to produce his peddler's license and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Ord. No. 84-9-1, § 8, 9-4-84; Code 1981, § 9-6008) 
Cross reference— Police, ch. 17. 
Sec. 11-199. - Reports of violations. 
The chief of police shall report to the secretary all convictions for violations of this article, and the secretary shall maintain a record for each license issued and reports of violations therein. 
(Ord. No. 84-9-1, § 9, 9-4-84; Code 1981, § 9-6009) 
Secs. 11-200—11-225. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 11-226. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of peddler within the corporate limits of the city, without first obtaining a license therefor as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 84-9-1, § 1, 9-4-84; Code 1981, § 9-6001) 
Sec. 11-227. - Application. 
Applicants for a license under this division must file with the secretary a sworn application on a form to be furnished by the secretary which shall give the following information: 
(1)  The name and description of the applicant. 
(2)  The address (legal and local) of the applicant. 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold. 
(4)  If the applicant is employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship. 
(5)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired. 
(6)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the same, together with license number or other means of identification. 
(7)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a felony, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. 
(Ord. No. 84-9-1, § 3, 9-4-84; Code 1981, § 9-6003) 
Sec. 11-228. - License fee; exception. 
(a)  The amount of the license fee shall be as set forth in the license fee schedule of the city as provided in section 8-36. 
(b)  No fee shall be required of a person selling products of the farm or orchard actually produced by the seller. 
(Ord. No. 84-9-1, § 4, 9-4-84; Code 1981, § 9-6004) 
Sec. 11-229. - Transfer. 
No license issued under the provisions of this division shall be used at any time by any person other than the one to whom it was issued. 
(Ord. No. 84-9-1, § 5, 9-4-84; Code 1981, § 9-6005) 
Sec. 11-230. - Exhibition. 
Peddlers shall exhibit their licenses at the request of any citizen. 
(Ord. No. 84-9-1, § 7, 9-4-84; Code 1981, § 9-6007) 
Secs. 11-231—11-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ITINERANT VENDORS[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; transient merchants, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 11-261. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Itinerant vendor means any person, whether a resident of the city or not, who has no permanent place of business within the city and who engages in a transient business in one temporary fixed place of business, or sells goods from a vehicle. The term "itinerant vendor" shall include the terms "traveling vendor" and "transient merchant." 
(Ord. No. 84-9-1, § 10, 9-4-84; Code 1981, § 9-6010(b)) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 11-262. - Enforcement; reports of violations. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of any police officer of the city to require any person seen peddling or vending, and who is not known by such officer to be duly licensed, to produce his license and his written permission from the owner to use the property for sales, and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the same. 
(b)  The chief of police shall report to the secretary all convictions for violations of this article, and the secretary shall maintain a record for each license issued and reports of violations therein. 
(Ord. No. 84-9-1, § 13, 9-4-84; Code 1981, § 9-6013) 
Cross reference— Police, ch. 17. 
Secs. 11-263—11-285. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 11-286. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of itinerant vendor within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a license therefor as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 84-9-1, § 10, 9-4-84; Code 1981, § 9-6010(a)) 
Sec. 11-287. - Application. 
Applicants for a license under this division must file with the secretary a sworn application in duplicate on a form to be furnished by the secretary which shall give the following information: 
(1)  The name and description of the applicant. 
(2)  The address (legal and local) of the applicant. 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold. 
(4)  If the applicant is employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship. 
(5)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired. 
(6)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the same, together with the license number or other means of identification. 
(7)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any felony, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. 
(8)  The applicant's state sales tax identification number. 
(9)  A copy of a written statement from the owner of the property proposed for the sales location. 
(Ord. No. 84-9-1, § 11, 9-4-84; Code 1981, § 9-6011) 
Sec. 11-288. - License fee; exhibition. 
(a)  The amount of the license fee shall be as set forth in the license fee schedule of the city as provided in section 8-36. 
(b)  No fee shall be required of a person selling products of the farm or orchard actually produced by the seller. 
(c)  The licensee shall exhibit his license in a conspicuous location in order that it can be viewed by the public. 
(Ord. No. 84-9-1, § 12, 9-4-84; Code 1981, § 9-6012) 
Secs. 11-289—11-310. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference— Charitable solicitations, O.C.G.A. § 43-17-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 11-311. - Unlawful acts. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to execute a registration under this article which contains any false statement, and it shall be unlawful for any person to solicit donations or contributions or sell any insignia or novelty on the streets of the city proportedly on behalf of or under the sponsorship of, any charitable, educational, religious, social, patriotic or civic club or organization which does not in fact exist or which has not been authorized to solicit pursuant to a permit issued under this article. 
(Code 1981, § 9-6027) 
Sec. 11-312. - Door-to-door and telephone solicitations; hours. 
No charitable solicitation door-to-door or by telephone shall be made before 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. 
(Code 1981, § 9-2029) 
Sec. 11-313. - Exemption. 
This article shall not apply to any locally established organization or church operated exclusively for charitable or religious purposes if the solicitations are in the form of collections or contributions at the regular assemblies of any such organization or church. 
(Code 1981, § 9-6025) 
Secs. 11-314—11-335. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 11-336. - Registration—Required. 
Any person who wishes to solicit donations or contributions for, or to sell any insignia or novelty on the streets of the city on behalf of, or under the sponsorship of, any charitable, educational, religious, social, patriotic or civic club or organization, shall register the activity with the secretary at least 48 hours in advance of the event and to obtain a permit therefor. 
(Code 1981, § 9-6021) 
Sec. 11-337. - Same—Form. 
The registration required by this article shall be in writing, shall be signed by an officer of the club or organization and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, headquarters address, phone number and object of the charitable, educational, religious, social, patriotic or civic club or organization conducting or sponsoring the solicitation or sale to which the registration relates. 
(2)  The days on which the solicitation or sale will take place. 
(3)  The purpose and object for which the funds to be derived from the solicitation or sale will be utilized. 
(4)  The name, address and telephone number of the chief officer of the club or organization in direct control of conducting or sponsoring the solicitation or sale and of the person preparing the registration form. 
(5)  Whether or not the club or organization, if not exempt under state law (O.C.G.A. § 43-17-9), has registered with the state. 
(6)  An outline of the methods to be used in conducting the solicitation or sale. 
(7)  The estimated cost of the solicitation or sale. 
(8)  The amount of any wages, fees, commissions, expenses or emoluments to be expended or paid to any persons in connection with the solicitation or sale and the name and addresses of all such persons. 
(9)  A statement to the effect that if a permit is granted, it will not be used or represented in any way as an endorsement by the city, or by any department or officer thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 9-6022) 
Sec. 11-338. - Fee. 
Before a permit is issued, there shall be paid to the city such a sum as set out in the fee schedule book of the city, as provided in section 8-36, and any additional fees as may be required for each facsimile copy of the permit that is desired. 
(Code 1981, § 9-6028) 
Sec. 11-339. - Issuance. 
The secretary shall issue the permit provided for in this division whenever he shall find the following facts to exist: 
(1)  That all of the statements made in the application are true. 
(2)  That the control and supervision of the solicitation will be adequate to prevent fraud and danger to the public and to the solicitors. 
(3)  That the applicant has not engaged in any fraudulent transaction or enterprise. 
(4)  That the solicitation will not be a fraud on the public. 
(5)  That the solicitation is to finance and promote the purpose or object described in the application and will not be conducted primarily for private profit. 
(Code 1981, § 9-6024) 
Sec. 11-340. - Exhibition. 
Solicitors shall carry on their person and exhibit their permits or copies thereof provided by the city at the request of any person. 
(Code 1981, § 9-6026) 
Sec. 11-341. - Transfer. 
No permit or badge issued under the provisions of this division shall be used or worn at any time by any person other than the person to whom it was issued. 
(Code 1981, § 9-6030) 
Sec. 11-342. - Time period. 
The permit under this division shall be valid only for the days on which the solicitation or sale will take place. 
(Code 1981, § 9-6023) 
Secs. 11-343—11-375. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 12; parking of taxicabs, § 12-249; taxicab stands, § 12-250. 
State Constitution reference— Municipal ambulance and emergency rescue services, art. IX, § II, par. III. 
State Law reference— Motor vehicle accident insurance, O.C.G.A. § 33-34-1 et seq.; liability of owner of leased vehicle, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-207; "proof of financial responsibility" defined, O.C.G.A. § 40-9-2(5); insurance for person renting U-drive-it vehicle, O.C.G.A. § 40-9-102. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 11-376. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Chauffeur's permit means written authority given by the chief of police pursuant to the provisions of this article to any person to drive or operate a taxicab on the public streets of the city. 
Permit means the written authority granted by the public safety committee of the city commission under this article to engage in the taxicab business in the city, as such business is defined by the provisions of this article. 
Taxicab means any motor-driven vehicle for transportation for hire of passengers and which is operated wholly or principally within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 31-1; Code 1981, § 9-8001) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 11-377. - License required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to carry on, engage in or conduct the business of operating taxicabs for the transportation of persons within the limits of the city without first having obtained a license from the city as provided in this article. 
(Code 1959, § 31-3; Code 1981, § 9-8003) 
Sec. 11-378. - Liability insurance—Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner, operator, driver or chauffeur of any taxicab to drive or operate the same on the public streets of the city unless such owner, operator, driver or chauffeur shall have first procured and filed with the secretary a liability insurance policy, issued by a good and responsible insurance company, or a surety bond issued by a good and responsible surety company, which insurance company or surety company must have authority to do business in the state and possess a certificate duly issued by the state which insurance company or surety company must be approved by the secretary. The amount of liability insurance or surety bond for each taxicab shall be as follows: 
(1)  An amount not less than $15,000.00 because of bodily injury to or death of one person in any one accident, and subject to such limit for one person, not less than $30,000.00 because of bodily injury to or death of two or more persons in any one accident, and not less than $10,000.00 because of injury to or destruction of property of others in any one accident. 
(2)  Ability to respond in compensation to certain injured individuals, without regard to fault, in an amount not less than $5,000.00 per injured person in compliance with the Georgia Motor Vehicle Accident Reparations Act (O.C.G.A. § 33-34-1 et seq.).
