The policy of insurance or surety bond may be in the form of a separate policy or separate surety bond for each taxicab, or may be in the form of a fleet policy covering all taxicabs operated by such owner, driver or chauffeur, in which latter event the policy of insurance or surety bond shall provide the same liability for each taxicab operated. Every taxicab while in service shall have conspicuously placed therein some sign evidencing the fact that the provisions of this section have been complied with, the form thereof to be prescribed by the secretary. 
(Code 1959, § 31-8; Code 1981, § 9-8008) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-9-2. 
Sec. 11-379. - Same—Cancellation. 
No policy of insurance or surety bond required in this division shall be canceled until the expiration of ten days' notice of intended cancellation thereof has been given in writing to the secretary by registered mail or personal delivery of the notice, and a provision therefor shall be made a part of the policy or surety bond. 
(Code 1959, § 31-9; Code 1981, § 9-8009) 
Sec. 11-380. - Taxicabs—Use for lewdness prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any driver of any taxicab operated in the city to permit any person to accompany or use such taxicab for the purpose of prostitution, lewdness or assignation, or to direct, take or transport or to offer or agree to direct, take or transport any other person with knowledge or reasonable cause to believe that the purpose of such directing, taking or transporting is for prostitution, lewdness or assignation. 
(Code 1959, § 31-16; Code 1981, § 9-8016) 
Sec. 11-381. - Same—Display of owner's name. 
It shall be unlawful for any taxicab to be driven or operated upon the streets of the city unless the name of the person either owning or operating the taxicab shall be conspicuously painted on the taxicab in letters not less than two inches in height. 
(Code 1959, § 31-17; Code 1981, § 9-8017) 
Sec. 11-382. - Same—Hours of operation. 
It shall be unlawful for any driver or operator of any taxicab to drive or operate the taxicab for more than 12 hours in any 24 hours. 
(Code 1959, § 31-18; Code 1981, § 9-8018) 
Sec. 11-383. - Rates—Schedule to be posted. 
It shall be unlawful for any person who is the owner, driver or operator of a taxicab to allow the taxicab to be operated upon the streets of the city or the police jurisdiction thereof, unless such taxicab has posted in a place clearly discernible and visible a schedule of rates for the transportation of persons within the corporate limits of the city and to and from the areas outside the corporate limits, and no charges shall be made for the transportation of persons in excess of the rates so posted. 
(Code 1959, §§ 31-19, 31-19.3; Ord. No. 79-14, § 1, 8-20-79; Code 1981, §§ 9-8019, 9-8022) 
Sec. 11-384. - Same—Reports. 
All persons licensed as required by section 11-377 shall report to the secretary in writing the rates for transportation of persons which such persons regularly charges. At least 15 days prior to any change in such rates, notice of the change shall be filed in writing with the secretary. 
(Code 1959, § 31-19.1; Ord. No. 79-14, § 2, 8-20-79; Code 1981, § 9-8020) 
Sec. 11-385. - Payment to be made at termination of trip; unlawful charges. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee under this article to charge any passenger a rate or fare greater than that rate on record in the office of the secretary as provided in this article. It shall be unlawful for any passenger to fail or refuse to pay any such lawful fare immediately upon termination of the employment, unless a later time of payment has been mutually agreed upon prior to employment. 
(Code 1959, § 31-19.2; Ord. No. 79-14, § 3, 8-20-79; Code 1981, § 9-8021) 
Sec. 11-386. - Additional engagement prohibited. 
No driver shall permit any person to occupy or ride in a taxicab other than the persons first employing or engaging the taxicab. 
(Code 1959, § 31-19.4; Code 1981, § 9-8023) 
Sec. 11-387. - Taximeters—Required in all taxicabs. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to own and operate or cause to be operated any taxicab in the city unless and until the taxicab shall be equipped with a practicable, standard taximeter in good and workable condition, designed to mechanically and accurately measure distance traveled, to record the time the vehicle is in waiting and upon which there shall be indicated by means of figures the fare charged. It shall be the duty of each person owning or operating a taxicab to keep the taximeter thereon in good and workable condition, and, at the beginning of every employment, to set the taximeter in the usual way so that it will register and compute on a mileage basis while the vehicle is running, and a time basis while waiting, and while the service is being rendered, show the fare to be charged. Any such taximeter shall be so placed that the fare thereof, where the fare is registered, will be well lighted and plainly visible to the passengers within the vehicle. 
(Code 1959, § 31-19.5; Code 1981, § 9-8024) 
Sec. 11-388. - Same—Flag, telltale lights and seal required. 
(a)  No driver of a taxicab, while carrying passengers, shall display the flag attached to the taximeter in a position to denote that the vehicle is not employed, or shall throw the flag of the taximeter into a recording position when the vehicle is not actually employed, or shall fail to throw the flag of the taximeter in a nonrecording position at the termination of every service. 
(b)  There shall be adequate telltale lights indicating that the taxicab is employed with the taximeter operating, or that it is unemployed with the taximeter not operating. 
(c)  Adequate provision shall be made for sealing all taximeters in such a manner that no adjustments, alterations or replacements affecting in any way the indications, the time or mileage rates or, in general, the accuracy of the taximeter, can be made without mutilating or destroying the seal. 
(Code 1959, § 31-19.6; Code 1981, § 9-8025) 
Sec. 11-389. - Terminals or stations required; parking on streets prohibited. 
All persons engaged in the taxicab business in the city shall have drive-in terminals or stations in which all vehicles shall be parked while not engaged in the actual transportation of passengers, and no such vehicle shall be parked on the streets of the city while not in actual use. 
(Code 1959, § 31-20; Code 1981, § 9-8026) 
Sec. 11-390. - Records of trips—Required. 
All persons operating taxicabs in the city shall keep a record of each trip made, which shall include the following: 
(1)  Mileage at the time the taxicab leaves the station. 
(2)  Mileage when it returns. 
(3)  All pickup trips must be recorded. 
(4)  Amount charged for the trip. 
(5)  Name of the driver of the taxicab. 
(6)  Number of the taxicab. 
(7)  Destination of the taxicab. 
(Code 1959, § 31-21; Code 1981, § 9-8027) 
Sec. 11-391. - Same—Responsibility for keeping. 
Each owner or operator of taxicabs in the city shall require each driver to keep the record described in section 11-390, and both the driver and the owner and operator failing or refusing to keep such record shall be guilty of violating this chapter and shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 1959, § 31-22; Code 1981, § 9-8028) 
Sec. 11-392. - Violation of laws—Duty to report. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to notify the secretary of any and all violations of any ordinances by any taxicab operator or chauffeur. 
(Code 1959, § 31-23; Code 1981, § 9-8029) 
Sec. 11-393. - Same—Hearing, suspension or revocation of permit. 
Whenever any person engaged in the taxicab business or any operator or driver of a taxicab within the city is found to be violating the provisions of this article or the laws of the state or any other law of the city, the public safety committee of the city commission may, upon complaint or upon its own motion, issue an order to such person to appear at a fixed time and place for investigation. If the public safety committee shall be satisfied, after such hearing, of the violation of the laws of the city or the state or any terms of any permit issued, the committee may suspend, for a fixed period in its discretion, or revoke, the permit. 
(Code 1959, § 31-24; Code 1981, § 9-8030) 
Secs. 11-394—11-415. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT TO OPERATE BUSINESS 

Sec. 11-416. - Operation subject to regulations; permit required. 
The operating of taxicabs within the city shall be subject to the conditions, regulations and restrictions set forth in this article, and it shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated in the city any taxicabs unless a permit for the operation thereof shall have been first issued by the secretary. 
(Code 1959, § 31-4; Code 1981, § 9-8004) 
Sec. 11-417. - Applications. 
Application for permits under this division shall be made to the secretary by a petition which shall set forth the name, address and place of business of the applicant, if an individual, and if a partnership the name and residence of each of the partners, and the place of business of the partnership, and if a corporation, the name and address of each of the officers of the corporation and the place of business of the corporation; the trade name under which the applicant does or proposes to do business; the name of the insurance company or surety company with which the applicant has made arrangements to secure his insurance or surety bond as required by this article; a financial statement of the company; and such other information as may be required by the secretary. 
(Code 1959, § 31-5; Code 1981, § 9-8005) 
Sec. 11-418. - Investigation of applicant. 
The secretary shall make or cause to be made an investigation including any hearing deemed necessary as to each application for permit for the operation of taxicabs. In determining whether a permit shall be issued, the secretary may investigate the fitness of the applicant to engage in the business of operating taxicabs and shall make or cause to be made an investigation in order to determine whether the demands of public convenience, necessity and safety justify the issuance of such permit. 
(Code 1959, § 31-6; Code 1981, § 9-8006) 
Sec. 11-419. - Issuance or denial; transfer. 
(a)  If the secretary determines to grant a permit for the operation of taxicabs, he shall issue the applicant a permit under this division, and such permit shall not be transferable except upon the consent of the secretary. If the secretary finds and decides that the public convenience, necessity and safety do not justify the issuance of the permit, or that the insurance company or surety company in which the applicant has made arrangements to secure insurance as required by the provisions of this article is not a good and responsible insurance or surety company, or that the provisions of the proposed policy or surety bond do not give ample protection to the public, or that the applicant is not a fit and proper person to conduct the taxicab business, then no permit shall be issued, and notice of the decision of the secretary shall be given to the applicant, setting forth the reason for the refusal of the permit. 
(b)  The applicant may appeal any decision of the secretary to the public safety committee by written request to the secretary, who will schedule a hearing before the public safety committee not later than 31 days after receipt of the written request. 
(Code 1959, § 31-7; Code 1981, § 9-8007) 
Secs. 11-420—11-450. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CHAUFFEUR'S PERMIT 

Sec. 11-451. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a taxicab upon the streets of the city unless such person shall have first obtained from the chief of police a chauffeur's permit, as set forth in this division. 
(Code 1959, § 31-10; Code 1981, § 9-8010) 
Sec. 11-452. - Eligibility, application, investigation, issuance and subsequent procedures. 
Any person having resided continuously in the city for not less than six months immediately preceding the making of application for a chauffeur's permit, being 18 years of age or over, may make an application with the chief of police for a chauffeur's permit. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make an investigation to determine the moral character and fitness of the applicant and the applicant's knowledge of the traffic laws of the city. It shall be the duty of the chief of police, if the applicant is a person of good moral character and fitness and possesses sufficient knowledge of the traffic laws of the city, to issue such person a written permit, which shall be signed by the chief of police, shall be sealed with the corporate seal of the city, and shall contain the name, address, sex, race, age and signature of the person. The chief of police shall procure or cause to be procured fingerprints and two photographs of the applicant; one of the photographs shall be retained by the chief of police for the files of the police department, and the other shall be attached to the chauffeur's permit, if the same shall be granted to the applicant. 
(Code 1959, § 31-11; Code 1981, § 9-8011) 
Sec. 11-453. - Destroying or defacing prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person holding a chauffeur's permit to deface, obliterate or destroy the same, or to cause same to be defaced, obliterated or destroyed. 
(Code 1959, § 31-12; Code 1981, § 9-8012) 
Sec. 11-454. - Display in taxicab. 
Every driver of any taxicab operated in the city shall have his chauffeur's permit displayed in the taxicab in a prominent place in the front thereof so as to be easily discernable by any person occupying the taxicab. 
(Code 1959, § 31-13; Code 1981, § 9-8013) 
Sec. 11-455. - Suspension; revocation. 
The public safety committee of the city commission, upon recommendation of the chief of police or upon the suggestion of the committee itself or one of its members, may suspend or revoke any chauffeur's permit issued by the chief of police, if upon investigation the committee shall find that the holder of the permit has violated any of the provisions of this article, has been convicted of a felony, or has been convicted of driving a taxicab or other motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquors, or if the person is suffering from a contagious or communicable disease or defect or impairment of vision, or if the person is not a person of good moral character and fitness; but before the permit shall be suspended or revoked by the committee, notice of intention thereof shall be served upon the person either by registered mail or by personal service. The person shall be given an opportunity to be heard, and the hearing shall be conducted by the committee. 
(Code 1959, § 31-14; Code 1981, § 9-8014) 
Sec. 11-456. - Renewal. 
Chauffeur's permits shall be renewed not later than the birth date of the permittee in each year. 
(Code 1959, § 31-15; Code 1981, § 9-8015) 
Secs. 11-457—11-475. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PUBLIC DEMONSTRATIONS; PARADES; RACES[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 20. 
State Law reference— Preventing or disrupting processions, meetings, etc., O.C.G.A. § 16-11-34; operation of motor vehicles in parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-7. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 11-476. - Bikeathons, walkathons, running road races, etc. 
No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form, or start any bikeathon, walkathon, running road race, or other organized event of similar import on any major thoroughfare or bridge in the city. For the purposes of this section, major thoroughfares in the city shall be as follows: 
(1)  U.S. route no. 27 and U.S. route no. 411. 
(2)  State route no. 1, state route no. 20, state route no. 53, state route no. 101, state route no. 293, and state route no. 703. 
(3)  The Second Avenue bridge at the Oostanaula River, the Turner-McCall Boulevard bridge at the Oostanaula River, the Turner-McCall Boulevard bridge at the Etowah River, the East Second Avenue bridge at the Etowah River, the South Broad Street bridge at the Etowah River, and the North Fifth Avenue bridge at the Oostanaula River. 
(4)  Turner-McCall Boulevard from Martha Berry Boulevard to the city limits, Martha Berry Boulevard from Turner-McCall Boulevard to the city limits, Shorter Avenue from Martha Berry Boulevard to the city limits, Broad Street from the Etowah River to East First Street, North Broad Street from East First Street to the city limits, East First Street from North Broad Street to the city limits, Riverbend Drive from Turner-McCall Boulevard to East Second Avenue, North Fifth Avenue from Broad Street to Martha Berry Boulevard, and Calhoun Avenue from North Broad Street to the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 81-2-2, § 1, 2-2-81; Code 1981, § 9-7040) 
Secs. 11-477—11-500. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ASSEMBLIES ON CITY STREETS, SIDEWALKS, PARKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2009-4-2, § II, adopted April 6, 2009, repealed former Art. IX, Div. 2, §§ 11-501—11-511, and enacted a new Div. 2 as set out herein. Former Div. 2 pertained to pickets; demonstrations; assemblies and derived from Code 1959, §§ 23A-1—23A-11 and Code 1981, §§ 9-7001—9-7011. 
Cross reference— Streets and sidewalks, ch. 20. 

Sec. 11-501. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Assembly means any outdoor event, regardless of the number of participants, which meets the following definition: 
(1)  Any demonstration, rally, protest, march, parade, motorcade, procession of any kind, or similar display, consisting of persons, animals, or vehicles, or a combination thereof, having a common purpose, design, destination, or goal, which does not fit into the exclusions set forth in subsection (2) below: 
(2)  The following events or occurrences shall not be deemed to be an assembly: 
a.  Funeral processions, or 
b.  Students going to and from school classes or participating in education classes, provided this conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities, or 
c.  An event or occurrence sponsored by a governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions, or 
d.  A family gathering. 
(Ord. No. 2009-4-2, § II, 4-6-09; Ord. No. 2017-9-1, § I, 9-25-17) 
Sec. 11-502. - Assembly permit. 
No person shall, without first being permitted by the chief of police or his/her appointed designee ("permitting officer") after application made according to the requirements set out hereinafter, conduct, engage in, participate in, aid, form, or start an assembly: 
(1)  In any city building, structure, parking lot, recreational facility, or square, or 
(2)  Upon any street, sidewalk, park, or public right-of-way in the city which requires the temporary closing or obstruction of all or a portion of any city street, sidewalk, park, or public right-of-way, or 
(3)  Upon any street, sidewalk, public right-of-way, or any other city property involving a motorized vehicle, or 
(4)  Upon any street, sidewalk, public right-of-way, or any other city property involving the use of any electronic sound amplification system (other than a radio or recorder or other device which is possessed and used by an individual for his/her own enjoyment and is operated in such a manner so as to not interfere with the use and enjoyment of any other person). 
(Ord. No. 2009-4-2, § II, 4-6-09; Ord. No. 2017-9-1, § II, 9-25-17) 
Sec. 11-503. - Permit application. 
(a)  An applicant seeking the issuance of an assembly permit shall file an application with the Rome City Chief of Police. Application forms are available at the police office located at 5 Government Plaza, Suite 300, Rome, Georgia 30161. An assembly permit shall be effective for thirty days from the date on which it is issued, but only for the dates and times explicitly denoted in the permit application and approved by the permitting office. 
(b)  Applications for assembly permits must be filed with the permitting officer not less than four days before the date on which the proposed assembly is to occur. A ten dollar nonrefundable application fee must be paid at the time of filing the application. 
(c)  Applications for assembly permits shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such assembly. 
(2)  If the assembly is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address, and telephone number of the organization's headquarters and the authorized and responsible heads of such organization. 
(3)  If the assembly is to be held by, on behalf of, or for any person other than the applicant, the applicant shall file, in addition to the assembly permit application, a written authorization from such person authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on their behalf. 
(4)  The name, address, and telephone number of the person who will be present at the assembly at all times and who will be responsible for the assembly and the conduct of its participants ("designee"). 
(5)  The date or dates of the assembly. 
(6)  The hours when the assembly will start and end. 
(7)  The exact location of the assembly, or if the assembly is processional or mobile, the specific rouse to be traveled. 
(8)  The approximate number of persons, animals, and vehicles which will constitute the assembly, the type of animals and a description of the number and types of vehicles to be used during the assembly. 
(9)  Whether sound amplification equipment will be employed, and, if so, a description of the equipment to be used sufficient to allow the permitting officer to evaluate the application. 
(10)  Whether artificial lighting will be employed and, if so, a description of the equipment to be used sufficient to allow the permitting officer to evaluate the application. 
(11)  Whether any temporary static structures will be constructed or employed, and if so, a description of the number and type of such structures sufficient to allow the permitting officer to evaluate the application. 
(12)  A description of the anticipated need for safety, police, medical, sanitation, and other required personnel or equipment. 
(13)  Whether any sign, display, flag, placard, or banner larger than three feet by three feet, or composed, in whole or in part, of wood, metal, or a hard plastic material, and if so, the anticipated number thereof. 
(14)  A disclosure as to whether the applicant or any entity for whom the application is being made is, or has been, a party to any legal action, criminal, civil, or administrative, arising out of any event of a nature substantially similar to the one proposed in the application. And, if so, a brief factual summary, including the date and location, of any such events. 
(Ord. No. 2009-4-2, § II, 4-6-09; Ord. No. 2017-9-1, § III, 9-25-17) 
Sec. 11-504. - Review of application. 
(a)  It is the intent of the City of Rome in enacting this division to reasonably regulate only the time, place, and manner of such assemblies and not to unduly burden, suppress, or regulate the content or message of any speech or expressive conduct contained therein. In furtherance of this intent: 
(1)  No permit shall be denied nor shall the applicant be given less favorable treatment as to the time, place, and manner of an assembly, on account of the race, color, creed, religion, gender, domestic relationship status, parental status, familial status, sexual orientation, national origin, political affiliation, or gender identity of the applicant and/or participants of the assembly. 
(2)  No permit shall denied nor shall the applicant be given less favorable treatment as to the time, place, and manner of an assembly, based upon the message of the assembly, the content of speech of the assembly, nor based on the identity or associational relationships of the applicant and/or participants. 
(3)  Nothing above withstanding, reasonable accommodation as to time, place, and manner may be required in order for the city to ensure and preserve the rights and liberties of its citizens and the safety, health, and good order of its society. 
(b)  Within four working days of the receipt of a fully completed, executed, and filed application, the permitting officer shall review the application in light of the goals set forth above and the considerations provided below, and render a decision to grant or deny, in whole or in part, the application for an assembly permit. If the permit is denied in whole or in part, the permitting officer shall provide a written statement of the reasons for said denial to the applicant. Such written statement of denial shall be postmarked no later than four working days after receipt of a fully completed, executed, and filed application. 
If the permitting officer modifies the plans for the assembly as set forth in the application, an assembly permit shall be issued to the applicant only upon the applicant's written acceptance of the permitting officer's modifications. 
(Ord. No. 2009-4-2, § II, 4-6-09) 
Sec. 11-505. - Denial or revocation of permit. 
The City of Rome Chief of Police, or his/her designees, may deny an assembly permit, or revoke a previously granted assembly permit, for any of the following considerations or a combination thereof: 
(1)  The application does not contain all of the required information or materials, or the information is so incomplete, vague, or ambiguous as to prevent a meaningful review by the permitting officer. 
(2)  The application contains material omissions, falsehoods, or misrepresentations. 
(3)  The applicant lacks authority to represent the entity for which the application is being made. 
(4)  The applicant or entity for which the permit is sought has on prior occasions substantially damaged city streets, sidewalks, parks, and/or other city real or personal property. 
(5)  The applicant or entity for which the permit is sought has on prior occasions materially violated permitting ordinances in connection with events of a substantially similar nature. 
(6)  If the assembly is being held for an unlawful purpose, and/or violates a federal, state, or local law or ordinance. 
(7)  The assembly would conflict with previously planned programs or events organized by the City of Rome and previously scheduled for substantially the same time and place. 
(8)  A fully executed prior application for an assembly permit has been granted to a prior applicant authorizing uses or activities which do not reasonably permit multiple occupancy of that particular space. 
(9)  When, due to the scope of the assembly and the number of police, safety, or city personnel required to provide protection and traffic control for the assembly, and due to the need for police, safety, or city personnel elsewhere in the city, the assembly would require the diversion of such a number of police, safety, or city personnel that it will be more likely than not that normal police and safety protection elsewhere in the city cannot be provided continuously and safely for the duration of the assembly. 
(10)  The assembly as proposed is likely to present an unreasonable danger to the health or safety of participants in the assembly or other members of the public (though not through the agency of any predicted reaction by onlookers or members of the public). 
(11)  The assembly as proposed is likely to substantially restrict and/or congest traffic (vehicular or pedestrian) on any of the public roads, rights-of-way, sidewalks, or waterways in the immediate vicinity of such assembly. 
(12)  Due to the city's substantial and compelling interest in ensuring the health and safety of its citizens, a permit may be denied and an assembly may be terminated for public safety reasons by the chief of police and/or the fire chief. 
(Ord. No. 2009-4-2, § II, 4-6-09) 
Sec. 11-506. - Appeals. 
(a)  Upon receipt of any decision by the permitting officer denying an application, the applicant may, within four business days, file a written notice of appeal with the secretary of the city manager. 
(b)  Such appeal shall succinctly state the grounds upon which it is asserted that the determination by the permitting officer should be modified or reversed. The applicant must attach a copy of the application and the permitting officer's letter of denial or modification to their written appeal. 
(c)  The city manager shall act upon the appeal within ten days after its receipt. Within three business days of the city manager's decision to affirm, modify, or reverse the permitting officer's decision, the city manager shall send a written notice its decision to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2009-4-2, § II, 4-6-09) 
Sec. 11-507. - Prohibited conduct during assemblies. 
Regardless of whether an assembly permit is required, or has been obtained, the following conduct shall not be permitted during any assembly: 
(1)  No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct, impede, or interfere with any assembly, or with any person, vehicle, or animal participating in or used in an assembly. 
(2)  No driver or vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising an assembly when the vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as an assembly, unless specifically authorized to do so by Rome City Police Department personnel. 
(3)  No person shall carry or possess glass bottles, glass jars, glass containers of any kind, bricks, stones, rocks, pieces of asphalt, or concrete, or any other type of weapon, including but not limited to: any air rifle, air pistol, paintball gun, paintball rifle, explosive, blasting cap, knife, hatchet, ax, slingshot, blackjack, metal knuckles, mace, iron buckle, ax handle, chains, crowbar, hammer, or any club, bludgeon or any other instrumentality used, or intended to be used, as a dangerous weapon. 
(4)  No person shall carry, possess, or assemble, any sign, display, flag, placard, or banner larger than three feet by three feet, or composed, in whole or in part, of wood, metal, or a hard plastic material, unless said sign, display, flag, placard, or banner has been approved by the permitting officer prior to it being use during an assembly. No sign, display, flag, placard, or banner may be draped or affixed to any City of Rome property, including, but not limited to, the streets, sidewalks, trees, buildings, or any other property of the city. 
(5)  No electronic sound amplification equipment shall used or employed during an assembly (except for a radio or recorder or other device which is possessed and used by an individual for his/her own enjoyment and is operated in such a manner so as to not interfere with the use and enjoyment of any other person), unless prior authorization from the permitting officer is obtained. 
(6)  No vehicles shall be used in an assembly, unless prior authorization from the permitting officer is obtained. 
(7)  No person shall violate the terms of their assembly permit or deviate from the approved information submitted in the application for the permit, if the assembly is such that a permit is required. 
(8)  No person engaged in, participating in, conducting, attending, or observing an assembly shall violate any federal, state, or local law or ordinance. 
(9)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit a disabled person from carrying, possessing or using a wheelchair, cane, walker, or similar device necessary for providing mobility so that person may participate in an assembly. 
(Ord. No. 2009-4-2, § II, 4-6-09) 
Sec. 11-508. - Retention of permit. 
The assembly designee shall be present during the entire assembly, and shall carry the assembly permit during the entire assembly, including set-up and break-down. Upon request, the designee shall provide the assembly permit to any City of Rome personnel during the assembly. 
(Ord. No. 2009-4-2, § II, 4-6-09) 
Sec. 11-509. - Compliance. 
The applicant, designee, and all assembly participants shall comply with all of the permit terms, directions, and conditions, and with all applicable laws and sections of this division and other ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2009-4-2, § II, 4-6-09) 
Sec. 11-510. - Penalty for violation of division. 
Any person violating this division shall, upon conviction in the municipal court, be punished according to the provisions of section 1-9. 
(Ord. No. 2009-4-2, § II, 4-6-09) 
Secs. 11-511—11-519. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RESIDENTIAL PICKETING[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2009-4-2, § II, adopted April 6, 2009, repealed former Art. IX, Div. 3, §§ 11-531—11-570. Former Div. 3 pertained to parades and derived from Code 1959, §§ 23A-12, 23A-14—23A-26 and Code 1981, §§ 9-7021—9-7035. 

Sec. 11-520. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Residential picketing means: 
(1)  To patrol or station oneself upon, before, or immediately about an individual residence, bearing some insignia or sign designed to persuade or protest; or 
(2)  Staging a public or private protest of any kind upon, before, or immediately about an individual residence; or 
(3)  Obstructing passage to or from an individual residence; or 
(4)  Promoting a strike or a boycott upon, before, or immediately about an individual residence. 
Individual residence means a single-family dwelling or a single duplex dwelling, but shall not mean a multifamily dwelling such as an apartment, condominium, townhome complex. 
(Ord. No. 2009-4-3, § I, 4-6-09) 
Sec. 11-521. - Prohibited conduct. 
In order to protect the public health, welfare, and good order of the city, and to ensure that every citizen has the opportunity to experience peace, well-being and privacy in their homes, it shall be unlawful for any person to engage in residential picketing. 
(Ord. No. 2009-4-3, § I, 4-6-09) 
Sec. 11-522. - Penalty. 
Any person who is found guilty of violating this section shall be penalized as provided in section 1-9. 
(Ord. No. 2009-4-3, § I, 4-6-09) 
Secs. 11-523—11-600. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - FRANCHISES[13] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Diversion of utility service, § 14-17; utilities, ch. 22. 
State Law reference— Municipal franchises, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2(7); avoiding charges for cable television service, etc., O.C.G.A. § 46-5-2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 11-601—11-625. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TELESCRIPPS CABLE COMPANY 

Sec. 11-626. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Cable television means a system of transmitting audio and video signals and electrical impulses. 
Gross revenues means all billed revenues, minus bad debts, in whatever form and from whatever source, received by the company or by any associate or subsidiary of the company from operations of the cable TV system or service within the city. It is intended that revenues shall be included in the computation if received by the company, regardless of changes in transmission means, in technology or in programming, so long as the revenues are derived from the provision of cable TV services. 
(Ord. No. 89-2-2, §§ II, VII, 2-20-89) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 11-627. - Rights granted. 
In consideration of the faithful performance and observance of the conditions and reservations specified in this division, the nonexclusive right is hereby granted to TeleScripps Cable Company, its successors and assigns (referred to in this division as the "company") to erect, maintain, and operate television transmission and distribution facilities and additions thereto in, under, over, along, across, and upon the streets, lanes, avenues, sidewalks, bridges, alleys and other public places in the city and subsequent additions thereto, for the purpose of transmission and distribution of television impulses, both community antenna and closed circuit, in accordance with the laws and regulations of the United States of America and the state and the ordinances and regulations of the city, for a period of 20 years, with the option of a 20-year extension, subject to agreement of terms. The intent of the parties is to comply with the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984. 
(Ord. No. 89-2-2, § I, 2-20-89) 
Sec. 11-628. - Use of poles generally. 
The poles currently used for the company's distribution system are those of the Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Georgia Power Company, and others when and where practical, including poles of the company where necessary, provided that mutually satisfactory agreement for attachment can be entered into with such companies. 
(Ord. No. 89-2-2, § III, 2-20-89) 
Sec. 11-629. - Location, construction, and maintenance of system. 
(a)  The company's transmission and distribution system, poles, wires, and appurtenances shall be located, erected and maintained so as not to endanger or interfere with the lives of persons, or to interfere with any improvements the city may deem proper to make, or hinder unnecessarily in the opinion of the city commissioners or their designated agents, or obstruct the free use of the streets, alleys, bridges or other public property. 
(b)  The matter of height of lines and the placement of the same on poles shall be subject to the direction of the electrical inspector of the city. 
(c)  Construction and maintenance of the transmission and distribution system, including house connections, shall be in accordance with the provisions of the National Electrical Safety Code, prepared by the National Bureau of Standards, the National Electrical Code of the National Fire Protection Association, and such applicable ordinances and regulations of the city affecting electrical installations which may be presently in effect or may be enacted by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 89-2-2, § IV, 2-20-89) 
Sec. 11-630. - Streets and public places; openings; obstructions; improvements. 
(a)  In the maintenance and operation of its television transmission and distribution system in the streets and alleys, and in the course of any new construction or addition to its facilities, the company shall proceed so as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the general public; any opening or obstruction in the streets or other public places made by the company in the course of its operations shall be guarded and protected at all times by the placement of adequate barriers, fences or boardings, the bounds of which during periods of dusk and darkness shall be clearly designated by appropriate warning lights. Any openings in streets shall be temporarily covered to the extent practical, without impeding the work progress, to minimize the public inconvenience. 
(b)  Whenever the company shall take up or disturb any pavement, sidewalk, or other improvement of any street, avenue, alley or other public place, a permit must first be obtained from the director of public works. The same shall be replaced and the surface restored in as good condition as before entry within 48 hours after completion of the company's work. Upon failure of the company to make such restoration within such time, or if the restoration cannot be made within such time, to begin the restoration within such time, or upon the company's delay of more than 24 hours in the continuation of a restoration begun, the city may serve upon the company notice of the city's intent to cause the restoration to be made, and the city may, unless the company within 24 hours after receipt of such notice begins or resumes the proper restoration, cause the proper restoration to be made, including the removal of excess dirt, and the expense of the same shall be paid by the company upon demand of the city. 
(c)  The company shall at all times comply with any and all rules and regulations which the city commission has made or may make applying to the public generally with reference to the removal or replacement of pavements and to excavations in streets and other public places, not inconsistent with their use for the purposes contemplated by this division. 
(Ord. No. 89-2-2, § V, 2-20-89) 
Sec. 11-631. - Service to be furnished. 
The company shall furnish to its subscribers a service capable of providing 12 channels, beginning with a minimum of eight channels. The company shall provide such additional channels as deemed feasible and practical, so long as this does not conflict with rules and regulations of the Federal Communication Commission and other public service programs already scheduled. Upon request, the company shall furnish the use of a channel (but not equipment) to be shared by the city government and by the county government; however, the company may utilize such channel at such times as it is not used by either the city or the county. The company shall also furnish basic service from the CATV system free of charge to each public school, police station, firehouse and municipal building, now or hereafter located in the city, which is located upon a street upon which the service shall exist; provided the utility companies have made space available for the company's cable. Where multiple service in these public buildings is required, the company shall provide, at cost, necessary distribution equipment and materials, but is not expected to install inside wiring for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 89-2-2, § VI, 2-20-89) 
Sec. 11-632. - Franchise fee. 
(a)  The company shall pay to the city as a franchise fee during each calendar year during the existence of the franchise a sum of money determined as follows: 
(1)  January 1, 1988, through December 31, 1989, 3.5% of gross revenues. 
(2)  January 1, 1990, through December 31, 1991, 4.0% of gross revenues. 
(3)  January 1, 1992, through December 31, 1993, 4.5% of gross revenues. 
(4)  January 1, 1994, through December 31, 2007, 5.0% of gross revenues. 
(b)  The company shall not be required to pay any city business license fee or tax, except ad valorem taxes. 
(c)  Payments shall be made annually and shall be accompanied by a warranty from the company that the statement of gross revenues derived by the company from the operation of the system is true and correct. The city may require, at any time, an audit of revenue figures for the immediately prior year. Audits of other years may be required if material error is found in the current audit. 
(Ord. No. 89-2-2, § VII, 2-20-89) 
Sec. 11-633. - Conformance to requirements of Federal Communications Commission. 
The company's distribution system shall conform to the requirements of the Federal Communications Commission, particularly with respect to freedom from spurious radiation. 
(Ord. No. 89-2-2, § VIII, 2-20-89) 
Sec. 11-634. - Service to be provided; duration. 
The company shall provide cable television service to the city as contemplated and provided for by this division until the termination of this division. 
(Ord. No. 89-2-2, § IX, 2-20-89) 
Sec. 11-635. - Claims for injury or damages; indemnification; insurance; defense of proceeding against city. 
(a)  The company shall indemnify and hold the city harmless at all times during the term of this grant from and against all claims for injury or damages to persons or property both real and personal caused by the construction, erection, operation or maintenance of any structure, equipment, appliance or products authorized or used pursuant to authority of this division. 
(b)  The company shall carry insurance in such form and in such companies that are licensed to do business in the state to protect the city and itself from and against any and all claims for injury or damages to persons or property, both real and personal, caused by the construction, erection, operation or maintenance of any structure, equipment, appliance or products authorized or used pursuant to authority of this division. The amount of such insurance against liability due to damage to property shall be not less than $150,000.00 as to any one person and $250,000.00 as to any one accident, and against the liability due to injury or death of persons the amount of such insurance shall not be less than $500,000.00 as to any one person and $1,000,000.00 as to any one accident. 
(c)  The company, upon receipt of due notice in writing from the city, shall defend at its own expense, or cause the same to be done, proceedings against the city in which it is claimed that the injury or damage arose from the company's activities in the operation of its television system. 
(Ord. No. 89-2-2, § X, 2-20-89) 
Sec. 11-636. - Rights and duties upon termination or forfeiture of franchise. 
(a)  Upon termination or forfeiture of this grant in accordance with any of its terms, the company may sell its cables, wires and appliances and business to any person or persons entitled to operate a cable television system in the city. If the company does not sell such assets within a reasonable time, the company will, upon reasonable written request therefor, undertake to remove its cables, wires and appliances from the city streets, lanes, sidewalks, alleys, bridges, highways, and other public places within the city and subsequent additions thereto in sufficient time to make available the poles (referred to in section 11-628 and used by the company) for use by any person or persons entitled to operate a cable television system in the city, as such person or persons proceed to use such poles. 
(b)  In the event of the failure of the company to perform the obligations of this section, the city shall have the right to make a written demand on the company to proceed to carry out the removal of such equipment within 30 days from the date of such demand. Upon a failure of the company to proceed with such a removal expeditiously, the city shall have the right to remove the same and retain it as the city's property without accounting therefor to the company, and the expense of such removal shall be charged to and paid by the company after giving credit for the value, if any, of the equipment removed by the city. 
(Ord. No. 89-2-2, § XI, 2-20-89) 
Sec. 11-637. - Right of city to revoke franchise on default of company. 
If the company shall fail to comply with any of the provisions of this grant, or default in any of its obligations, as provided for in section 11-634, and shall fail, within 75 days after written notice from the city to correct such default or noncompliance, the city commission shall have the right to revoke this division, and all rights of the company hereunder, unless and until such failure or default shall be so corrected. 
(Ord. No. 89-2-2, § XII, 2-20-89) 
Sec. 11-638. - Assignment, transfer, or sublease of franchise limited. 
The company shall not assign, transfer or sublet the privilege granted in this division and will not sell such privilege without the prior consent in writing of the city commission; provided, however, that a mortgage, lien, deed to secure debt, security interest or other encumbrances of such privilege as a part of acquiring, constructing, equipping or maintaining CATV systems shall not be considered a violation of this section, and any such creditor shall be entitled to all the rights and remedies granted to the same in any documents relating to such a transaction, including, without limitation, a foreclosure or voluntary conveyance to the creditor or assigns and any subsequent sale or other disposition of the security referred to in any such documents without such consent. 
(Ord. No. 89-2-2, § XIV, 2-20-89) 
Sec. 11-639. - Franchise fee on sale of franchise. 
If the company should sell a controlling interest in the privilege under this division after receiving consent thereto to the extent required by section 11-638, the company shall pay to the city the sum of $50,000.00 as a retroactive franchise fee due to the city in the year in which any such sale takes place, provided that such payment does not cause the total franchise fee for that year to exceed five percent of gross revenue. 
(Ord. No. 89-2-2, § XV, 2-20-89) 
Secs. 11-640—11-649. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - PAWNSHOPS AND PAWNBROKERS 

Sec. 11-650. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Employee means any person who works in a pawnshop, whether on a part-time or full-time basis, regardless of whether remuneration is received or not. 
Pawnbroker means any person who works in a pawnshop in the capacity of manager or owner or both. 
Pawnshop means any business that takes or receives by way of pledge, pawn or exchange, any goods, wares, merchandise or personal property of any kind as security for the repayment of money lent thereon. 
Pawn or pledge means a bailment of personal property as security for any debt or engagement redeemable upon certain terms and with the implied power of sale or default. 
(Ord. No. 99-5-2, § I, 5-12-99) 
State Law reference— Pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. §§ 44-12-130 et seq. 
Sec. 11-651. - Responsibility for enforcement. 
The city police department shall see that the provisions of this article are observed and enforced. 
(Ord. No. 99-5-2, § I, 5-12-99) 
Sec. 11-652. - Employees. 
No person shall be an employee of a pawnshop in any capacity until such person has been fingerprinted by the public safety department and has been issued an annual permit authorizing such person to be employed by a pawnshop. It shall be the duty of the pawnbroker to assure that there is compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 99-5-2, § I, 5-12-99) 
Sec. 11-653. - Character of person connected with pawn business. 
No owner, employee, pawnbroker or any person connected with a pawnshop for which a license or permit is sought shall have been convicted of a crime involving "moral turpitude" or shall have been convicted of any crime involving felony theft, burglary, robbery, or a violation of the "Family Violence Act." 
(Ord. No. 99-5-2, § I, 5-12-99) 
Sec. 11-654. - Annual permit. 
Before operating a pawnshop or becoming an employee of a pawnshop, any person must first file an application with the city police department for a permit to operate or be employed in the pawnshop, pursuant to the following: 
(1)  The application shall be made on an annual basis; 
(2)  No permit shall be issued until a fee in an amount established by action of the city board of commissioners, a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, is paid to the city; 
(3)  The application shall state the address of the pawnshop; 
(4)  The application shall contain the full name, address, phone number, date of birth and Social Security Number of any employee or pawnbroker; 
(5)  The chief of police or any other officer of the city designated by the city commissioners, shall investigate each applicant for such license and shall report to the city board of commissioners whether such applicant is a person of good character and has not been convicted of a criminal offense an indicated in this section. 
(Ord. No. 99-5-2, § I, 5-12-99) 
Sec. 11-655. - Records of transactions. 
(a)  Every pawnbroker shall maintain a permanent electronic record of its pawn transactions in which an accurate description of all property pledged, traded or sold to the pawnshop can be transmitted to the city police department via an electronic automated reporting system. Each of these transactions shall contain an accurate description of all property pledged, traded or sold to the pawnshop and shall be made at the time of each transaction, provided that the following information is included: 
(1)  The date and time of the purchase, pawn or sale of the property. 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of the customer making the pledge, trade or sale. 
(3)  A description of the customer in terms of sex, race, date of birth, height and weight, as well as the driver's license number of the customer or some other identification card which contains a photograph of the customer. 
(4)  A description of the pledged or purchased property by serial, model or other number, if available, and by any identifying marks (e.g., brand name, color, style, etc.) 
(5)  The number of the receipt or pawn transaction issued for the property pawned or bought. 
(6)  The price paid or the amount loaned. 
(7)  The maturity date of the transaction, if a pawn. 
(8)  A photograph of the customer and the item pawned or bought which will be taken with the electronic automated reporting system at the time of the transaction. 
(9)  The signature of the customer. 
(b)  Every pawnshop shall enter each transaction as it occurs into the electronic automated reporting system or may elect to upload electronically via the internet a batch file of all transactions for each business day to the administrator of the electronic automated reporting system immediately at the conclusion of each business day. The administrator of the electronic automated reporting system will electronically transmit all transactions to the city police department. 
(c)  In the event that the electronic automated reporting system becomes temporarily or permanently disabled, pawnshops and pawnbrokers will be notified as soon as possible. In this event, the pawnbrokers will be required to make records of transactions in paper form. Such paper forms must include all information as enumerated in paragraph (a) of this Code Section. Pawnbrokers shall maintain a three-day supply of these paper forms. 
(d)  Any duly authorized law enforcement officer may, during the ordinary hours of business or any other reasonable time, inspect any pawnbroker's electronic records at the pawnbroker's place of business to ensure compliance with this section. 
(e)  The chief of police or his designee shall select and designate the required automated reporting system. There will be a fee assessed to the pawnshop for each reported transaction; said fee shall be set forth in the fee schedule book of the city as provided in section 8-36. This fee will be invoiced to the pawnbroker and collected by the chief of police or his designee, which may be a third party administrator of the automated reporting system. 
(Ord. No. 99-5-2, § I, 5-12-99; Ord. No. 06-9-2, § I, 9-5-06) 
Editor's note— Section II of Ord. No. 2006-9-2 provides for an effective date of Dec. 1, 2006. 
State Law reference— O.C.G.A. §§ 44-12-132, 44-12-133 et seq. 
Sec. 11-656. - Waiting period for disposal of articles. 
Any pawnbroker or employee of a pawnshop who makes a loan on pledged goods, or buys pledged goods on the condition that the seller may repurchase said goods, shall hold said goods for at least 30 days before disposing of them by sale, transfer, shipment or otherwise. Nonpledged goods bought under this section shall be held for at least seven calendar days before disposing of them by sale, transfer, shipment or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 99-5-2, § I, 5-12-99) 
State Law reference— O.C.G.A. § 44-12-138 
Sec. 11-657. - Dealing with minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker or employee of a pawnshop to receive goods in pawn, trade, purchase or sale from a person under 18 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 99-5-2, § I, 5-12-99) 
State Law reference— O.C.G.A. § 44-12-137 
Sec. 11-658. - Lost or stolen items. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every person operating or employed by a pawnbroker's license or permit, to report to the chief of police or his duly authorized agent any article or goods sold or pawned to him if he shall have a reason to believe that the article or goods was stolen or lost when presented by seller or customer. 
(b)  With respect to any items which would normally have a serial number or other means of identification, if any pawnbroker or employee of a pawnshop becomes aware that such items have had the identification removed, defaced or destroyed, such fact shall be immediately reported to the chief of police or his duly authorized agent. 
(c)  If it is determined that an item bought, sold, traded or pawned by a seller or customer to the pawnbroker or his employee is the subject of any reported theft, then the surrender of said item to the chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall be done upon demand. 
(Ord. No. 99-5-2, § I, 5-12-99) 
Sec. 11-659. - Violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker or employee of a pawnshop to violate any of the provisions of this article, whether or not such person or employee is the holder of a current valid permit issued according to the terms of this article. Further, any person failing to comply with any provision of this article or other rules, ordinances and regulations as may be passed by the city board of commissioners for conduct of the business of a pawnbroker, shall upon conviction, have the license to conduct business revoked. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker or employee of a pawnshop to: 
(1)  Make any false statement in an application for any permit provided for in this article. 
(2)  Make any false entry in any record book, ledger or form required by the terms of this article. 
(3)  Violate any criminal law of this state while acting in the course of business as a pawnbroker or employee of a pawnbroker. 
(c)  Persons who violate this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 99-5-2, § I, 5-12-99) 
State Law reference— O.C.G.A. § 44-12-137. 
Secs. 11-660—11-699. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - BUSINESS IMPROVEMENT DISTRICT 

Sec. 11-700. - Findings. 
OCGA § 36-43-1 et seq. authorizes municipalities to establish city business improvement districts for the purpose of providing supplemental service to such districts by imposing assessments on property and collecting business license surcharges. The city has received a petition requesting the renewal and modification of the business improvement district, originally created in 2006, from property owners representing more than 51 percent of the total property value in proposed district. 
(Ord. No. 06-3-1, § I, 3-6-06; Ord. No. 2015-05-01, § I, 5-26-15) 
Sec. 11-701. - Creation of business improvement district; adoption of district plan; management of plan; amendments. 
(a)  There is hereby created a business improvement district in Rome, Georgia (the "District"). The legal boundaries of the District shall be set forth on an official map (the "Business Improvement District Map") which is a part of an official plan for the District (the "District Plan"). A copy of the Business Improvement District Map shall remain on file and available for inspection in the office of the Floyd County Tax Commissioner and the City of Rome Downtown Development Authority. The Business Improvement District Map attached hereto as a part of Exhibit A is hereby adopted and made a part of this chapter. 
(b)  The District Plan, also known as the Management Plan, attached hereto as Exhibit A, is hereby adopted and made a part of this ordinance. A copy of the District Plan shall remain on file and available for inspection in the office of the Rome Department of Downtown Development Authority. 
(c)  The District Plan may be amended from time to time by the city commission by adopting an official amendment to this ordinance. The District Plan must set forth, at a minimum, the following: 
(1)  The Business Improvement District Map; 
(2)  A description of the boundaries of the District; 
(3)  The maximum millage rate, if any, to be levied in the District; 
(4)  The proposed time for implementation and completion of the District Plan; 
(5)  Design and rehabilitation standards, if any, to be applied to buildings and structures within the District; 
(6)  The maximum surcharge, if any, to be levied on existing businesses and occupations within the District; 
(7)  The supplemental services to be provided within the District; 
(8)  Any other rules and regulations applicable to the District; 
(9)  The method of management of the District. 
(d)  Management of Plan. 
The Business Improvement District shall be managed by the downtown development authority for the City of Rome. The downtown development authority shall submit an annual financial statement to the City of Rome Commission for review and publication. 
(Ord. No. 06-3-1, § I, 3-6-06; Ord. No. 07-1-1, §§ I, II, 1-2-07; Ord. No. 2015-05-01, § I, 5-26-15) 
Sec. 11-702. - Supplemental services; continuation of services. 
(a)  Supplemental services provided in the District pursuant to the District Plan shall commence on January 1, 2016, and the District shall terminate on December 31, 2025, unless renewed by ordinance. 
(b)  The level of services presently provided to the District by the city will continue to be provided at the same level as before the District was created. It is the intent of the city that the provision of supplemental services within the District shall not reduce or otherwise replace existing services provided by the city. 
(Ord. No. 06-3-1, § I, 3-6-06; Ord. No. 2015-05-01, § I, 5-26-15) 
Sec. 11-703. - Separation of funds. 
Funds collected within the District under this article shall not be used for any other purpose other than those set forth in the District Plan. 
(Ord. No. 06-3-1, § I, 3-6-06; Ord. No. 2015-05-01, § I, 5-26-15) 
Secs. 11-704—11-799. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - SECONDHAND DEALERS 

Sec. 11-800. - Secondhand dealers. 
The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Employee means any person who works for a secondhand dealer, whether on a part-time or full-time basis, regardless of whether remuneration is received or not. 
Exempt items means clothing, music and video compact discs, furniture, any consignment item, motor vehicles, motorcycles, motorized water craft, waste paper, books, magazines, tires, lumber or wood products, and any recycled goods. 
Purchase means buying, exchanging, transferring, collecting, or otherwise acquiring regulated property from another person not a secondhand dealer, for resale, exchange, or transfer by the purchaser. This includes taking possession of regulated property with an express or implied agreement or understanding that the regulated property shall be returned at a subsequent time at a stipulated price or in exchange for payment of a storage or handling fee. 
Regulated secondhand items means articles or merchandise of any kind, including: hand tools, power tools, sporting equipment, electronic equipment, watches, jewelry, precious stones, precious metals, scrap gold, coins, musical instruments, electrical appliances, washers, dryers, refrigerators or any other items not specifically exempt under this section that have been previously sold or put into action or service. 
Secondhand dealer means any sole proprietorship, partnership, limited partnership, family limited partnership, joint venture, association, cooperative, trust, corporation, personal holding company, limited liability company, limited liability partnership, or any other form of organization whose business is dealing in, purchasing, selling, or trading regulated secondhand items. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11-2, § I, 11-3-08) 
Sec. 11-801. - Responsibility for enforcement. 
The city police department shall enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11-2, § I, 11-3-08) 
Sec. 11-802. - Character of secondhand dealer. 
No person convicted of a crime involving "moral turpitude" or any crime involving felony theft, burglary, or robbery shall receive a permit to be a secondhand dealer for five years following such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11-2, § I, 11-3-08) 
Sec. 11-803. - Annual permit. 
Before operating as a secondhand dealer, any person must first file an application with the city police department for a permit to operate as a secondhand dealer, pursuant to the following: 
(1)  The application shall be made on an annual basis; 
(2)  No permit shall be issued until a fee in an amount established by action of the city board of commissioners; said fee shall be set forth in the fee schedule book of the city as provided in section 8-36; 
(3)  The application shall state the physical address of the secondhand dealer; 
(4)  The application shall contain the full name, address, phone number, date of birth and Social Security number of all owners; and 
(5)  The chief of police or any other officer of the city designated by the city commissioners, shall investigate each applicant for such license. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11-2, § I, 11-3-08) 
Sec. 11-804. - Records of transactions. 
(a)  Every secondhand dealer shall maintain a permanent electronic record of its transactions so that an accurate description of all property purchased by the secondhand dealer can be transmitted to the Rome City Police Department via an electronic automated reporting system. Each of these transactions shall contain an accurate description of all property purchased by the secondhand dealer and shall be made at the time of each transaction, provided that the following information is included: 
(1)  The date and time of the purchase, or trade of the property; 
(2)  The name, address, and telephone number of the customer making the trade or sale; 
(3)  A description of the customer in terms of sex, race, date of birth, height and weight, as well as the driver's license number of the customer or some other identification card which contains a photograph of the customer; 
(4)  A description of the traded or purchased property by make, model, serial number, or other identifying number, and by any identifying marks (e.g. brand name, color, style, etc.); 
(5)  The number of the receipt or transaction issued for the property bought or traded; 
(6)  The price paid; 
(7)  A photograph of the customer and the item purchased which will be taken with the electronic automated reporting system at the time of the transaction; 
(8)  Any secondhand dealer that purchases regulated secondhand items at a yard sale, flea market, auction, or other similar events must report the secondhand item with all required information with the exception of the photograph of the seller; 
(9)  The signature of the customer. 
(b)  Every secondhand dealer shall enter each transaction as it occurs into the electronic automated reporting system or may elect to upload electronically via the internet a batch of all transactions for each business day to the administrator of the electronic reporting system immediately at the conclusion of each business day. The administrator of the electronic automated reporting system will electronically transmit all transactions to the city police department. 
(c)  In the event that the electronic automated reporting system becomes temporarily or permanently disabled, secondhand dealers will be notified as soon as possible. In this event, the secondhand dealer will be required to make records of transactions in paper form. Such paper forms must include all information as enumerated in paragraph (a) of this Code Section. Secondhand dealers shall maintain a three-day supply of these paper forms. 
(d)  Any duly authorized law enforcement officer may, during the ordinary hours of business or at any other reasonable time, inspect any secondhand dealer's electronic records and inventory at the secondhand dealer's place of business to ensure compliance with this section. 
(e)  The chief of police or his designee shall select and designate the required automated reporting system. There will be a fee assessed to the secondhand dealer for each reported transaction; said fee shall be set forth in the fee schedule book of the city as provided in section 8-36. This fee will be invoiced to the secondhand dealers and collected by the chief of police or his designee, which may be a third part administrator of the automated reporting system. 
(f)  Only transaction records containing complete information shall be deemed to comply with this section. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11-2, § I, 11-3-08) 
Sec. 11-805. - Tagging regulated property for identification. 
Each secondhand dealer shall affix a tag to every item of regulated property, which must contain a unique, legible number. That unique number must either be the same as the transaction report number for that item or be referenced to the transaction report required by the Rome Police Department or assigned by the approved reporting method described in the records of reporting. After the holding period has expired, the transaction number must remain identifiable on the property until sold. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11-2, § I, 11-3-08) 
Sec. 11-806. - Waiting period for disposal of articles. 
Any secondhand dealer who purchases goods under this section shall hold such goods for at least seven calendar days before disposing of them by sale, transfer, shipment or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11-2, § I, 11-3-08) 
Sec. 11-807. - Dealing with minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any secondhand dealer or his employee to receive goods by trade, purchase or sale from a person less than 18 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11-2, § I, 11-3-08) 
Sec. 11-808. - Lost or stolen items. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every person operating as or employed by a secondhand dealer to report to the chief of police or his duly authorized agent any article or item purchased by him if he shall have a reason to believe that the article or item was stolen or lost when presented by a seller or customer. 
(b)  With respect to any items which would normally have a serial number or other means of identification, if any owner or employee of a secondhand dealer becomes aware that such items have had the identification number removed, defaced or destroyed, such fact shall be immediately reported to the chief of police or his duly authorized agent. 
(c)  If it is determined that an item bought, sold, or traded by a seller or customer to the secondhand dealer or his employee is the subject of any reported theft, then the surrender of said item to the chief of police or his duly authorized agent shall be done upon demand. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11-2, § I, 11-3-08) 
Sec. 11-809. - "Secondhand dealers" not included. 
The following shall not be considered secondhand dealers and are exempt from the provisions of this article: 
(1)  A business whose acquisitions of regulated secondhand items consist exclusively of donated items and/or were purchased from 501(c)(3) organizations; or 
(2)  A person whose only business transactions with regulated secondhand items in the City of Rome consist of the sale of personal property acquired for household or personal use; or 
(3)  A person whose only business transactions with regulated secondhand items in the City of Rome consist of a display space, booth, or table maintained for displaying or selling merchandise at any trade show, convention, festival, fair, circus, market, flea market, swap meet, antique mall or similar event; or 
(4)  Regulated secondhand items sold by a licensed auctioneer at an auction; or 
(5)  Regulated secondhand items sold at an estate sale, yard sale or similar event. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11-2, § I, 11-3-08) 
Sec. 11-810. - Fixed physical location. 
No person or business may operate as a secondhand dealer within the City of Rome unless the person or business maintains a fixed physical business location. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11-2, § I, 11-3-08) 
Sec. 11-811. - Violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or employee of a secondhand dealer to violate any of the provisions of this article. Further, any person failing to comply with any provision of this article or other rules, ordinances and regulations as may be passed by the city board of commissioners for conduct of the business of a secondhand dealer shall upon conviction, have the permit to conduct business revoked. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or employee of a secondhand dealer to: 
(1)  Make any false statement in an application for any permit provided for in this article. 
(2)  Make any false entry in any record book, ledger or form required by the terms of this article. 
(3)  Violate any criminal law of this state while acting in the course of business as an owner or employee of a secondhand dealer. 
(c)  Persons who violate this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11-2, § I, 11-3-08) 
Secs. 11-812—11-829. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES 

Sec. 11-830. - Purpose; findings and rationale. 
(a)  Purpose. It is the purpose of this article to regulate sexually oriented businesses in order to promote the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of the city, and to establish reasonable and uniform regulations to prevent the deleterious secondary effects of sexually oriented businesses within the city. The provisions of this article have neither the purpose nor effect of imposing a limitation or restriction on the content or reasonable access to any communicative materials, including sexually oriented materials. Similarly, it is neither the intent nor effect of this article to restrict or deny access by adults to sexually oriented materials protected by the First Amendment, or to deny access by the distributors and exhibitors of sexually oriented entertainment to their intended market. Neither is it the intent nor effect of this article to condone or legitimize the distribution of obscene material. 
(b)  Findings and rationale. Based on evidence of the adverse secondary effects of adult uses presented in hearings and in reports made available to the city commission, and on findings, interpretations, and narrowing constructions incorporated in the cases of City of Littleton v. Z.J. Gifts D-4, L.L.C., 541 U.S. 774 (2004); City of Los Angeles v. Alameda Books, Inc., 535 U.S. 425 (2002); City of Erie v. Pap's A.M., 529 U.S. 277 (2000); City of Renton v. Playtime Theatres, Inc., 475 U.S. 41 (1986); Young v. American Mini Theatres, 427 U.S. 50 (1976); Barnes v. Glen Theatre, Inc., 501 U.S. 560 (1991); California v. LaRue, 409 U.S. 109 (1972); N.Y. State Liquor Authority v. Bellanca, 452 U.S. 714 (1981); Sewell v. Georgia, 435 U.S. 982 (1978); FW/PBS, Inc. v. City of Dallas, 493 U.S. 215 (1990); City of Dallas v. Stanglin, 490 U.S. 19 (1989); and 
Stardust, 3007 LLC v. City of Brookhaven, 899 F.3d 1164 (11th Cir. 2018); HH-Indianapolis, LLC v. Consol. City of Indianapolis/Marion County, 889 F.3d 432 (7th Cir. 2018); HH-Indianapolis, LLC v. Consol. City of Indianapolis/Marion County, 265 F. Supp. 3d 873 (S.D. Ind. 2017); Flanigan's Enters., Inc. v. City of Sandy Springs, 703 F. App'x 929 (11th Cir. 2017); Maxim Cabaret, Inc. v. City of Sandy Springs, 816 S.E.2d 31 (Ga. 2018); Oasis Goodtime Emporium I, Inc. v. City of Doraville, 297 Ga. 513 (2015); Trop, Inc. v. City of Brookhaven, 296 Ga. 85 (2014); Goldrush II v. City of Marietta, 267 Ga. 683 (1997); Flanigan's Enters., Inc. v. Fulton County, 596 F.3d 1265 (11th Cir. 2010); Peek-a-Boo Lounge v. Cobb County, 285 F.3d 1319 (11th Cir. 2002); DLS, Inc. v. City of Chattanooga, 107 F.3d 403 (6th Cir. 1997); Grand Faloon Tavern, Inc. v. State, 272 Ga. 129 (2000); Flippen Alliance for Community Empowerment, Inc. v. Brannan, 601 S.E.2d 106 (Ga. Ct. App. 2004); Oasis Goodtime Emporium I, Inc. v. City of Fall River, 714 F.3d 65 (1st Cir. 2013); Imaginary Images, Inc. v. Evans, 612 F.3d 736 (4th Cir. 2010); LLEH, Inc. v. Wichita County, 289 F.3d 358 (5th Cir. 2002); Ocello v. Koster, 354 S.W.3d 187 (Mo. 2011); 84 Video/Newsstand, Inc. v. Sartini, 2011 WL 3904097 (6th Cir. Sept. 7, 2011); Plaza Group Properties, LLC v. Spencer County Plan Commission, 877 N.E.2d 877 (Ind. Coweta County, No. 3:09-CV-123, R. 41 (N.D. Ga. Feb. 28, 2011); High Five Investments, LLC v. Floyd County, No. 4:06-CV-190, R. 128 (N.D. Ga. Mar. 14, 2008); 10950 Retail, LLC v. Fulton County, No. 1:06-CV-1923, R. 62 Order (N.D. Ga. Dec. 21, 2006); 10950 Retail, LLC v. Fulton County, No. 1:06-CV-1923, R. 84 Contempt Order (N.D. Ga. Jan. 4, 2007); Z.J. Gifts D-4, L.L.C. v. City of Littleton, Civil Action No. 99-N-1696, Memorandum Decision and Order (D. Colo. March 31, 2001); People ex rel. Deters v. The Lion's Den, Inc., Case No. 04-CH-26, Modified Permanent Injunction Order (Ill. Fourth Judicial Circuit, Effingham County, July 13, 2005); Reliable Consultants, Inc. v. City of Kennedale, No. 4:05-CV-166-A, Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law (N.D. Tex. May 26, 2005); Starship Enterprises of Atlanta, Inc. v. Gwinnett County, No. 176A-00699-1 (Order Granting Summary Judgment and Permanent Injunction, Jan. 12, 2018); 
and based upon reports concerning secondary effects occurring in and around sexually oriented businesses, including, but not limited to, "Correlates of Current Transactional Sex among a Sample of Female Exotic Dancers in Baltimore, MD," Journal of Urban Health (2011); "Does the Presence of Sexually Oriented Businesses Relate to Increased Levels of Crime?" Crime & Delinquency (2012) (Louisville, KY); Metropolis, Illinois - 2011-12; Manatee County, Florida - 2007; Hillsborough County, Florida - 2006; Clarksville, Indiana - 2009; El Paso, Texas - 2008; Memphis, Tennessee - 2006; New Albany, Indiana - 2009; Louisville, Kentucky - 2004; Fulton County, GA - 2001; Chattanooga, Tennessee - 1999-2003; Jackson County, Missouri - 2008; Ft. Worth, Texas - 2004; Kennedale, Texas - 2005; Greensboro, North Carolina - 2003; Dallas, Texas - 1997; Houston, Texas - 1997, 1983; Phoenix, Arizona - 1995-98, 1979; Tucson, Arizona - 1990; Spokane, Washington - 2001; St. Cloud, Minnesota - 1994; Austin, Texas - 1986; Indianapolis, Indiana - 1984; Garden Grove, California - 1991; Los Angeles, California - 1977; Whittier, California - 1978; Oklahoma City, Oklahoma - 1986; New York, New York Times Square - 1994; the Report of the Attorney General's Working Group On The Regulation Of Sexually Oriented Businesses, (June 6, 1989, State of Minnesota); Dallas, Texas - 2007; "Rural Hotspots: The Case of Adult Businesses," 19 Criminal Justice Policy Review 153 (2008); "Stripclubs According to Strippers: Exposing Workplace Sexual Violence," by Kelly Holsopple, Program Director, Freedom and Justice Center for Prostitution Resources, Minneapolis, Minnesota; "Sexually Oriented Businesses: An Insider's View," by David Sherman, presented to the Michigan House Committee on Ethics and Constitutional Law, Jan. 12, 2000; Sex Store Statistics and Articles; Indianapolis / Marion County Board of Zoning Appeals Documents; Law Enforcement and Private Investigator Affidavits (Adult Cabarets in Forest Park, GA and Sandy Springs, GA); DeKalb County Testimony and Reports - 2014; and Strip Club-Trafficking Documents, the City Commission finds: 
(1)  Sexually oriented businesses, as a category of commercial uses, are associated with a wide variety of adverse secondary effects including, but not limited to, personal and property crimes, human trafficking, prostitution, potential spread of disease, lewdness, public indecency, obscenity, illicit drug use and drug trafficking, negative impacts on surrounding properties, urban blight, litter, and sexual assault and exploitation. Alcohol consumption impairs judgment and lowers inhibitions, thereby increasing the risk of adverse secondary effects. 
(2)  Sexually oriented businesses should be separated from sensitive land uses to minimize the impact of their secondary effects upon such uses, and should be separated from other sexually oriented businesses, to minimize the secondary effects associated with such uses and to prevent an unnecessary concentration of sexually oriented businesses in one area.
