(a)  No driver of any motor vehicle shall operate the vehicle upon the public streets, highways, public or private driveways or parking lots in such a manner as to create a danger to persons or property by intentionally and unnecessarily causing the vehicle to move directly toward any person or property, to move in a zigzag or circular course, or to gyrate or spin around, except to avoid a collision or injury or damage. 
(b)  The offense described in subsection (a) shall be sufficiently designated on any traffic ticket, warrant or complaint when referred to as "laying drags." 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of subsection (a) shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 1959, § 30-38.1; Code 1981, § 10-2011) 
Sec. 12-173. - Approaching sign indicating play street. 
Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating any street or part thereof as a play street, no person shall drive a vehicle upon any such street or portion thereof except drivers of vehicles having business or whose residences are within such closed area, and then any such driver shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon any such street or portion thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 30-35; Code 1981, § 10-2012) 
Sec. 12-174. - Use of television and radio sets. 
(a)  When any vehicle has a television or video set therein, it shall not be operated in view of the driver while the vehicle is in motion. 
(b)  When any vehicle has a radio set therein, such radio set shall not be operated at a volume great enough to prevent the driver of the vehicle from hearing horn signals of other vehicles or the warning of emergency vehicles. 
(Code 1959, § 30-52; Code 1981, § 10-2013) 
Sec. 12-175. - Funeral processions to be identified. 
A funeral composed of a procession of vehicles shall be identified as such by the display upon the outside of each vehicle of a pennant or other identifying insignia or by such other method as may be determined and designated by the police department. 
(Code 1959, § 30-43; Code 1981, § 10-2018) 
Sec. 12-176. - Driving through funeral or other procession. 
No driver of a bus or other vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when the vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in this chapter. This section shall not apply at intersections where traffic is controlled by traffic control signs or police officers. 
(Code 1959, § 30-41; Code 1981, § 10-2016) 
Sec. 12-177. - Drivers in a procession. 
Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the righthand edge of a roadway as practical and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practical and safe. 
(Code 1959, § 30-42; Code 1981, § 10-2017) 
Cross reference— Parades, § 11-531 et seq. 
Sec. 12-178. - Following or parking near fire apparatus prohibited. 
No driver of any vehicle other than one on official business shall follow any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm or other emergency vehicle closer than 500 feet, or drive into or park such vehicle within 500 feet of any fire apparatus stopped in answer to a fire alarm. 
(Ord. No. 81-12-8, § 1, 12-7-81; Code 1981, § 10-2019) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 9. 
Sec. 12-179. - Crossing fire hose prohibited. 
No vehicle shall be driven over any unprotected fire hose when laid down on any street, private road or driveway to be used at any fire or alarm of fire, without consent of the fire department official in command. 
(Ord. No. 81-12-8, § 2, 12-7-81; Code 1981, § 10-2020) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 9. 
Sec. 12-180. - Speed detection devices. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Speed detection device has the meaning provided in O.C.G.A. § 40-14-1. 
(b)  The use of speed detection devices is desired and hereby approved. 
(c)  The city commission may, by resolution, name the street or road on which the speed detection device is to be used, and shall, consistent with section 12-166, specify the speed limits on such street or road for the approval by the division of traffic engineering and safety of the state department of transportation. 
(Ord. No. 85-3-13, §§ 2, 3, 3-4-85; Code 1981, § 10-2021) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-181. - Driving on levees prohibited. 
Unless upon an officially dedicated public way, or unless specifically permitted by an official sign or by the direction of the chief of police, no person shall drive or operate any motorized vehicle on or over any levee within the city. 
(Ord. No. 86-9-10, § 1, 9-15-86; Code 1981, § 10-2022) 
Sec. 12-182. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 03-7-1, § II, approved July 7, 2003, repealed § 12-182 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to trespass by motor vehicle in privately owned parking lots as enacted by Code 1981, § 10-2023, as amended. 
Secs. 12-183—12-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TRUCK ROUTES; SIZE, WEIGHT AND LOAD 

Sec. 12-211. - Definitions. 
In the construction of this article, words and phrases used in this article shall have their customary meanings, except for specific words and phrases which shall be defined in this section. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Deviating truck means a truck which leaves and departs from a truck route while traveling within the city limits. 
Prohibited street means a street over which truck traffic is prohibited by action of the traffic engineer, in accordance with section 12-36. 
Truck means any vehicle designed or operated for the transportation of property, including raw materials, and whose body weight or whose combined body and load weight exceeds five tons. 
Truck route means a way over certain streets, as designated in this article, over and along which trucks coming into and going out of the city must operate. 
(Code 1981, § 10-2051) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-212. - Purpose. 
It is hereby declared to be the purpose of this article to protect the safety of the public in their lives and property in the use of the streets of the city; to facilitate and expedite traffic within the city; and to protect the streets of the city from unusual wear and damage. 
(Code 1959, § 30-178; Code 1981, § 10-2052) 
Sec. 12-213. - Size. 
No vehicle operated upon any public street of the city exclusive of those public streets which are also a part of the state or federal highway system, except vehicles designed to carry passengers, shall exceed a total outside width, including load thereon, of 96 inches, not including mirrors and accessories attached thereto; no vehicle unladen or with load shall exceed a height of 13 feet six inches; no vehicle or combination of vehicles shall exceed a total length of 60 feet. 
(Code 1981, § 10-2053) 
State Law reference— Length of vehicles and loads, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-24. 
Sec. 12-214. - Load. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Axle load means the total load on all wheels whose centers may be included between two parallel transverse vertical planes 40 inches apart. 
(b)  No wheel on any vehicle operated upon any public street of this city, equipped with high pressure, pneumatic, solid rubber or cushion tires shall carry a load which exceeds 8,000 pounds by more than 13 percent or an axle load which exceeds 16,000 pounds by more than 13 percent; no wheel equipped with low pressure pneumatic tires shall carry a load which exceeds 9,000 pounds by more than 13 percent or any axle load which exceeds 18,000 pounds by more than 13 percent. If any vehicle can be made to comply with the requirements of this section by shifting or equalizing the load on all wheels or axles and does so when requested by the proper authority the vehicle shall not be held to be operating in violation of this section; provided, however, that the maximum total gross weight, including tolerance, shall not exceed 73,280 pounds. 
(Code 1981, § 10-2054) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-215. - Permit for occasional movements at variance with article. 
(a)  Required. For occasional movements of materials or objects of dimensions or weights which exceed the limits provided in this article, a special permit shall be obtained as provided in subsection (c). 
(b)  Application. The application for any permit required by this article shall specifically describe the motor vehicle and load to be operated or moved and the particular route for which a permit to operate is requested. 
(c)  Issuance. The traffic engineer may, upon application, issue a special permit authorizing the applicant to operate or move a motor vehicle or combinations of vehicles upon the public streets, when the length, width, height or weight of the vehicles and load exceeds the maximum limit. 
(d)  Refusal; limitations. The traffic engineer may withhold permits for the movement of vehicles which exceed the maximum size and weight limits, if the movement of those vehicles would unduly interfere with the safety or the general welfare or the convenience of the general public. If the permit is issued, the traffic engineer may limit the number of trips, the time limits within which the vehicles may be operated, or otherwise prescribe the conditions of operation of those vehicles on the public streets. 
(e)  Carried; inspection. Every special permit issued under this article shall be carried in the vehicle or combination of vehicles to which it refers and shall be open to inspection by any police officer or authorized agent of the city. 
(Code 1981, §§ 10-2055—10-2059) 
Sec. 12-216. - Application of prohibited street regulation. 
(a)  No truck shall be operated over a prohibited street, unless in accordance with this section. 
(b)  Any truck may be deviated from a truck route and operated over a prohibited street where necessary to reach a destination point within the city for the conduct of business, provided streets upon which truck traffic is permitted are used until reaching the intersection of such prohibited street nearest such street on which truck traffic is permitted and leading to the destination. 
(c)  Any truck may be operated over a prohibited street where necessary to leave a point of origin within the city for the conduct of business, provided it leaves such prohibited street at the nearest intersection of a truck route to such point of origin. 
(d)  Any truck may be operated over a prohibited street listed in this article if owned or operated by the city, public utilities, or any contractor or materialman, while engaged in the repair, maintenance or construction of streets, street improvements or street utilities within the city. 
(e)  An emergency vehicle may be operated on any street within the city. 
(f)  A truck may be operated on a prohibited street when required to do so by an officially established detour. 
(Code 1959, § 30-180; Code 1981, § 10-2060) 
Sec. 12-217. - Truck traffic in city. 
(a)  Outside origin. 
(1)  One inside destination point. All trucks entering the city for a destination point in the city shall proceed only over an established truck route and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street, upon which such traffic is permitted, nearest to the destination point. Upon leaving the destination point, a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest possible route. 
(2)  Multiple inside destination points. All trucks entering the city for multiple destination points shall proceed only over established truck routes and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street, upon which such traffic is permitted, nearest to the first destination point. Upon leaving the first destination point a deviating truck shall proceed to other destination points by the shortest direction and only over streets upon which such traffic is permitted. Upon leaving the last destination point, a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest permissible route. 
(b)  Inside origin. 
(1)  Outside destination point. All trucks, on a trip originating in the city and traveling in the city for a destination point outside the city, shall proceed by the shortest direction over streets on which such traffic is permitted to a truck route as established in this article. 
(2)  Inside destination points. All trucks, on a trip originating in the city and traveling in the city for destination points in the city, shall proceed only over streets upon which such traffic is permitted. 
(Code 1959, § 30-182; Code 1981, § 10-2061) 
Secs. 12-218—12-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 

Sec. 12-241. - Application of article. 
(a)  The provisions of this article prohibiting the standing or parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times or at those times indicated on official signs except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device. 
(b)  The provisions of this article imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other and more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times. 
(Code 1981, § 10-2031) 
Sec. 12-242. - Enforcement. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the police department or a city employee specially designated by the downtown development authority to enforce the provisions of this article, and the police department or the specially designated city employee may use tire markings and other devices and procedures to determine violations. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, erase or alter any tire markings, chalk or otherwise, placed by the police department or a city employee specially designated by the downtown development authority to enforce the provisions of this article on any vehicle parked in the city with the intent to prevent the enforcement of any provisions of this article. 
(Code 1959, § 30-114; Ord. No. 82-4-3, § 1, 4-17-82; Code 1981, §§ 10-2043, 10-2046; Ord. No. 00-3-3, § I, 3-20-00) 
Sec. 12-243. - Designation of parking spaces; parking within space required. 
(a)  The traffic engineer is hereby authorized and directed to mark off and maintain individual parking spaces. Such parking spaces shall be designated by lines painted or durably marked on the curb or the surface of the street. 
(b)  At each space so marked it shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in such a way that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the limits of such space. 
(c)  Vehicles shall park in marked spaces in the Downtown Parking Zone as defined in section 12-244 in such a manner and direction that the license plate is clearly visible from the adjacent travel lane in the roadway or parking lot aisle. 
(Code 1981, § 10-2032; Ord. No. 2018-11-1, § I, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 12-244. - Parking time limits. 
(a)  The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them below: 
Downtown parking zone means: 
(1)  The public parking spaces, within and alongside the area bounded by First Avenue (from East First Street to West First Street), West First Street (from First Avenue to Tribune Street to Riverside Parkway), Tribune Street, Sixth Avenue (from Tribune Street to East First Street), and East First Street (from Sixth Avenue to First Avenue), including Second Avenue, Third Avenue, Fourth Avenue, Fifth Avenue, and Broad Street from First Avenue to Riverside Parkway; and 
(2)  The public parking spaces located in any parking lot managed by the downtown development authority. 
Special parking permit means any parking permit issued by the downtown development authority or the city police department for use in any downtown public parking space. 
(b)  No vehicle or motorcycle shall be parked on-street for more than two hours, whether consecutive or otherwise, in the downtown parking zone between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. 
(c)  No vehicle or motorcycle shall be parked for more than 48 consecutive hours in the downtown parking zone. If any vehicle or motorcycle is so parked for more than 48 consecutive hours, the city police department shall have the authority to have the vehicle or motorcycle towed to a place designated by the city police department, with the owner or operator to bear all towing and storage costs. 
(d)  The penalty fines shall be adopted by resolution of the city commission as an amendment to the fee schedule book kept on file in the city clerk's office. 
(e)  Special parking permits shall be available for issuance. Written guidelines for issuance of special parking permits shall be established by resolution of the city commission upon the recommendation of the board of the downtown development authority or the chief of police for the city. 
(f)  Designated off-street public parking time limits and/or restrictions shall be indicated by official signs. 
(Ord. No. 88-9-1, § 1, 9-6-88; Code 1981, § 10-2033; Ord. No. 93-12-5, § I, 12-20-93; Ord. No. 98-10-1, § I, 10-5-98; Ord. No. 02-1-1, § I, 1-7-02; Ord. No. 2009-6-2, § I, 6-15-09; Ord. No. 2013-9-1, § I, 9-9-13; Ord. No. 2014-8-1, § I, 8-25-14; Ord. No. 2018-11-1, § II, 11-13-18) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-245. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2018-7-1, § I, adopted July 9, 2018, repealed former § 12-245 which pertained to all-night parking prohibited and derived from Code 1959, § 30-91; Code 1981, § 10-2034. 
Sec. 12-246. - Parking for certain purposes prohibited. 
No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying such vehicle for sale. 
(2)  Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle, unless making repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(Code 1959, § 30-92; Code 1981, § 10-2035) 
Sec. 12-247. - Standing or parking on one-way roadways. 
If a highway includes two or more separate roadways and traffic is restricted to one direction upon any such roadway, then outside the Downtown Parking Zone and residential zones no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon the left-hand side of such one-way roadway for any purpose including loading or unloading unless signs are erected to permit such standing or parking. 
(Code 1981, § 10-2036; Ord. No. 2018-7-1, § II, 7-9-18) 
Sec. 12-248. - Lights on parked vehicles. 
(a)  Whenever a vehicle is lawfully parked at nighttime upon any street within a business or residence district, no lights need be displayed upon such parked vehicle. 
(b)  Whenever a vehicle is parked upon a street or highway outside of a business or residence district during the hours between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise, such vehicle shall be equipped with one or more lamps which shall exhibit a white or amber light on the roadway side visible from a distance of 500 feet to the front of the vehicle and a red light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear. 
(c)  Any lighted headlamps upon a parked vehicle shall be depressed or dimmed. 
(Code 1959, § 30-87; Code 1981, § 10-2039) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-28. 
Sec. 12-249. - Parking of buses and taxicabs regulated. 
The driver of a bus or taxicab shall not park upon any street in any business district at any place other than at a bus stop or taxicab stand, respectively, except that this section shall not prevent the driver of any such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers. 
(Code 1959, § 30-103; Code 1981, § 10-2040) 
Cross reference— Vehicles for hire, § 11-376 et seq. 
Sec. 12-250. - Restricted use of bus and taxicab stands. 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading and unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter such zone. 
(Code 1959, § 30-104; Code 1981, § 10-2041) 
Cross reference— Vehicles for hire, § 11-376 et seq. 
Sec. 12-251. - Railroad trains and buses not to block streets. 
It shall be unlawful for the directing officer or the operator of any railroad train or bus to direct the operation of or to operate the same in such a manner as to prevent the use of any street for purposes of travel for a period of time longer than five minutes, except that this provision shall not apply to trains or cars in motion other than those engaged in switching. It shall be unlawful for the driver of any bus to stop such bus within an intersection or on a crosswalk for the purpose of receiving or discharging passengers. 
(Code 1959, § 30-80; Code 1981, § 10-2042) 
Sec. 12-252. - Handicapped parking—Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in section 12-253, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Handicapped parking place means any area on public or private property which has been designated as reserved for the use of handicapped persons by any sign or pavement marking bearing the word "handicapped," or a symbol representing a person in a wheelchair. 
Handicapped person means a person who by reason of illness, injury, age, congenital malfunction, or other incapacity or disability has a significant loss or impairment of mobility. 
(Ord. of 11-3-80; Code 1981, § 10-2044) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-221. 
Sec. 12-253. - Same—Parking prohibited in handicapped parking places without permit or license plate. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand, or park any vehicle in a handicapped parking place unless there is displayed on the dashboard or hung from the rearview mirror of the parked vehicle a valid unexpired handicapped parking permit or unless there is attached to the vehicle a specially designated license plate for disabled persons authorized under O.C.G.A. § 40-6-222(d). 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand, or park any vehicle in a handicapped parking place except for the purpose of allowing a handicapped person to enter or get out of such vehicle while in such parking place. However, nothing in this subsection shall prevent an ambulance or emergency vehicle from stopping in a handicapped parking place. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person or institution, other than the one to whom a handicapped parking permit or specially designated license plate for the disabled person is issued, to make use of a handicapped parking permit or specially designated license plate for a disabled person. It shall be unlawful for any person to use a handicapped parking permit for any institutional vehicle other than the vehicle for which the permit has been issued. 
(d)  No person shall park a vehicle so as to block any entrance or egress ramp used by handicapped persons on public or private property. 
(e)  Authorities of the city shall honor visitors' out-of-state handicapped license tags or similar special parking permits on the same basis as handicapped license tags or special parking permits issued within this state. 
(Ord. of 11-3-80; Code 1981, § 10-2045) 
Sec. 12-254. - Public loading zones. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle within a designated loading zone except for the purpose of loading or unloading such vehicle. A delivery or pickup vehicle may park in a designated loading zone only during such time as materials or passengers are being loaded and/or unloaded from the vehicle, and in no case may such vehicle remain parked in a designated loading zone for longer than 20 minutes, unless a different time limit is indicated by sign or permitted by ordinance. A vehicle must be removed from a loading zone immediately upon completion of loading and/or unloading materials from such vehicle or the expiration of the time limit for that loading zone, whichever occurs first. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park for loading or unloading at an angle other than that marked for regular parking in that location or to leave the back gate of the vehicle lowered so as to extend beyond the marked space for the vehicle, or to park without doors opened flat against the body of the vehicle while loading or unloading. In the event spaces for regular parking are not marked in said location then the prohibition of obstruction of traffic in section 12-255 shall apply to any encroachment by gates, ramps or doors of the loading or unloading vehicle. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle within a properly marked loading zone between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. if said loading zone is also marked as a no parking tow zone between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(d)  At the discretion of a police officer, the City of Rome, Georgia may tow and impound or otherwise move vehicles which are parked by their owners or operators in any loading zone in violation of the regulations, at the owner's or operator's expense. 
(e)  Broad Street additional regulations. The loading zones on the portion of Broad Street between its intersections with First Avenue and Sixth Avenue shall be unmarked center-lane loading zones and shall have the following regulations concerning permitted users of the loading zone in addition to the provisions of paragraphs (a) through (e) above: 
(1)  The exclusive permitted users shall be pickup or delivery vehicles at least 20 feet in length, including lifts or ramps, actively engaged in loading or unloading materials. 
(2)  All delivery vehicles are prohibited from loading or unloading in the center lane within: 
a.  Fifteen feet on either side of a mid-block crosswalk; 
b.  Fifty feet on the approach side of an intersection, except for Second Avenue which shall not be within 100 feet of the approach side to the intersection; or 
c.  Twenty-five feet on the departure side of an intersection, except for Second Avenue which shall not be within 70 feet of the departure side of the intersection. 
(3)  All delivery drivers are required to place safety cones behind their delivery vehicles and in the immediate area of the points of access to the vehicles from the street, or activate flashing hazard lights to alert motorists to the loading or unloading activity that is under way in the center lane. 
(4)  The center lane on Broad Street shall not be used for loading and unloading between the hours of 11:00 a.m.—1:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 2018-7-1, § III, 7-9-18) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2018-7-1, § III, adopted July 9, 2018, in effect repealed former § 12-254 which pertained to parking of business vehicles prohibited in residential zones and derived from Ord. No. 2016-01-01, § I, 1-11-16. 
Sec. 12-255. - Obstruction of traffic. 
No person shall park any vehicle upon a street in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic. Where an arterial or major and minor collector streets as established by the Rome-Floyd County Planning Department has a centerline, no person shall park a vehicle within 12 feet of such centerline. No person shall park a vehicle in such a manner as to obstruct or interfere with the access of emergency vehicles through said street. 
(Ord. No. 2018-7-1, § IV, 7-9-18) 
Secs. 12-256—12-275. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BICYCLES; PLAY VEHICLES 

Sec. 12-276. - Parking. 
No person shall park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway against the curb or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or against a building or at the curb, in such manner as to afford the least obstruction to pedestrian traffic. 
(Code 1959, § 30-145; Code 1981, § 10-2071) 
Sec. 12-277. - Riding on sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall ride a bicycle on a sidewalk within a business district. 
(b)  No person shall ride a skateboard on a sidewalk within a C-2 zone. 
(c)  The chief of police is authorized to erect signs on any sidewalk or roadway prohibiting the riding of bicycles thereon by any person and when those signs are in place no person shall disobey the signs. 
(d)  Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk, that person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give audible signal before overtaking and passing the pedestrian. 
(Code 1959, § 30-146; Ord. No. 88-5-1, §§ 2, 3, 5-2-88; Code 1981, § 10-2072) 
Cross reference— Zoning, ch. 23. 
Sec. 12-278. - Coasters, roller skates, and similar devices; use restricted. 
No person upon roller skates or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle, or similar device shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a street on a crosswalk, and when so crossing such person shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. This section shall not apply upon any street while set aside as a play street as authorized by ordinances of this city. 
(Code 1959, § 30-20; Code 1981, § 10-2074) 
Secs. 12-279—12-300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - WRECKER AND TOWING SERVICES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Licenses, permits and business regulations, ch. 11. 
State Law reference— Removal of junked motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4; flashing or revolving lights on vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-92; local ordinances, etc., relating to wrecker services, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-10.1. 

Sec. 12-301. - Definitions 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Tow means towing, hauling and removing vehicles by the use of a wrecker. 
Vehicle means, unless otherwise indicated, a vehicle to be towed shall be: 
(1)  A vehicle damaged to such an extent that it is unable to be moved safely under its own power; 
(2)  A vehicle abandoned by its owner, driver, or other person; 
(3)  A vehicle impounded or under the control of a city police officer or other lawfully empowered officer of the city or state; 
(4)  A vehicle, the owner or operator or person in possession of which is under arrest or in the custody of the city police or other lawfully empowered officer of the city or state; 
(5)  A vehicle, the owner or operator or person in possession of which is not in physical or mental condition to operate a vehicle. 
Wrecker means an automotive vehicle with hoisting apparatus and equipment for towing wrecked, disabled or abandoned automobiles or other vehicles. The term "wrecker" also includes any vehicle otherwise equipped and used for the purpose of towing wrecked, disabled or abandoned automobiles or other vehicles. This definition includes "rollback" or "slide back" wreckers. Passenger cars, light truck and similar vehicles means any vehicle weight up to 10,000 pounds of gross vehicle weight ("GVW"). 
Wrecker service means any entity, corporation, partnership, or individual person, either as principal, agent, or employee, in the business of removing, towing and/or storing wrecked, disabled or abandoned automobiles or other vehicles by the use of a wrecker or other towing device within the city. 
Wrecker service company means any person furnishing wrecker service within the city. 
(Code 1959, § 30-171; Ord. No. 85-5-1, § 1, 5-6-85; Code 1981, § 10-2101; Ord. No. 93-12-3, § II, 12-6-93; Ord. No. 2010-8-3, § I, 8-16-10) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-302. - Conditions prerequisite to furnishing towing service at request of city. 
Unless the person needing wrecker services specifically requests that a wrecker service unauthorized under this article be called, all persons engaged in the wrecker service business within the city shall not be called upon by police officers or other authorized employees of the city to furnish the service of towing any vehicle upon the streets of the city, unless the person engaged in furnishing the wrecker service shall have complied with the following conditions: 
(1)  The wrecker service shall be available 24 hours a day, seven days a week, to provide the service. 
(2)  The wrecker service shall have qualified licensed employees, skilled and knowledgeable in performing their duties, and available at all times to avoid delay. 
(3)  The wrecker service shall operate at least two wreckers (e.g. 8,000 pound dual cable wrecker or "rollback" wreckers with wheel lifts). The wreckers shall: 
a.  Be in good operating condition, meeting all requirements of state law, and be equipped with a flashing light mounted on top of the tow car, or on top of the crane or hoist, which light will be visible for a distance of 1,000 feet, and mounted in such a manner that it can be seen both by approaching and rear traffic. 
b.  Be equipped with sufficient red flares, lanterns or warning lights and reflectors to be able to mark the scene of a wreck on both sides of the same, so as to warn all traffic on the highway of the emergency existing while the wreckers are in operation. 
c.  Carry brooms, shovels, oil dry, sand, and fire extinguishers suitable for extinguishing fires in wrecked vehicles, and for cleaning up the debris, fluids and glass from the area where the wreck has occurred. The fire extinguisher shall be of a type capable of extinguishing a fire of flammable liquid. 
(4)  Wrecker services placed on call list to receive large wrecker call shall have available heavy duty wrecker(s) having a 26,001 pound minimum gross weight rating with a 20-ton winch, or an equivalent vehicle having the same minimum capabilities for moving vehicles, including large trucks, buses and loaded and unloaded tractor trailers. 
(5)  The wrecker service shall have attached and displayed in a conspicuous place, on both the right and left sides of the wrecker, the name of the towing service or company and their unit number. Magnetic or removable decals or signs do not satisfy the requirements of this paragraph. 
(6)  The wrecker service shall maintain in the wrecker service's name, at a minimum, the following insurance policies: 
a.  An automobile liability insurance police having a combined single limit of not less than $300,000.00; 
b.  A comprehensive general liability police providing bodily injury coverage limits of $100,000.00 per occurrence and property damage coverage limits of $100,000.00 per person and $100,000.00 annual aggregate; 
c.  Cargo and garage keepers' liability insurance with a limit of $100,000.00; and 
d.  Workers' compensation insurance meeting the minimum coverage required by Georgia law. 
Said insurance policies shall name the City of Rome as an additional insured under the policy, and shall provide for written notification at least 15 days prior to any modification, expiration, or cancellation of the policy. The wrecker service shall provide to the chief of police a full copy of the insurance policy no later than five days from execution of agreement or extension thereof or any modification or renewal of the policy. 
(7)  The wrecker service shall provide a storage area located within the city limits or within a six-mile radius from the intersection of Second Avenue and Broad Street for the storage and safekeeping of vehicles towed under this article. The area shall be enclosed with a solid wall, or a substantial wire fence as defined in sections 23-2 and 23-36 of the Rome City Code. Such fence shall not be less than eight feet in height, except that all wrecker services in operation as of November 15, 1993 may maintain a fence not less than six feet in height until such time as the service elects to construct a new or replacement fence. All fences must be visually screened, and have a capacity for a minimum of 30 cars. Wrecker storage lots will be inspected annually by an official from the City of Rome/Floyd Building Inspection Department or Police Department. Storage areas established before November 1993 found to be in need of repair are subject to the latest requirements of being not less than eight feet in height, and will be given notice of needed repairs. Upon notice, the wrecker service shall have 30 days to make repairs. 
(8)  The wrecker service shall employ operating personnel of wrecker units that shall be technically qualified and physically cable of responding immediately to all calls received. Operating personnel of wreckers must obtain a Rome Police Department ID, which must be worn at all times while responding to calls under this article. 
(9)  The wrecker service must maintain registration with the Georgia Public Service Commission and possess all state-required permits. 
(Code 1959, § 30-172; Code 1981, § 10-2102; Ord. No. 85-5-1, § 1, 5-6-85; Ord. No. 90-1-1, § I, 1-22-90; Ord. No. 93-12-3, § III, 12-6-93; Ord. No. 05-7-2, § I, 7-18-05; Ord. No. 2010-8-3, § II, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 12-303. - Responsibility of wrecker service companies. 
(a)  Wrecker service companies shall maintain a daily list of vehicles towed and/or stored for police-initiated towing and storage services. The list shall contain details as to the make, year, model, color, vehicle I.D. number, license plate number, name of owner, and the purpose of removing and/or storing vehicle. The records shall be retained for a period of 12 months and shall be made available to the police department upon request during normal business hours, Monday through Friday (8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.). 
(b)  Wrecker service companies shall be responsible to the vehicle owner for all damages done during towing and storage of any vehicles entrusted to them under this article. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of every driver of a wrecker service vehicle to tow vehicles in a professional manner and to deal with the public in a professional and courteous manner. 
(d)  Reasonable care shall be taken by wrecker service personnel to ensure no further damage will occur to the vehicle towed, either through carelessness or from natural elements, and the wrecker service shall use the proper equipment necessary (e.g. dollies, wheel lifts) to prevent further damage to the vehicles towed. 
(e)  Wrecker service companies shall cooperate with all duly authorized law enforcement officers in the protection of any evidence or in any investigation arising out of a wreck or seizure of a vehicle by any officials. 
(f)  Wrecker service companies shall have a response time of 30 minutes or less for at least 90 percent of all calls during every calendar year. Response time is the time elapsed from the time the 911 center dispatches the wrecker service until the time that the wrecker actually arrives at the location of the vehicle that is to be towed. 
(g)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-276, it shall be the responsibility of the wrecker service company, prior to leaving the scene of any collision, to clean the pavement and right of way of all debris of the collision, including the removal of all glass from paved roadways. In the event that engine fluids have spilled on the roadway, the wrecker service shall provide and spread only that amount of oil dry material on the affected area in order to render the roadway safe for vehicular traffic. 
(h)  A wrecker service company may release any vehicle to the registered owner, unless a hold has been placed on the vehicle by the arresting officer, or a court order prohibits the release. 
(i)  Wrecker service companies shall not go to any accident scene unless: 
(1)  Called by the police department; 
(2)  Called by the vehicle owner/operator; or 
(3)  There exists an extreme emergency immediately endangering life or property. 
(j)  Wrecker service companies shall provide information to the police department under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Whenever any wrecked or abandoned vehicle is removed without the request, direction or participation of the police department, the wrecker service performing the removal shall, if the owner is unknown and within 72 hours of such removal, furnish to the police department on a form approved by the police department the following information with respect to such vehicle: tag number and description, including year, model, make, color and vehicle identification number. 
(2)  Upon receipt of such information, the police department shall immediately take steps to ascertain the identity of the vehicle owner and notify them of the time and place of removal and of the present whereabouts of the vehicle. 
(3)  Nothing in this article shall relieve any wrecker service of any of the requirements imposed by virtue of O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq., or by virtue of any other law with respect to the duties, among others, to make diligent inquiries as to the ownership of vehicles and notification to owners. 
(Ord. No. 85-5-1, § 1, 5-6-85; Code 1981, § 10-2103; Ord. No. 93-12-3, § IV, 12-6-93; Ord. No. 2010-8-3, § III, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 12-304. - Regulation of fees for services rendered. 
(a)  Fees for on-call services rendered under this article shall not exceed the schedule of fees for services rendered, on file in the clerk's office, which are hereby incorporated by reference herein and made a part of this article. 
(b)  The wrecker service shall post all towing fees, reflecting the prices to be charged to the public. Fees shall be posted in open view to the public in the wrecker service's lobby. In addition, the wrecker service shall deliver to each owner or representative of every towed vehicle present at the scene of the tow a pre-printed disclosure form approved by the City of Rome that clearly provides: 
(1)  The fees to be charged by the wrecker service; 
(2)  Location of storage lots; 
(3)  Times of vehicle release; and 
(4)  Phone number(s) of the wrecker service. 
(c)  The wrecker service shall furnish the person who pays for wrecker services a written receipt on a pre-printed form approved by the City of Rome which contains the same information as the disclosure form described in subsection 12-304(b), and which provides: 
(1)  An itemization of all charges; 
(2)  The name of the person on the scene who recovered the vehicle; and 
(3)  The telephone number of a representative of the City of Rome designated to receive comments about wrecker services. 
(d)  The schedule of fees for on-call services rendered may only be modified by the public safety committee of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 85-5-1, § 1, 5-6-85; Code 1981, § 10-2104; Ord. No. 93-12-3, § V, 12-6-93; Ord. No. 2010-8-3, § IV, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 12-305. - Procedures for city police officers and employees. 
(a)  A schedule shall be set up by the chief of police on a rotating basis for all qualified wrecker service companies which have qualified under this article, which wreckers service companies shall be used as hereinafter provided, except in extreme emergency, where persons are trapped or pinned in or under vehicles, or in burning vehicles, or in danger of drowning by submersion, or where traffic is blocked to prevent normal flow of vehicles, in which event, and only in which event, a police officer or other lawfully authorized officer shall be authorized to call the nearest, most qualified company to prevent serious injury or death. 
(b)  The police officer or other lawfully authorized officer shall first determine whether or not a wrecker is needed, and if a wrecker is needed, shall ascertain whether the owner or operator is in condition to make a preference known, what wrecker service company the owner or operator desires to be called, and shall then call the preferred company desired by the owner or operator of the vehicle if the wrecker service can respond within a reasonable time. Officers can advise the owner or operator that they may request an estimated cost of the towing service. 
(c)  In the event the owner or operator is unable, due to injury or due to a physical or mental impairment, to make a choice, or does not have any preference, then said police officer or other authorized officer shall call the wrecker service company on schedule for that week. 
(d)  If the wrecker service company on the schedule is not reached, the 911 dispatcher shall immediately notify the previous week's approved wrecker service on the list to provide service. 
(e)  If the wrecker service company on the schedule is reached, but is unable to furnish the service, then such wrecker service company shall inform the 911 dispatcher of the name of the qualified and on-call wrecker service company that will be responding to the call. Other substitutions are not allowed and must be done when 911 makes the initial call. Whether on-call or substitution, the fee schedule published by the city shall apply. 
(f)  Except in extreme emergencies, the police officer or other authorized officer shall await the arrival of the wrecker and shall in the meantime try to make the scene of the accident safe for other vehicles, using the road in the vicinity thereof, giving warnings and directing traffic. 
(g)  The police officer or other authorized officer shall make a tow-in report, which shall contain the information and details prescribed by the city (especially the name of the operator and owner), on a form made up for that purpose. The officer shall have the wrecker operator sign the tow-in report and provide a copy of it to the wrecker operator before leaving the scene. The officer shall retain the original for department records. 
(h)  A thorough inventory shall be made by the officer on the scene of personal articles and equipment in the vehicle to be towed, such inventory to be written upon a form provided by the police department. If the officer requests that a vehicle be towed to the police department, the wrecker operator shall have the watch commander sign the tow-in bill. At such time, the watch commander will assume the responsibility for said vehicle, and indicate where said vehicle is to be placed. The watch commander shall forward the tow bill and shall notify the person or persons responsible for follow-up regarding the vehicle. 
(i)  Officers are to insure that a copy of the tow-in report is mailed to the registered owner of an abandoned vehicle. 
(j)  Officers will give the 911 dispatch center as much information as possible about the size of the vehicle and the circumstances. This information will be passed on to the wrecker service, which will make the determination as to which equipment is necessary for the situation. 
(Code 1959, §§ 30-174, 30-175; Code 1981, § 10-2105; Ord. No. 85-5-1, § 1, 5-6-85; Ord. No. 93-12-3, § VI, 12-6-93; Ord. No. 05-7-2, § II, 7-18-05; Ord. No. 2010-8-3, § V, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 12-306. - Wreckers while in use designated authorized emergency vehicles. 
All wreckers used by wrecker service companies, when used in an emergency while carrying on the business of the wrecker service companies, are hereby declared to authorized emergency vehicles, under the purview of the applicable laws of the state. 
(Code 1959, § 30-176; Code 1981, § 10-2106; Ord. No. 85-5-1, § 1, 5-6-85; Ord. No. 93-12-3, § VII, 12-6-93) 
State Law reference— "Authorized emergency vehicle" defined, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1(3); regulations pertaining to authorized emergency vehicles, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-6, 40-6-74. 
Sec. 12-307. - Responsibility for payment. 
All charges and fees for towing and storage of the vehicle towed shall be at the expense of the owner of the vehicle, and against the vehicle itself, as provided by state law. 
(Ord. No. 85-5-1, § 1, 5-6-85; Code 1981, § 10-2107; Ord. No. 93-12-3, § VIII, 12-6-93; Ord. No. 2010-8-3, § VI, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 12-308. - Qualification of wrecker service companies. 
(a)  Any wrecker service company desiring to be qualified to be placed on the rotating schedule for use by the city, under the conditions set out herein, shall file an application before October 1 of the calendar year with the chief of police. 
(b)  After the creation of the official on-call schedule, all wrecker services seeking to be placed on the rotating schedule shall, if qualified, be placed on the next calendar year, following receipt of an acceptable application before the October 1 deadline. 
(c)  A continuing responsibility for eligibility shall include an adequate and reasonable response time to calls made to the scheduled wrecker service company to assure efficient service on a 24-hour basis, and compliance with all sections of chapter 12, article VII of the Code of the City of Rome, Georgia. Companies failing to remain qualified will be notified of the problem, in writing by the chief of police, and shall be given a 15-day period to correct the condition. The wrecker service may be temporarily suspended from service and removed from the approved list during this period. If the company fails to correct the condition within the 15-day period, the company shall be removed from the wrecker service schedule. Appeals to decisions of the police chief may be filed in writing with the city manager. 
(d)  Wrecker service companies desiring to be qualified on the rotating schedule shall agree to waive all charges to the city in the cases of innocent arrests. 
(e)  Wrecker service companies desiring to be qualified on the rotating schedule shall agree that the fee schedule published by the city shall apply to all calls initiated by a police officer or other authorized official to which the wrecker service responds while on call. 
(f)  Notwithstanding anything in chapter 12, article VII of the Code of the City of Rome, Georgia to the contrary, any wrecker service that has an owner or operator that has been convicted of a felony within five years will not be on the City of Rome's rotating schedule for police-initiated tows. All wrecker services desiring to be placed on or to remain on said rotating schedule agree to provide the Rome Police Department, at the time of seeking qualification under this article and thereafter, annually, with a release executed by all owners of each wrecker service and all operators for each wrecker service, which authorizes the Rome Police Department to conduct a criminal records search of said individuals. All wrecker services desiring to qualify or to remain qualified shall also provide a release to the Rome Police Department with respect to all new owners or operators of the wrecker service. 
(g)  The fee schedule which is made a part of this article shall be posted in a conspicuous place at the qualified wrecker service company's place of business, and each wrecker vehicle of the company shall carry a copy of the schedule, for the purpose of furnishing the same for vehicle owners or operators. 
(Ord. No. 93-12-3, § IX, 12-6-93; Ord. No. 2010-8-3, § VII, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 12-309. - Penalties for violations. 
(a)  Violations of the provisions of this article shall be punished as provided in Section 1-9 of the Code of the City of Rome, Georgia, and may be brought on citation in municipal court with or without a prosecutor. 
(b)  The violation of the provisions of this article by any wrecker service may be enjoined by instituting appropriate proceedings for injunction in the courts of competent jurisdiction in this state. Such actions may be maintained notwithstanding that other adequate remedies at law exist. Such actions may be instituted in the name of the governing authority of the city. 
(c)  Violations of provisions of this article by any wrecker service shall be due cause for revocation of any city business license, after notice and hearing before the Rome City Commission Public Safety Committee. 
(d)  Violations of provisions of this article by any wrecker service shall be due cause for removal of the wrecker service from the approved wrecker service list, after notice and hearing before the Rome City Commission Public Safety Committee. 
(e)  The remedies set forth in subsections (a) through (d) of this section are cumulative. 
(Ord. No. 2010-8-3, § VIII, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 12-310. - Fee schedule and operating fees procedures. 
(a)  Basic tow for any vehicles up to 10,000 lbs. within City of Rome, day or night ..... $100.00 
(b)  Additional per hour charge after first hour of service of light duty wrecker ..... 50.00 
(c)  Large wrecker service (GVW over 26,001 lbs.), (per hour after first hour) ..... 250.00 
(d)  Medium wrecker tow of vehicles (GVW over 10,001 lbs.), (first hour) ..... 250.00 
Per hour after first hour ..... 125.00 
(e)  Supplies used at scene (sand, oil dry, etc.), up to ..... 50.00 
(f)  Use of dollies (if needed) ..... 30.00 
(g)  Daily storage for vehicle towed (commencing 24 hours after pick-up) ..... 18.00 
(h)  Winching recovery fee for vehicles (off of road right-of-way) ..... 50.00 
(i)  After business hours vehicle release fee if wrecker service has to return to storage lot (not required) ..... 50.00 
Vehicle can be picked up Monday through Saturday 8:00 a.m.—5:00 p.m. without charge. 
(Ord. No. 2010-8-3, § IX, 8-16-10) 
Secs. 12-311—12-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - RAILROADS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— Railroad grade crossings, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-190 et seq.; railroad companies, O.C.G.A. § 46-8-1 et seq. 

Sec. 12-331. - Bridge or trestle—Definition. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in section 12-332, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Railroad bridge or trestle means any bridge or trestle upon which railroad tracks are laid for the exclusive purpose of train traffic and not defined as a bridge or trestle maintained by any railroad company for the general public's use and for the exclusive purpose of providing for pedestrian and motor vehicle traffic. 
(Code 1959, § 26-1; Code 1981, § 10-2081) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-332. - Same—Walking or trespassing upon prohibited; application of provisions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to walk upon or otherwise trespass upon any railroad trestle or bridge within the city limits, except that trestle running from the area of Broad Street and West First Street to Heritage Park, which has been specifically converted to pedestrian usage. 
(b)  This section shall have no application to persons employed by the owners of the railroad bridges or trestles when those persons are engaged in the scope of their employment or to any person riding as a passenger on any train being operated over and upon the railroad bridges and trestles. 
(Code 1959, § 26-2; Code 1981, § 10-2082) 
Sec. 12-333. - Speed limit; warning. 
(a)  The running speed of trains and vehicles on all railroad tracks within the corporate limits of the city shall not at any time be at a rate greater than 40 miles per hour. 
(b)  The train crew shall give ample warning to all persons of the approach of the train by ringing bells and sounding horns and whistles, so as to afford all reasonable opportunity to avoid collisions. 
(Code 1959, § 26-4; Ord. No. 78-10, § 1, 12-19-77; Code 1981, § 10-2084) 
Sec. 12-334. - Warning devices at specified crossings. 
The Southern Railway Company shall install and maintain automatically controlled warning gates at the crossing of East Second Avenue and the Southern Railway Company's main line, and at the crossing of East 12th Street and the Southern Railway Company's main line. 
(Ord. No. 78-10, § 2, 12-19-77; Code 1981, § 10-2085) 
Secs. 12-335—12-360. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - TRANSIT DEPARTMENT[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 12-361. - Created; named. 
A department of the city to be known as the Rome Transit Department is hereby created. 
(Code 1959, § 30A-1; Code 1981, § 10-3001) 
Sec. 12-362. - Transit committee; membership and authority. 
(a)  The standing committee of the city commission known as the transit committee shall consist of at least three members of the city commission. 
(b)  The transit committee shall have full authority to make such rules and regulations for the operation of the transit department as the committee deems advisable. 
(c)  No increase or decrease of transportation services to the areas served by the transit department or fares shall be made without the approval of the city commission. 
(Code 1959, § 30A-2; Code 1981, § 10-3002) 
Sec. 12-363. - Superintendent. 
A department director of the transit department shall be appointed by the city manager with the concurrence of a majority of the city commission. The department director may be discharged by the city manager, with or without cause, as provided in the Charter of the city. The department director shall be known as the superintendent of the transit department. 
(Code 1959, § 30A-3; Code 1981, § 10-3003) 
Sec. 12-364. - Personnel; physical examination required of drivers. 
(a)  The transit department director, assisted by the personnel department, is authorized to hire such personnel as shall be necessary to operate the department. 
(b)  Every employee of the transit department who is a driver must undergo and pass a physical examination at least once each year to determine physical fitness to drive. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Code, no employee of the transit department shall be employed by the city after attaining the age of 65 years. 
(Code 1959, § 30A-4; Code 1981, § 10-3004) 
Sec. 12-365. - Funds; accounts; reports. 
A separate account shall be set up at a banking depository as designated by the city commission for the safekeeping of the monies of the transit department. Separate records showing the operation of the department shall be maintained by the transit department under the direction of the finance director. Daily reports of the receipts of the department shall be furnished to the secretary. 
(Code 1959, § 30A-5; Code 1981, § 10-3005) 
Sec. 12-366. - Employees handling monies to be bonded. 
All employees of the transit department who handle monies of the department shall furnish the city a bond in an amount to be set by the finance director to insure the faithful performance of their duties. Such bond shall be paid for out of transit department funds. 
(Code 1959, § 30A-6; Code 1981, § 10-3006) 
Sec. 12-367. - Liability insurance to be carried. 
Liability insurance in an amount to be determined by the transit committee of the city commission shall be carried on all vehicles operated or connected with the transit department. 
(Code 1959, § 30A-7; Code 1981, § 10-3007) 
ARTICLE X. - FIRE LANES 

Sec. 12-368. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in a given section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Fire lane means any area on public or private property which has been designated as a fire lane or prohibited zone by any sign or pavement markings bearing "Fire Lane" or "Prohibited Zone," and shall apply at all times. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2-1, § II, 2-7-11) 
Sec. 12-369. - Application. 
The provisions of this ordinance shall apply to all vehicles operated at shopping centers or parking lots or similar areas customarily used by the public. It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park any vehicle within any fire lane or prohibited area which would prohibit access to the structure by any fire truck or fire apparatus, police, ambulance or other emergency equipment. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2-1, § II, 2-7-11) 
Sec. 12-370. - Exceptions. 
Any vehicle designated as an emergency vehicle when responding to an emergency or fire alarm may park or stand, irrespective of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2-1, § III, 2-7-11) 
Sec. 12-371. - Enforcement. 
It shall be the duty of the police department and/or the fire marshal, or his designee, to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2-1, § IV, 2-7-11) 
Sec. 12-372. - Penalty for violations. 
Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision under this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. 
(Ord. No. 2011-2-1, § IV, 2-7-11) 
Secs. 12.373—12.379. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - PERSONAL TRANSPORTATION VEHICLES 

Sec. 12-380. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this article: 
Authorized street means a public roadway of the city by whatever name (e.g. road, alley, avenue, street, boulevard, etc.) that: 
(1)  Has a posted speed limit of 25 miles per hour or less; 
(2)  Is not designated as part of either the state or federal highway system; 
(3)  Has not been designated as an unauthorized street by ordinance or resolution by the the city commission. 
Driver means the person driving and having physical control over a personal transportation vehicle. 
Owner means the person holding title to the PTV who has a majority ownership interest in the PTV. 
Parking area means those areas accessible to the public by motor vehicular traffic and which are designated for the temporary parking of motor vehicles, usually in places referred to as parking lots. 
Personal transportation vehicle (PTV) means any motor vehicle: 
(1)  With a minimum of four wheels; 
(2)  Capabable of a maximum level ground speed of less than 20 miles per hour; 
(3)  With a maximum gross vehicle weight, unladed or empty weight, of 1,375 pounds; and 
(4)  Capable of transporting not more than eight persons. 
The term does not include any mobility aids, including power wheelchairs and scooters, which can be used indoors and outdoors for the express purpose of enabling mobility for a person with a disability. The term also does not include any all-terrain vehicle, which means any motorized vehicle designed for off-road use which is equipped with three or more low pressure tires and with a seat to be straddled by the operator with handlebars for steering control. 
Unauthorized street means a public roadway of the city by whatever name (e.g. road, alley, avenue, highway, route, boulevard, etc.) that has been designated by the city commission by ordinance or resolution as an unauthorized street. 
(Ord. No. 2016-03-01, § I, 3-14-2016) 
Sec. 12-381. - Registration permit. 
Before any PTV may be operated over an authorized street or parking area of the city it shall be registered and permitted by the police department. If the PTV is compliant with local and state law, then a decal shall be issued from that department signifying its registration. The registration requirements include the following specifics: 
(1)  Only those persons 18 years of age or older may register a PTV; 
(2)  The person registering the PTV must be the owner of the PTV; 
(3)  The registration permit received from the police department shall be maintained in the PTV at all times and shall be produced for inspection upon request. 
(4)  The registration application shall be made on a form supplied by the city and shall contain the following information: 
a.  Name and address of owner. 
b.  Model, make, name and PTV identification number. 
c.  Current driver's license number of owner. 
d.  Such other information as the city may require. 
(5)  The registration application shall be accompanied by a fee of $15.00. 
(6)  The registration application shall be accompanied by evidence of personal liability insurance coverage consistent with the minimum requriements of state law for operational motor vehicles. 
(7)  The registration shall be effective until such time that it may be revoked or the PTV is transferred to a new owner. If the registered owner transfers ownership of the PTV, the registration permit must be returned to the police department. 
(8)  It shall be the PTV owner's responsibility to ensure that the information on the application remains current and accurate. 
The city commission may, at its discretion, waive registration requirements for city sponsored special events of a limited duration. 
(Ord. No. 2016-03-01, § I, 3-14-2016) 
Sec. 12-382. - Revocation. 
The registration permit may be revoked if: 
(1)  The permit holder no longer has a valid driver's license. 
(2)  The owner or driver of a PTV fails to abide by the rules an regulations of this article. 
(3)  The owner or driver of a PTV fails to abide by the traffic laws in use for a PTV on an authorized street or parking area. 
(Ord. No. 2016-03-01, § I, 3-14-2016) 
Sec. 12-383. - Transfer. 
Upon transfer of ownership of the PTV to a person who intends to operate it over the authorized streets and parking areas, the new owner must register the PTV as outlined herein above. Such registration by the new owner must occur within ten days of the transfer of ownership. 
(Ord. No. 2016-03-01, § I, 3-14-2016) 
Sec. 12-384. - Operation regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to operate a PTV on any street within the city that is not an authorized street. 
(b)  Only those persons who hold a valid motor vehicle driver's license and who are 18 years of age or older may drive a PTV on the authorized streets and parking areas of the city. 
(c)  All drivers of PTVs shall abide by all traffic regulations applicable to vehicular traffic when using the authorized streets and parking areas of the city. 
(d)  Current proof of liability insurance coverage shall be maintained in the PTV when operated and available for inspection upon request. 
(e)  A PTV shall not be operated to transport more than eight persons. 
(f)  A PTV shall not be operated on the sidewalks at any time. 
(g)  Every driver of a PTV shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all of the rules of the road and duties applicable to the driver of any other vehicle. 
(h)  All PTVs are entitled to the full use of a lane on the authorized streets and parking areas of the city and no motor vehicle shall be driven in such a manner as to deprive any PTV of the full use of a lane. 
(i)  The driver of a PTV shall not overtake and pass in the same lane occupied by the vehicle being overtaken. 
(j)  The driver of a PTV operating on an authorized street may cross a state or federal route only at intersections that have been designated for such purposes by the state department of transportation. 
(k)  All laws and ordinances relative to alcohol and its use, including open container laws, which apply to traffic on the streets of the city shall also apply to drivers and occupants of PTVs. 
(l)  All drivers and passengers must remain seated at all times during the operation of the PTV. No person may sit on the driver's lap during the operation of the PTV. 
(Ord. No. 2016-03-01, § I, 3-14-2016) 
Sec. 12-385. - Vehicle standards and equipment. 
Each PTV shall meet the following design standards and shall be equipped with the following operational equipment: 
(1)  A minimum of four wheels; 
(2)  Capable of a maximum level ground speed of no more than 20 mph; 
(3)  A maximum gross vehicle weight, empty and unladen, of 1,375 pounds; 
(4)  A maximum transport capacity of eight persons; 
(5)  A braking system sufficient for the weight and passenger capacity of the vehicle including a parking brake; 
(6)  A reverse warning device functional at all times when the directional control is in the reverse position; 
(7)  A main power switch. When the switch is in the "off" position or the key or other device that activates the switched is removed, the motive power circuit shall be inoperative. If the switch uses a key, it shall be removable only in the "off" position; 
(8)  Head lamps; 
(9)  Reflex reflectors; 
(10)  Tail lamps; 
(11)  Front and rear turn signals; 
(12)  A horn; 
(13)  A rearview mirror; 
(14)  Safety warning labels; and 
(15)  Hip restraints and hand holds or a combination thereof. 
Each PTV shall be maintained in working order and kept in good condition and shall be subject to inspection by city officials and/or the city police department at reasonable times and intervals. 
(Ord. No. 2016-03-01, § I, 3-14-2016) 
Sec. 12-386. - Liability. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed as an assumption of liability by the city for any injuries to persons or property which may result from the operation of a PTV or by the failure of the city to revoke said permit. Adoption of this article is not to be relied upon as a determination by the city that operation of a PTV on public roads is safe or advisable if done in accordance with this article. By regulating such operation the city is merely addressing safety issues. All persons who operate or ride in PTVs on public roads do so with their own judgment and at their own risk, and must be observant of, and attentive to the safety of themselves and others, including their passengers, other motorists, bicyclists, and pedestrians. 
(Ord. No. 2016-03-01, § I, 3-14-2016) 
Sec. 12-387. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates the terms of this article shall be punished as follows: 
In addition to whatever violations of the driver of a PTV may be subject to pursuant to Georgia law and or Code of Municipal Ordinances, the registered owner of the PTV shall be subject to the following civil penalties: 
(1)  For the first offense a fine of not less than $50.00; and if not timely paid, revocation of the permit. 
(2)  For the second offense, a fine of not less than $100.00; and if not timely paid, revocation of the permit. 
(3)  For the third offense, the registration for the PTV shall be revoked. In the event the registration is revoked under this section, the PTV cannot thereafter be re-registered by the same owner or any family member for a period of two years. 
(Ord. No. 2016-03-01, § I, 3-14-2016) 
Secs. 12-388—12-399. - Reserved. 
Chapter 13 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Municipal court, art. XV. 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; city divisions and departments, § 2-2; traffic violations bureau, § 12-101 et seq.; police, ch. 17. 
State Constitution reference— Municipal courts authorized, art. VI, § I, par. I; continuation of municipal courts, art. VI, § X, par. I. 
State Law reference— Magistrate court serving as municipal court, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-150 et seq.; municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq.; limitations on home rule powers, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6; jurisdiction to impose punishments for driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-391. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Judge. 
(a)  The judge of the municipal court shall be a member of the State Bar of Georgia, shall be at least 21 years of age and shall have practiced law for at least three years. 
(b)  The city manager shall have authority to appoint standby associate judges to serve from time to time in the judge's absence. Any standby associate judge shall possess the qualifications set forth in subsection (a) for the judge of the municipal court. 
(Code 1981, § 2-5001) 
Sec. 13-2. - Sessions. 
(a)  A regular session of the municipal court shall be held at least once each week at a fixed hour of a fixed day as may be determined by the judge; provided, that any session may be dispensed with when there is no business pending in the court or no cases are ready for trial. 
(b)  The municipal court may hold special sessions of court when, in the judge's opinion, it is necessary or there is urgent cause for the trial of accused persons before the next regularly scheduled session of the court. 
(Code 1981, § 2-5002) 
Sec. 13-3. - Clerk. 
(a)  There shall be a clerk of court who shall be appointed or removed by the city manager or his designee. 
(b)  The clerk of court shall: 
(1)  Prepare all subpoenas and warrants and maintain a docket thereof that will show the name of the person for whom the subpoena or warrant was issued, its date, at whose instance it was issued and to whom it was delivered. 
(2)  Be the custodian of the seal of the court and have authority to certify copies of all official records of the court and to maintain the proper books of accounts, including receipts and disbursements, which the court may maintain. 
(3)  Perform such other duties as may be imposed by the judge. 
(Code 1981, § 2-5003) 
Sec. 13-4. - Rules. 
The municipal court shall be controlled by the rules of the superior courts, as far as they are applicable to municipal courts, and a sound construction of the Constitutions of the state and of the United States and the Charter and ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 12-2; Code 1981, § 2-5004) 
Sec. 13-5. - Practice. 
The city shall have the opening and conclusion of each case, unless the defendant introduces no evidence; then the defendant shall be entitled to the conclusion. The city shall announce first whether it is ready for trial, and if not ready shall be held to as strict a showing for a continuance as the defendant. The rules of evidence shall be the same as in the superior court, as far as applicable to the case on trial. 
(Code 1959, § 12-3; Code 1981, § 2-5005) 
Sec. 13-6. - Persons charged with offense; summons; trial. 
Any person who is charged with an offense against any of the provisions of this Code or any ordinances of the city shall be informed by summons in writing served on him of the nature and cause of the accusation; shall have compulsory process for obtaining witnesses in his behalf; shall have a speedy trial; shall be confronted with the witnesses against him; and shall have the privilege of cross examination as in the superior courts of the state. The same rules as to examination of witnesses and the evidence adduced as obtained in such courts, as far as they are applicable to examining courts, shall be applicable to cases before the municipal court. The person accused shall have the privilege of defending himself, by counsel or by himself, or both, whichever shall seem proper to him. No one shall be condemned, fined or punished without a chance of being heard in his defense. 
(Code 1959, § 12-5; Code 1981, § 2-5006) 
Sec. 13-7. - Form and execution of summons. 
It shall be the duty of the clerk of court in all cases where complaint is made or information given of any violation of the laws or ordinances of the city, whether the accused is confined in jail or not, to issue a summons directed to the accused requiring him to appear in the municipal court to answer such charge, which summons shall set forth the offense and the time and place of trial, bear test in the name of the judge of the municipal court, be signed officially by the clerk and directed to the chief of police or any police officer of the city to be executed, which police officer shall execute the same by serving a copy on the accused or leaving it at his place of residence. 
(Code 1959, § 12-6; Code 1981, § 2-5007) 
Sec. 13-8. - Witness—Subpoena. 
Whenever the attendance of any witness may be required before the municipal court to establish any fact, the clerk of court shall issue a subpoena, directed to the witness, stating the time and place of trial and the parties to the case, and bearing test in the name of the judge of the municipal court, which subpoena shall be served as other summons by any police officer. 
(Code 1959, § 12-7; Code 1981, § 2-5008) 
Sec. 13-9. - Same—Defaulting. 
If any person, summoned as a witness under this chapter, shall fail, neglect or refuse to attend a trial or render at the time a sufficient excuse in the judgement of the court, the defaulting witness shall be liable to a penalty in accordance with section 1-9. If the case shall be continued on account of the witness' absence, the court may issue an attachment against such witness, requiring him to show cause on the day appointed for trial, why he should not be further dealt with for contempt. Any police officer, by virtue of such attachment, shall arrest and confine the person, so as to have him before the court at such time as may be appointed for further hearing of the original complaint. 
(Code 1959, § 12-8; Code 1981, § 2-5009) 
Sec. 13-10. - Continuances. 
Where the ends of justice require it, cases may be continued. All continuances shall be addressed to the sound legal discretion of the court under the rules governing the superior courts of this state. 
(Code 1959, § 12-9; Code 1981, § 2-5010) 
Sec. 13-11. - Plea of guilty in absence of defendant. 
Any person against whom any complaint is lodged or information given in the municipal court may file a plea of guilty under such regulations and upon such terms as the court may prescribe. If such person cannot attend the trial, the court may pass such order or sentence in the case as if the person were personally present. 
(Code 1959, § 12-10; Code 1981, § 2-5011) 
Sec. 13-12. - Persons implicated to be tried. 
If on the trial of any case before the municipal court, it appears that any other person besides the one on trial has violated a provision of this Code or any ordinance of the city, he may then and there be tried, if present, unless the case is continued for legal cause. 
(Code 1959, § 12-11; Code 1981, § 2-5012) 
Sec. 13-13. - Contempt of court. 
Any person who, during a sitting of the municipal court, shall be guilty of contempt of court, or refuse to abide by any sentence or order of such court, shall be punished in accordance with section 1-9. 
(Code 1959, § 12-12; Code 1981, § 2-5013) 
Charter reference— Punishment for contempt of court, § 15-1. 
Sec. 13-14. - Docket. 
A docket shall be kept in the office of clerk of court on which shall appear the name of every defendant charged with a violation of this Code or any city ordinances, or of any offense over which the municipal court has jurisdiction. At the trial of all cases in the municipal court, the judge of the municipal court shall record opposite the statement of the case the punishment inflicted and the date; and the clerk of court shall enter, under the judge of the municipal court's sentence, the final disposition of the case, that is, whether the fine, if any, was collected and the date of such collection and when and to whom such amounts were turned over by the clerk of court. 
(Code 1959, § 12-13; Ord. No. 84-5-4, § 1, 5-7-84; Code 1981, § 2-5014) 
Sec. 13-15. - Enforcement of penalties against corporations. 
Whenever a corporation shall violate any provision of this Code or any ordinance of the city, a warrant shall issue against such corporation for violating such provision, and the clerk of court shall issue a copy of such warrant, which shall be served by the chief of police or any police officer of the city upon any officer of the corporation to be found in the city, or upon the agent, superintendent or person in charge of the business of the corporation in the city.
